This rockfall was so large that it traveled all the way to the Merced River. Extremely large rockfalls like this are called rock avalanches. This particular rock avalanche is made up of nearly one and a half million tons of rock! We have dated the other rock avalanches in Yosemite and found that there is a strong link to earthquakes, just as John Muir observed on that fateful night in 1872. As you make your way to the final stop on this tour, look around at the vast field of boulders and imagine the chaos that took place here just a few thousand years ago.
data.audioDescription: A dirt path leads into an area surrounded by trees. Large boulder fields are on both sides of the path. An opening in the trees reveals a view looking up the sheer granite valley walls that are blackened with lichen. Several white patches can be found on the rock wall, indicating areas of fresh rockfall.

data.title: Geology Tour - Origin of Yosemite Falls
data.listingDescription: A tour stop that allows you to notice one of the most iconic features in Yosemite; the cascading waterfalls of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls.

images.altText: A dashed yellow line follows a curved gully to the left of a tall waterfall.
images.caption: A dashed yellow line indicates the old path of Yosemite Creek just left of Upper Yosemite Fall. Photo by Kalen Martin-Gross.

data.bodyText:
As you made your way to this stop you surely noticed one of the most iconic features in Yosemite; the cascading waterfalls of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. Together these waterfalls plunge a total of 2,425 feet, or about 740 meters, making Yosemite Falls one of the tallest waterfalls in the world. Yosemite Falls is unlike other waterfalls in Yosemite and the Sierra Nevada. To illustrate what makes Yosemite Falls so different, we'll have to travel back in time hundreds of thousands of years to a time when glaciers filled Yosemite Valley to the rim.

Glaciers are masses of ice that form from the accumulation of snow, and that flow downhill under their own weight. As they move, glaciers scrape and pluck at the bedrock, excavating and transporting huge amounts of sediment. When glaciers melt, they drop the rocky debris they had been carrying in mound-like ridges called moraines.

There have been many glacial periods over the last few million years, glaciers repeatedly advanced into Yosemite Valley from the high country and then retreated back. The most recent time that a glacier occupied Yosemite Valley was about 20,000 years ago. At that time, the glacier extended to as far west as Bridal Veil Fall and reached about two-thirds of the way up the cliffs. Earlier glacial periods were larger, with glaciers extending west as far as the town of El Portal and reaching the rim of Yosemite Valley.

Hundreds of thousands of years ago, Yosemite Creek didn't leap directly off the cliff, but rather cascaded down the steep gully that you can see to the left of the falls. What caused the creek to shift position? We can't see it from here, but behind Yosemite Falls there is a moraine left behind by one of those ancient glaciers. The moraine diverted the Yosemite Creek from its path down the steep gully and forced it directly off the cliff. This unique geological accident created one of the tallest waterfalls in the world and one of the most iconic features in Yosemite.

As you walk to the next stop make some observations about the ground surface that surrounds the trail.
data.audioDescription: Along a paved path on the outskirts of a large, open meadow, views of Yosemite Falls and the tall cliff walls on the east end of Yosemite Valley open up.

data.title: Geology Tour - Reflections
data.listingDescription: Looking upstream from Sentinel Bridge you can often see Half-Dome's reflection in the Merced River. This picturesque view may seem timeless, but in fact it is just a quick snapshot in time.

images.altText: A rock formation that resembles a halved-dome, reflects in a river that is lined with pine trees.
images.caption: Half Dome reflects in the Merced River. Photo by Jennifer Aldred.

data.bodyText: Looking upstream from Sentinel Bridge you can often see Half-Dome's reflection in the Merced River. This picturesque view may seem timeless, but in fact it is just a quick snapshot in time. Yosemite's landscape is the result of millions of years of change, and that change continues today. Even at this moment, that granite giant is slowly wearing away from the forces of water and wind, and sometimes falling away catastrophically. Some of that material makes up the sediment particles in the riverbed before you slowly drifting along in the current and sometimes sweeping away in floods. Take a moment to reflect on the natural processes that continue to shape the awe-inspiring landscape around you. Thanks for joining me today. I hope you have enjoyed learning about the living geology of Yosemite National Park.
data.audioDescription:
Sentinel Bridge is a great place to experience Half Dome. Many photographers enjoy gathering here to take pictures of Half Dome and its reflection in the Merced River, especially when the colors of sunset play on its rock face. The bridge is completely made of stone and is slightly arched. A wayside exhibit is affixed to the metal railing that is adhered to the stone barrier-wall on the bridge. On the east side of the bridge, tall trees line the banks of the river and Half Dome rises over the tree line. A wayside exhibit is titled, The Story of Half Dome, and has an orange-toned, faint, background photo of textured granite rock. Text reads, millions of years ago the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there never was a matching half. Undercut by glaciers near the base, slabs of rock fell away from a broad vertical crack in the granite, leaving a sheer face. Remnants of the missing rock still project from Half Dome's rim.

There are more granite domes here than in any other place in the world. Massive granite domes from when large curved layers of rock "exfoliate" or slab off.

Illustrated brochure: A side profile of Half Dome, with dark shadows in the front and low laying clouds floating below its face. In the background, some grey peaks cross the skyline and the sky is a bright orange and yellow. The text reads Yosemite Valley, on top, and Southern Pacific, on bottom.

Caption: c. 1910

Black and white postcard: Half Dome and trees surrounding it have an almost symmetrical reflection in the Merced River.

Caption: Half Dome from Sentinel Bridge, postcard, c. 1940. Since the mid-19th century, countless images of the park's most famous dome, Half Dome, have been circulated. Its profile has become an enduring and instantly recognizable symbol of Yosemite.

A section on the left side of the panel has a header that reads, An Ahwahneechee Tale of Half Dome. Text below it reads, long ago, two travelers, Tissiak and her husband, Tokoyee, fought with each other. He became so angry that he began to beat her; enraged, she hurled her basket of acorns at him. As they stood facing each other, they were turned to stone for their wickedness. The acorn basket (Basket Dome) lies upturned beside Tokoyee (North Dome) and the rock face of Tissiak (Half Dome) is stained with her tears.

Photo: Half Dome is illuminated with the orange light of the alpen glow. Behind Half Dome, other mountains a lit as well, and the sky is full of dark clouds.

data.title: Geology Tour - Rockfall Hazards
data.listingDescription: As you walked to this stop, you probably noticed the steep, towering cliff and the piles of boulders, called talus, at the base of the cliff. Some of the talus boulders can be quite large. These boulders were once a part of the cliff face and broke loose in events called rockfalls in which boulders fall, bounce and roll down the cliffs and talus piles.

images.altText: A thick cloud of dust hurls into the air near the base of a rock formation that appears to look like a half of a dome, sheer face forward.
images.caption: A rockfall from the face of Half-Dome on July 27, 2006. NPS photo.

data.bodyText:
As you walked to this stop, you probably noticed the steep, towering cliff and the piles of boulders, called talus, at the base of the cliff. Some of the talus boulders can be quite large. These boulders were once a part of the cliff face and broke loose in events called rockfalls in which boulders fall, bounce and roll down the cliffs and talus piles. The gigantic boulder in front of you now is from a rockfall that occurred about 3,000 years ago. This boulder is one of the largest you will see in Yosemite Valley but boulders like this are actually fairly common. All of them represent past rockfalls. Since glaciers retreated from Yosemite Valley, rockfalls became the dominant geological force eroding the cliffs and they still occur today. Rockfalls happen year-round, with an average of about one event every five days. As of 2020, there have been 16 deaths and more than one hundred injuries related to rockfalls in Yosemite.

Geologists study rockfalls to help the Park Service reduce risk. Research has identified areas in Yosemite Valley at the highest risk from rockfalls. The Park Service use this information to move buildings out of these areas or changed how the buildings are used. These efforts led to a 95% reduction in risk from rockfalls. However, that does not mean people are completely safe. Rockfalls are inherently unpredictable, in part because there are many natural forces that can trigger rockfalls, ranging from rainfall to earthquakes. Rockfalls are a natural force shaping this landscape but they also present a hazard that we need to be aware of as we enjoy this beautiful park.

As you walk along the trail east of the Chapel, take note of the large boulder field on both sides of the trail - what observations can you make about it?
data.audioDescription: A dirt trail leads into a dense forest just behind the Yosemite Chapel. A large, shed sized boulder sits at the edge of the forest and an open meadow. boulder fields are on the other side of the dirt path.

data.title: Geology Tour - Welcome
data.listingDescription: Fun facts about Yosemite's geology that will increase your appreciation for the natural beauty all around you.

images.altText: A sign reads "flood water level, 11 pm, January 2, 1997," and shows an arrow pointing left to right, indicating water levels. Yosemite Falls is in the background.
images.caption: A sign in Cook's Meadow shows water levels during the historic 1997 flood. Photo by Kalen Martin-Gross.

data.bodyText:
Hi, this is Greg Stock, Yosemite's park geologist. I'd like to share some fun facts about Yosemite's geology that I hope will increase your appreciation for the natural beauty all around you.

Let's begin by observing the sign before you that shows the floodwater level on January 2, 1997. The horizontal line on that sign marks the height of water during the largest and most damaging flood in Yosemite's recorded history. In your mind, extend that line across the valley and imagine floodwaters spread almost wall to wall. We will talk more about this flood at another stop, but let this image set the stage as we explore how natural forces shape Yosemite National Park.
data.audioDescription:
Stop 1 is a prime spot to experience Yosemite Falls. It is located to the north side of Sentinel Bridge Parking, which is lined with a wooden fence that separates the sidewalk from the large open meadow that allows views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. Bus stop #11 stands at the southeast side of the parking lot. Four benches, a green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, wood, shelter are all by the bus stop. Further south from the bus stop, a crosswalk leads across the street to the Sentinel Bridge.

A nearby sign reads, flood water level, 11pm, January 2, 1997. A double-sided arrow points from left to right, indicating the water level. The sign itself stands over six feet high.

data.title: Geology Tour - Yosemite Underwater: Twentieth Century Floods
data.listingDescription: On most days, the Merced River flows peacefully beneath Superintendents Bridge. However, on January 2, 1997 the Merced was a raging torrent. The 1997 flood is the most damaging in Yosemite's recorded history. In the center of the valley, floodwaters were more than 10 feet, or 3 meters, deep.

images.altText: adfa
images.caption: Superintendents Bridge after the January 2, 1997 flood.

data.bodyText:
On most days, the Merced River flows peacefully beneath Superintendents Bridge. However, on January 2, 1997 the Merced was a raging torrent. The 1997 flood is the most damaging in Yosemite's recorded history. In the center of the valley, floodwaters were more than 10 feet, or 3 meters, deep. The flood damaged roads and infrastructure, resulting in prolonged closure of Yosemite Valley. The metal marker attached to the bridge indicates the height of the five largest floods in recorded history. Compare your height to the flood water level of 1997 to get a sense of the depth of water above the bridge. Now compare it to the four other major floods. What do these floods all have in common besides their large size? Here's a hint: What time of year did these floods occur? That's right, they all occurred during the winter months.

Yosemite, like the rest of California, receives most of its annual precipitation in just a few months, usually between November and March. During these cold winter months, especially at high elevations, the precipitation falls as snow. In the high country, snow depths can be tens of feet deep. Typically, the snow will melt as temperatures warm in the summer and the rivers gently rise in response. This means that there is usually a several month-long lag between the time when the snow falls and when the rivers rise. However, in some years warm, tropical storms originating near Hawaii make their way to California. The warm air accompanying these storms raises the snowline to a higher elevation. The snowline is an elevation line, controlled by air temperature, that divides rain from snow. In Yosemite, the wintertime snowline is usually around 6,000 feet, or about 1,800 meters, but during these warm storms, snowline can rise to 10,000 feet, or more than 3,000 meters, elevation. If the snowline is higher, this means that more rain is falling over the watershed instead of snow. You've probably seen heavy rain running off a parking lot. Well, heavy rain running off large areas of granite bedrock looks similar. The combination of heavy rain and melted snow across the entire watershed produces extreme flood events. It is under these conditions that the largest, most damaging floods in Yosemite's history have occurred. As global temperatures warm the snowline in Yosemite is likely to increase in elevation also increasing the likelihood of future floods.

Our next stop is at a huge boulder behind the Chapel, across Southside Drive. To get there, please use one of the two crosswalks crossing Southside Drive and watch for cars. The trail picks up at the far end of the parking lot next to the Chapel.
data.audioDescription:
A wooden bridge with wood posts and railings expands across the Merced River. Trees line the banks of the river, up and down stream. A wayside exhibit is affixed to the wooden railing and is titled Twentieth Century Floods. The exhibit panel has a background photo of Half Dome and surrounding rock formations reflected in a large body of water in an area that spills into a meadow. Panel text reads, in the 20th century, five dramatic winter floods inundated this area. This marker indicates how high the Merced River floodwaters rose during those years. A table shows three columns with headers that read, date, cubic feet/second at Happy Isles Gauging Station, and Height of water level above this bridge. Five rows of data are below each header. The first row reads, December 11, 1937 - 8,400 cubic feet/second - 2.7 feet. The second row reads, November 18, 1950 - 9,260 cubic feet/second - 3.9 feet. The third row reads December 23, 1955 - 9,860 cubic feet/second - 4.1 feet. The fourth row reads, December 23, 1964 - 9,240 cubic feet/second - 3.8 feet. And, the fifth row reads January 2, 1997 - 10,100 cubic feet/second - 5.3 feet.

A bronze water marker is located on the bridge next to the wayside exhibit. It is over five feet tall and about one foot wide. Wavy strips of metal, only a few inches apart from each other, connect two thick poles on both ends of the strips, from bottom to top. Five dates are embedded within the poles. The bottom date is 1937 and is placed about three feet above the bridge. Then 1964, 1950, and 1955, are stacked on top of each other, about four feet above the bridge, and 1997 being the top date, is just over five feet above the bridge.

data.title: Glacier Point
data.listingDescription: The Glacier Point Road is closed for 2022. This world renowned overlook gives visitors a grand view of Yosemite Valley from above and a captivating vista of the park's southeastern high peaks. Glacier Point, an overlook with a commanding view of Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls, is located 30 miles (a one-hour drive) from either Yosemite Valley or Wawona. The road stays open as weather permits.

images.altText: Visitors at Glacier Point enjoying the view
images.title: Glacier Point
images.caption: View from Glacier Point

data.bodyText:
This world-renowned overlook gives visitors a grand view of Yosemite Valley from above and a captivating vista of the park's southeastern high peaks.

Glacier Point, an overlook with a commanding view of Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls, is located 30 miles (a one-hour drive) from either Yosemite Valley or Wawona. A short, paved, wheelchair-accessible trail takes you to a point 3,214 feet above Yosemite Valley's Curry Village, allowing views of Yosemite's high country.

In 1903, President Theodore Roosevelt went on a three-day guided wilderness trip through Yosemite with John Muir that started at the Mariposa Grove, and included Sentinel Dome, Glacier Point, and Yosemite Valley. Muir seized this opportunity "to do some forest good in talking freely around the campfire," with the president. Buffalo Soldiers from the Ninth Cavalry Troop were there as presidential escorts, and were asked to clear the Four Mile Trail for the president's use, but Muir and Roosevelt had other plans and used that ploy to escape from their escorts! This story ended up as an article in the New York Times later that year.

Tips & Seasonal Information

The Glacier Point Road is open to vehicles from approximately late May through October or November. Vehicles longer than 30 feet and vehicles pulling trailers are not allowed past Sentinel Dome parking lot.

The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

From mid-December through March, cross-country skiers can experience the view from Glacier Point after skiing 10.5 miles (one-way), conditions permitting.

Accessibility

The Glacier Point overlook is wheelchair accessible via a 300-yard paved, switchback trail from the main parking lot. The restrooms, snack bar, and gift shop are all accessible. A bronze tactile relief model which idenitfies geologic features is located on the terrace below the gift shop. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
data.audioDescription:
Glacier Point offers views from an upper terrace and a lower terrace. The upper terrace shows the northern part of Yosemite Valley and beyond, while the lower terrace shows views to the east. Looking north from the upper terrace, the northern granite walls of Yosemite Valley are seen, including Yosemite Falls and Royal Arches. The Merced River snakes through the valley while patches of meadow show through the heavy forest. A metal wayside exhibit is mounted to the railing and is titled Glacier Point Upper Terrace, Yosemite National Park. Text to the bottom left of the panel reads: As glaciers retreated from the Valley, they left piles of rock and gravel debris (called moraines) in their path. Behind the moraines, the waters of the Merced River collected, creating ancient Lake Yosemite. The lake gradually filled with river-carried sediments leaving behind the flat Valley floor. Yosemite Guardian Galen Clark, and other residents, dynamited the moraine in 1890 to lower the water table. As the ground became less saturated, more trees grew and Valley meadows began to shrink.

Illustration: A panoramic view of a portion of Yosemite Valley and beyond shows, from left to right, iconic features found in the area. to the far left, a rock juts out over the valley and is labeled Overhanging Rock, 7,200 feet. To the right of that, on the other side of the valley is a multi-tiered waterfall labeled Yosemite Falls: drops 2,425 feet. Below the waterfall, on the valley floor, over a bunch of trees is a label that indicates where Yosemite Valley Lodge is located. A littler further to the right, still on the valley floor is Yosemite Village, then a little further, a label that indicates where The Ahwahnee is. Continuing to the right, above the valley walls are one peak and two domes. Mount Hoffman at 10,850 feet, North Dome at 7,542 feet, and Basket Dome at 7,612 feet. On the valley floor, Royal Arches is labeled on the valley walls, then Mirror lake is in a valley between North Dome and Half Dome. Finally, to the far right is Half Dome at 8,842 feet. Text to the far right of the panel reads: Ancient Yosemite Creek cascaded thousands of feet into a deep, V-shaped canyon carved by the Merced River. During the Ice Age, glaciers gouged out the canyon into an even steeper U-shape with vertical walls. Yosemite Creek was left hanging 2,600 feet above the valley floor. The creek now plummets over the precipice as Yosemite Falls. When the winter's snowmelt disappears, usually by later summer. Yosemite Falls dwindle and often dry up completely. Looking to the east from the lower terrace, the eastern granite walls of Yosemite Valley are seen, including Half Dome. The Merced River snakes through the valley and cars can be seen maneuvering through the developed areas of the valley, like the campgrounds and Half Dome Village. A metal wayside exhibit is mounted to the railing and is titled Glacier Point Lower Terrace, Yosemite National Park. Text to the bottom left of the panel reads: From this vantage point, you can see about one-quarter of Yosemite National Park. The pointed peaks in the distance were unglaciated. Although glaciers quarried rocks from their sides, they never rode over their tops (the peaks would be smooth and rounded if they had). At the height of the Ice Age, which spanned some two million years, ice filled Yosemite Valley and reached a height 700 feet above where you are standing. The shape of the valley below you is a result of the carving actions of those ancient ice fields. Illustration: A panoramic view of a portion of Yosemite Valley and beyond shows, from left to right, iconic features found in the area. to the far left, Mount Hoffman at 10,850 feet, North Dome at 7,542 feet, and Basket Dome at 7,612 feet are grouped near each other. Further to the right are Mt. Watkins at 8,500 feet, Tenaya Peak at 10,301 feet, and Echo Peaks at 11,040 feet. On the floor of Yosemite Valley are Mirror Lake, with Tenaya Canyon right above it. Finally, to the far right are Cloud's Rest at 9,926 feet and Half Dome at 8,842 feet.

data.title: Glacier Point Gift Shop and Snack Stand
data.listingDescription: Find souvenirs, snacks, and convenience items at the Glacier Point Gift Shop and Snack Stand on your visit to this stunning overlook. You will also find gifts, books, apparel, plus a selection of hiking essentials if you're planning a hike down to Yosemite Valley via the Four Mile Trail or the Panorama Trail. You can also enjoy a refreshing ice cream or a quick bite at the Snack Stand.

images.altText: Wooden and stone gift shop building
images.title: Glacier Point Gift Shop and Snack Stand
images.caption: Glacier Point Gift Shop and Snack Stand

data.bodyText:
Find souvenirs, snacks, apparel, and convenience items at the Glacier Point Gift Shop and Snack Stand on your visit to this stunning overlook.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open seasonally approximately May to October, depending on the opening of Glacier Point Road. See website for hours.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the Glacier Point parking area.
data.audioDescription: A large, nearly symmetrical, timber and stone building has vertical, wooden-plank siding, a large stone foundation, and stone siding that extends up the height of the building at each corner. The building has a low-pitched roof and a matching, smaller porch roof that extends outward and is held up by two large cobblestoned columns. Two sets of glass double-doors are beneath the porch, in the center of the front side of the building. Three windows are on both sides of the entrance. Four small windows are lined up above the porch roof. A cobblestoned smokestack is to the right of the roof ridge. A penny press machine is in front of the left porch column and picnic tables are located to the left of the entrance. A bench and a row of recycle bins are to the right of the entrance.

data.title: Glacier Point Ski Hut
data.listingDescription: View Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and the Yosemite High Country from one of the most gorgeous and breathtaking sites in the Sierra Nevada region, from the Glacier Point Ski Hut.A 10.5-mile cross-country ski trip from Badger Pass Ski Area, on groomed terrain, will bring you to this rustic accommodation. Experienced cross-country skiers can do the entire round-trip in 4 to 5 hours, however, many guests like to explore Glacier Point longer and stay at Glacier Point Ski Hut overni

images.altText: Ski track in the snow lead toward a wooden building with stone accents. Tall pine trees rise behind the building and a snow covered mountainous landscape, featuring Half Dome, can be seen to the right.
images.caption: Photo by Yosemite Hospitality

data.bodyText:
View Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and the Yosemite High Country from one of the most breathtaking sites in the Sierra Nevada region, from the Glacier Point Ski Hut.

A 10.5-mile cross-country ski trip from Badger Pass Ski Area, on groomed terrain, will bring you to this rustic accommodation. Experienced cross-country skiers can do the entire round-trip in 4 to 5 hours, however, many guests like to explore Glacier Point longer and stay at Glacier Point Ski Hut overnight. Children must be at least 14 years old and accompanied by an adult to stay at Glacier Point Ski Hut. Reservations are required, and the Hut is only open in the winter.

Inside the Glacier Point Ski Hut, you'll find a charming dining room and rustic accommodations that include:

Comfortable Sofas
Woodstove
Restrooms
Large bunk bed area that sleeps up to 20 people in a single room.

Equipment rentals are available. See website for more information.


Hours:
Closed until further notice.

Getting Here:
Begin at Badger Pass, located along the Glacier Point Road, about 8 miles east of the Chinquapin intersection and the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations:
To dispose of human waste, dig through snow and six inches into soil.
Pack out all garbage, including toilet paper.
Skiers and snowshoers should make and maintain separate tracks.

Hazards & Warnings:
Short days mean that you might not be able to travel as far as expected.
Let someone know where you are going.
Keep track of all members of your party.
Watch for hypothermia - slow movements, peculiar behavior, unintelligible speech.
Stay on trails.
Get weather forecast and be prepared for the unexpected.
Carry proper food and gear for unexpected bivouac.
Carry and drink plenty of water - If you are thirsty, you are already dehydrated.
If someone needs help send someone to ski to Yosemite Ski and Snowboard Area or to Glacier Point Ski Hut (two skiers best).
Call 911. If possible, leave someone with the person in trouble.
data.audioDescription: A large, nearly symmetrical, timber and stone building has vertical, wooden-plank siding, a large stone foundation, and stone siding that extends up the height of the building at each corner. The building has a low-pitched roof and a matching, smaller porch roof that extends outward and is held up by two large cobblestoned columns. Two sets of glass double-doors are beneath the porch, in the center of the front side of the building. Three windows are on both sides of the entrance. Four small windows are lined up above the porch roof. A cobblestoned smokestack is to the right of the roof ridge. As you first walk in, a cobblestoned fireplace is opposite the entrance. Sofas surround a coffee table in front of the fireplace. A large open space to the right holds enough bunk beds to sleep up to 20 people.

data.title: Glen Aulin and Soda Springs Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Hike through meadow and forest on this scenic trail that leads you to Glen Aulin and beyond. Soda Springs Soda Springs-carbonated, cold water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure. A side path leads to the nearby historic Parsons Memorial Lodge, which offers exhibits in the summer. (limited hours-see Yosemite Guide for schedule). Glen Aulin Follow the Tuolumne River as it drops to Glen Aulin. Tuolumne Fall and White Cascade are four miles from the

images.altText: A river cascades over a series of short drops on bare granite
images.title: Tuolumne River on trail to Glen Aulin
images.caption: Tuolumne River on the trail to Glen Aulin

data.bodyText:
Soda Springs

This easy hike features expansive views of Tuolumne Meadows as you walk to Soda Springs, a natural source of cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground. The spring is protected within a historic log enclosure. Parsons Memorial Lodge can also be reached via a short walk beyond Soda Springs. The lodge, which features historic exhibits and interpretive programs, may be open during limited hours in summer.

Distance:  1 mile (1.6 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: minimal
Time estimate: 30 minutes

Glen Aulin

This long day hike follows the Tuolumne River through meadow systems and forest as it drops to Glen Aulin. Tuolumne Fall and White Cascade are four miles from the trailhead. Several more waterfalls can be seen along the trail for hikers going past Glen Aulin. Return to the trailhead along the same route.

Distance: 11 miles (17.7 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 800 ft (244 m) on return
Time estimate: 6-8 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available near Parsons Memorial Lodge. For hikers going to Glen Aulin, a flush toilet may be seasonally available at the High Sierra Camp.

The trail to Glen Aulin includes several unbridged stream crossings. Early in the season, when water can be very high, cold, and swift, use caution when crossing streams or turn back when crossing is not safe.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

The first quarter mile of the dirt trail is flat, with small paved sections, however, this trail is not considered wheelchair accessible. Some of the trail is a wide gravel path while other sections are narrow, rocky, and uneven.
data.audioDescription:
To the north of Tioga Road, a sandy trail leads into the vast expanse of the open Tuolumne Meadows. At the trailhead, a metal sign reads Soda Springs - 0.5 miles, Glen Aulin - 5.2 miles, and Waterwheel Falls - 8.7 miles. Two smaller signs are bolted to the metal post below the latter sign. The top sign shows an icon of a bicyclist inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it. The lower sign shows an icon of a dog inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it.

The sandy path is lined with several tall trees. As you get further into the middle of the meadow, an unobstructed view of the granite peaks and domes that surround the area start to show. Small signs on little wooden stakes are driven into the ground. The signs read, give plants a chance! Please stay off! The sign has an illustration of a hiking boot, hovering over four little plants, as if its ready to step on them, inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it.

data.title: Grizzly Giant Tour - A Famous Camping Trip
data.listingDescription: A Famous Camping TripLearn about John Muir and President Theodore Roosevelt's famous camping trip that initiated America's best idea, the birth of our National Parks. At their meeting, Muir spoke of environmental degradation, like development, and asked for another layer of protection as a national park to improve management. Muir convinced both Roosevelt and California Governor George Pardee, on that excursion, to recede the state grant and make the Valley and the Mariposa G

images.altText: Large, tree-sized branches extend from a wide giant sequoia tree trunk. Some of the branches curve upward.

data.bodyText:
A Famous Camping Trip
Learn about John Muir and President Theodore Roosevelt's famous camping trip that initiated America's best idea, the birth of our National Parks.

At their meeting, Muir spoke of environmental degradation, like development, and asked for another layer of protection as a national park to improve management. Muir convinced both Roosevelt and California Governor George Pardee, on that excursion, to recede the state grant and make the Valley and the Mariposa Grove part of Yosemite National Park. This joining together of the 1864 state grant lands with the 1890 national park lands occurred during Roosevelt's presidency in 1906.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the third stop of four on the Grizzly Giant Tour. A wood railing circles around most of the Grizzly Giant. The soft, spongy, textures of the reddish-brown sequoia trunk is noticable. Black burn scars surround the tree. The path splits. A path leads left, down to a tree with a hole cut through it's base, and a path leads right, going deeper into the grove. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Famous Camping Trip, and is next to the path. Panel text reads, taken in 1903 and featuring John Muir and President Theodore Roosevelt under the Grizzly Giant, this photograph captures a remarkable moment in time for the preservation of public lands. Perhaps while sitting around a campfire at this very spot, Muir convinced Roosevelt of the need to further protect this grove and the larger Yosemite area under federal jurisdiction. During his administration, President Roosevelt signed into existence 228 federally-managed parks, monuments, and preserves.

Black and white photo:(Center, John Muir with long beard) Nine men stand at the base of a giant sequoia, some leaning on it. They're all wearing hats and boots and period clothing. One man in the middle, President Roosevelt, has circular spectacles, a mustache, and a handkerchief around his neck. His left hand is placed in the left pocket of his open coat, while the other hand rests at his side. His long pants are tucked into his knee-high boots. The man to his left, John Muir, has a long mustache and beard, a vest underneath a suit coat, and trousers, all seeming to be the same gray-colored material. His hands are clasped behind his back.

Quote: The first night we camped in a grove of giant sequoias. It was clear weather, and we lay in the open, the enormous cinnamon-colored trunks rising about us like the columns of a vaster and more beautiful cathedral than was ever conceived by any human architect. -President Roosevelt

data.title: Grizzly Giant Tour - Enduring Giant
data.listingDescription: Enduring Giant The Grizzly Giant is one of the largest trees in the Mariposa Grove and is estimated to be 2,900 years old. As you near its base, look at the fires scars that remain. Fire plays a very important role in the growth of a giant sequoia.Giant sequoias have a dependency on natural fires for reproduction, which was not understood until the early 1960s. Lightning-caused fires reduce the competition from other evergreens, burn away the leaf litter on the forest floor,

images.altText: A man walks on a dirt path toward a large sequoia tree.

data.bodyText:
Enduring Giant
The Grizzly Giant is one of the largest trees in the Mariposa Grove and is estimated to be 2,900 years old. As you near its base, look at the fires scars that remain. Fire plays a very important role in the growth of a giant sequoia.

Giant sequoias have a dependency on natural fires for reproduction, which was not understood until the early 1960s. Lightning-caused fires reduce the competition from other evergreens, burn away the leaf litter on the forest floor, and leave a thin layer of nutrient-rich ash over the mineral soil, creating perfect conditions for seedlings to sprout. Look at the forest floor around you. Can you see the soil? Or, do you see leaf litter covering the soil?

Also, the heat from a fire dries some of the mature trees' green sequoia cones, causing a shower of fresh seeds to fall onto a perfectly-prepared seedbed. When winter comes, snow blankets the Mariposa Grove. As the snowpack melts the following spring, sunlight, moisture, fresh seeds, ash, and mineral soil combine to create a sequoia nursery.

To reduce the leaf litter and promote giant sequoia reproduction, the National Park Service began igniting "prescribed burns," that are deliberately set and closely monitored by rangers, during spring and fall. When the forest returns to a more natural state, these management fires will most likely be discontinued. Then nature can resume its cycle of lightning-caused fires every five to twenty years. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the first stop of four on the Grizzly Giant Tour. A cement path lined with boulders and wood railings leads directly to a large sequoia tree that is noticably larger in girth than all the surrounding trees. A black, charred, triangular burn scar concaves into the trunk of the tree at its base. Thick, tree-sized branches spread out from the trunk, some turning upward. A wayside exhibit titled, Enduring Giant, is next to the path. Panel text reads, the Grizzly Giant is one of the Mariposa Grove's most notable trees. Standing 209 feet (63.7 m) tall, it is 28 feet (8.5 m) in diameter and 96 feet (29 m) in circumference at its base.

Notice the blackened fire scars around the tree's base. Fires have burned here once every five to twenty years on average.

The Grizzly Giant, like other older sequoia trees and those damaged by lightning or fire, has a snag top due to loss of sapwood and a reduced ability to move water from roots to crown.

Look about halfway up for a large branch bending skyward. At nearly seven feet (2 m) in diameter, it is larger than the trunks of most of the trees around you.

Illustration: A mature giant sequoia with a full crown, thick branches, and wide base is the central figure in this side-by-side camparison graphic. To the sequoias right is a pine tree that's a tad shorter, has a slender trunk, and thin, wispy, branches. To the sequioas left is the statue of liberty, pedastal included, whose torch raises just a tiny bit above the height of the sequoia. At the base of the sequioa, about one-twentieth its size, is a shuttle bus with a group of people standing outside of it, making them look miniature in scale.

Caption: A giant sequoia is shown here in relation to the Statue of Liberty, people standing next to a shuttle bus, and a mature ponderosa pine.

data.title: Grizzly Giant Tour - The Surviving Tunnel Tree
data.listingDescription:
The Surviving Tunnel Tree
The California Tunnel Tree was cut in 1895 to allow horsedrawn stages to pass through. Most visitors don't know that two trees in this grove were tunneled, and this is the only one still standing, and still alive! Stroll through this living tree while thinking about its history. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about this and another tunnel tree.

images.altText: People stand inside a tunnel that has been cut out of the base of a large giant sequoia tree.

data.bodyText:
The Surviving Tunnel Tree
The California Tunnel Tree was cut in 1895 to allow horsedrawn stages to pass through. Most visitors don't know that two trees in this grove were tunneled, and this is the only one still standing, and still alive! Stroll through this living tree while thinking about its history. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about this and another tunnel tree.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourth stop of four on the Grizzly Giant Tour. The accessible path leads from the Grizzly Giant, down a hill to a large sequioa tree that has a tunnel carved out of its base. The wayside exhibit is titled, The Surviving Tunnel Tree, is next to the path. Panel text reads, walk through this living tree and look for evidence of it healing itself. Bark of this sequoia is growing inward in an attempte to close over its wound - the large tunnel carved in 1895. Thought to have served as a lower elevation winter replacement for the more famous Wawona Tunnel Tree, this tree became the second tunneled in this grove.

The Wawona Tunnel Tree fell in 1969 after serving as a portal to the past for over 75 years. Although weakened, the California Tunnel Tree survives today and offers us a glimpse into early tourism promotion and transporation. Both trees were helpful in publicizing the Mariposa Grove and promoting its inclusion into Yosemite National Park in 1906.

Black and white photo: A black, open-top, classic car is parked below a deeply furrowed giant sequoia trunk that has a hole in it. A sign above the entrance to the tree tunneled tree reads, California. A park ranger stands near the steering wheel, outside the vehicle, while a passenger sits in the back seat.

Caption: Park ranger and passenger driving a government vehicle through the California Tunnel Tree c. 1920s. Notice the tree's name nailed to the tree above the tunnel.

An informational map of the sequioa grove is also situated along the path, near the tunnel tree. The map is framed in large timber logs with log posts. The map reads Mariposa Grove. The key indicates light blue dotted lines are accessible trails, and thin, black, dotted lines are secondary trails. Icons for shuttle bus stops, restrooms, accessible parking, general parking, and mature giant sequoias are listed. Near the bottom left corner of the map is the Grove Arrival Area. Icons for restrooms, hiking, parking, and a shuttle stop are in the area. Major trails start here, all indicated by green, brown, light blue, and orange thick and thin, dotted lines. Small bunches of mature giant sequioa icons are in the area, which are individual bush-like circles, like looking down on a broccoli floret. The most concentrated bunch of mature giant sequoia icons are at the top of the map by a Mariposa Grove Cabin. Horse trails and restroom are located throughout the grove. Iconic trees are listed, a few examples being Fallen Monarch, Bachelor and Three Graces, Grizzly Giant, California Tunnel Tree, Faithful Couple, Clothespin Tree, Telescope Tree, and Fallen Wawona Tunnel Tree. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

data.title: Grizzly Giant Tour - The World Below
data.listingDescription:
The World Below
Tread lightly. Stepping off the trail, even for a quick photograph, may prevent water from reaching the trees' roots. Learn more about the microscopic life that exists beneath your feet, at this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: People stand next to a wood railing to get pictures taken with a large giant sequoia behind them.

data.bodyText:
The World Below
Tread lightly. Stepping off the trail, even for a quick photograph, may prevent water from reaching the trees' roots. Learn more about the microscopic life that exists beneath your feet, at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the second stop of four on the Grizzly Giant Tour. This wayside is facing the opposite directiong from the Grizzly Giant, toward an open area that is covered in dried pine needles and pine cones. The wayside exhibit is titled, The World Below, and is next to the path. Panel text reads, although these towering trees draw our gaze upward, the true source of their strength comes from below. Giant sequoias rely on wide, shallow root systems to maintain balance and absorb water and nutrients from the soil.

Hidden beneath your feet is a dynamic world of microscopic life. Tiny organisms recycle organic matter and create underground air pockets, making space for water from snowmelt or wetlands to nourish the trees.

Illustration: A small mouse digs a passageway into the the soil, similar to other bugs, worms, and centipedes. A root grows horizontally, near the grounds surface. A magnifying glass magnifies a section, showing smaller insects and organisms. A foot steps on a section of the ground, crushing down into the soil near the root, collapsing what air pockets and insects were there.

Caption: Stepping off trail, even for a quick photograph, compacts the loose, open soil and prevents water from reaching the trees' roots. As you approach the Grizzly Giant, look for markers that show the outer limit of the root system, which can extend 200 feet (61 m)
from the tree.

data.title: Grizzly Giant Trailhead (Accessible)
data.listingDescription:
This tour begins at the Grizzly Giant Accessible Parking area. Winding through a forest with many giant sequoias, this trail features the Grizzly Giant, the largest sequoia tree in the park, the California Tunnel Tree, and interpretive panels on the life and ecology of giant sequoias. This trail is relatively flat and is wheelchair accessible.


Grizzly Giant/California Tunnel Tree (easy)
0.26 mile (0.42 km) round-trip; 30-45 minutes


Hours :
From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Getting Here :
Located near Yosemite National Park's South Entrance. Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and take the free shuttle to the Mariposa Grove, when operating. Private vehicles may only enter the Mariposa Grove when the road is open and the shuttle is not operating. Only vehicles displaying a disability placard are permitted to drive into the Grove at any time.

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time. Feeding or approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to keep your food within arm's reach at all times, or store properly.
- Overnight camping is allowed in the Mariposa Grove from December 1 through April 15, if the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to cars. A wilderness permit is required to camp. Camping is only allowed above the Clothespin Tree.
- In the winter, water is only available at the welcome plaza and pit toilets are available in the Mariposa Grove at the arrival area, near the Grizzly Giant, and near the Mariposa Grove Cabin.

Accessibility :
Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or Grizzly Giant Accessible Parking, where designated accessible parking spaces are available.

images.altText: People walk on a dirt path to a distinct tree that is much larger than surrounding trees.

This trail is relatively flat and is wheelchair accessible.

Only vehicles displaying a disability placard are permitted to drive into the Grove at any time.

data.audioDescription: The Grizzly Giant accessible trailhead is located at the northwest end of a large accessible parking lot. A paved path leads to the right. A map, three green recycle bins, three brown trash bins, a split log used as a bench, and a small, brown, wood structure that houses vault toilets, line the paved walkway on the north side of the lot. At the trailhead, a wooden sign reads, Grizzly Giant 0.1 mile. The trail begins on a dirt road then continues on a paved, accessible trail to the left of the road. The path clears an opening in the forest and leads directyl to a large giant sequoia that is noticeably larger than all the surround trees, off in the distance. The trail is lined with boulders, a simple wood fence, and a few wayside exhibits.

data.title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
data.listingDescription: The Happy Isles Art and Nature Center is a family-oriented space designed for nature and art lovers of all ages. The center is open April through October and offers natural history exhibits, interactive displays, and art workshops with professional artists. Nearby, short trails focus on the area's four different environments: forest, river, talus, and fen. You can also see substantial evidence of the huge 1996 rockfall from the Glacier Point cliff far above the nature center.

images.altText: A single story building with a steeply pitched roof and river rock exterior walls
images.title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
images.caption: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center

data.bodyText:
The Happy Isles Art and Nature Center is a family-oriented space for nature and art lovers of all ages. The center offers natural history exhibits, interactive displays, and art workshops. Nearby, short trails focus on the area's four different environments: forest, river, talus, and fen. This building is located a short distance from shuttle stop 16. There is no parking in the immediate area.

Short workshops for kids are offered free of charge June through September as staffing allows. Paid, daily art classes using a variety of media are available for teens and adults. Learn more and register for teen/adult classes on the Yosemite Conservancy website or by calling 209/379-2646.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open seasonally April through October from 9 am to 4 pm daily.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. The center contains tactile exhibits on Yosemite's natural history. Limited designated accessible parking spaces are available nearby. Vehicles must display a disability placard to drive on Happy Isles Loop Road to reach this parking.
data.audioDescription: From shuttle stop 16, a paved side path, lined with several types of trees and bushes, leads past the restrooms, to the Happy Isles Art and Nature Center. Along the way, another paved path intersects and leads to the isles in the river to the left and toward the Fen to the right. As you approach the stone and timber building, the American flag waves on a tall flagpole to the right side of the path, and a wooden sign on the left reads, Happy Isles Nature Center, explore the world of nature. The building has stone siding and a steeply angled wooden roof.

passportStampImages.altText: A green circular stamp contains text that reads Yosemite National Park, Happy Isles Nature Center.
passportStampImages.title: Happy Isles Nature Center Passport Stamp

data.title: Harden Lake Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Admire the views as you hike through a pine forest and pass by small granite domes before reaching boulder-dotted Harden Lake. Hike along a gravel road-part of the original Tioga Road-that follows the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River for part of the route. At a trail junction 1.75 miles (2.8 km) down the road, follow the signs to the lake. Harden Lake (Moderate)5.8 miles (9.3 km) round trip; 2-4 hours,355-foot (122-m) elevation gain on thereturn trip. Hours :Accessible on

images.altText: A forested lake dotted surrounded by grasses, downed trees, and boulders
images.title: Harden Lake
images.caption: Harden Lake

data.bodyText:
Hike to a quiet forested lake beginning from the White Wolf area. The hike begins along a gravel road that follows the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River. This road was part of the former Tioga Road before it was reconstructed. At the trail junction 1.75 miles (2.8 km) down the road, follow the signs to the lake.

Distance: 5.8 miles (9.3 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 390 ft (120 m) on return
Time estimate: 2-4 hours

Route variation: continue past the lake and descend steeply to the edge of the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne River. To return, follow signs for Lukens Lake and White Wolf to complete this loop hike. This loop is much more challenging and adds 1,000 ft (300 m) of elevation gain.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails.

If the road to White Wolf is closed, add about two additional miles, round-trip, to this hike.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The trailhead to Harden Lake begins across the street from the White Wolf Lodge front office building. There is a row of parking spaces that are lined with tall pine trees. The trail begins near the center of the parking row and enters into the forest. Two trailhead signs are posted. The first sign is brown with white text and shows the mileage of several hiking destinations that begin at this trailhead. The sign reads, Lukens Lake - 2.3, Harden Lake - 5.7, Ten Lakes - 9.7, Pate Valley - 10.4, Smith Meadows - 11.1, Yosemite Valley - 13.9, Hetch Hetchy - 17.0. The other sign is also brown with white text and lists wilderness regulations. The sign reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

data.title: Hetch Hetchy Entrance
data.listingDescription: Hidden in Yosemite National Park's peaceful northwest corner, Hetch Hetchy Valley is a treasure worth visiting in all seasons. Located at 3,900 feet, Hetch Hetchy boasts one of the longest hiking seasons in the park and is an ideal place for thundering spring waterfalls and wildflower displays. The Hetch Hetchy Road is open from 8 am - 5 pm.

images.altText: Small wooden building with American flag on pole
images.title: Hetch Hetchy Entrance
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Entrance

data.bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Hidden in Yosemite National Park’s peaceful northwest corner, Hetch Hetchy Valley is a treasure worth visiting in all seasons.

Visitors can pay the park entrance fee, show their parks pass, or purchase a pass as they enter the park. Park brochures may be available. Entrance stations at Yosemite do not accept cash. Learn more about entrance fees and passes. 

Vehicles and/or trailers over 25 feet long and 8 feet wide are not permitted on the narrow, winding Hetch Hetchy Road.

Operating Hours and Seasons

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open only during daylight hours, from sunrise to sunset. There is no access to Hetch Hetchy trailheads when the road is closed.

Delays at the entrace station are possible if the parking lot fills (typically, mid-day on weekends).

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Check road status or call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
data.audioDescription: One inbound lane and one outbound lane are on each side of a small wooden kiosk that has a cobblestone base at the Hetch Hetchy Entrance. The National Park Service logo is placed above the windows on the kiosk. The logo consists of a downward pointing arrowhead, a sequoia tree, a mountain range, a lake, a bison, and text that reads National Park Service. A flag pole waving the American Flag is located in front of the kiosk. A small knee-height triangular sign reads U.S. Fee Area and has the National Park Service logo. Another sign, posted on the front side of the kiosk reads Hetch Hetchy Entrance, Elevation 4,750 feet. A white dry erase board on the side of the kiosk shows the local weather forecast. The kiosk is heavily shaded with the number of trees surrounding it.

data.title: Hetch Hetchy Reservoir - O'Shaughnessy Dam
data.listingDescription: Stand on the O'Shaughnessy Dam and ask yourself, where does my drinking water come from? This reservoir currently supplies drinking water to 2.7 million San Francisco Bay Area residents.After parking your vehicle, take a short walk onto the O'Shaughnessy Dam to get views of the reservoir and two waterfalls, Tueeulala Fall and Wapama Fall, in the distance.

images.altText: A concrete dam in front of a large body of water and granite cliffs above
images.title: O'Shaughnessy Dam
images.caption: O'Shaughnessy Dam with Hetch Hetchy Reservoir

data.bodyText:
From the parking area, take a short walk to the O'Shaughnessy Dam to get views of the reservoir and two waterfalls, Tueeulala Fall and Wapama Fall.

The O'Shaughnessy Dam, named for the chief engineer, was completed in 1938. Today, this 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies pristine drinking water to 2.7 million Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.

Tips & Hours

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open from sunrise to sunset only.

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

Pets are prohibited on all trails and on the dam. Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The viewpoint on O'Shaugnessy Dam is paved and wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription:
The Hetch Hetchy Reservoir is accessible by way of a one-way loop road. Just beyond the O'Shaughnessy Dam, the road starts to go up hill, at which point, multiple roadside parking spots are available on the right side of the road. Cars are able to pull directly into the diagonal spaces, right off of the main road. A knee-high stone barrier and a cement curb, line the parking area. A few tall trees grow on the opposite side of the stone barrier. Beyond the stone barrier is a deep valley, which the waters of the dam empty into. A narrow stream makes its way through the V-shaped valley. Near the top of the hill where the parking area is located, across the street, are a few picnic tables. A wayside exhibit inside a log frame stands nearby and reads, Recreation tips:

Bring plenty of water when hiking. Summer months can be very hot.
Bears are active in the area. You can help keep Yosemite's bears wild and alive by storing all food in a bear-proof storage canister available at park entrance stations. Speeding cars are a common cause of bear and other wildlife casualties, so please drive safely at all times.
Enjoy the area but leave no trace behind. Pack out what you pack in. Stay on the trails to avoid erosion and to protect the landscape and water quality.
Fishing is allowed from the bank of the reservoir, but please use artificial bait and obtain a valid fishing license before entering the park.
Overnight backpacking requires a Yosemite National Park wilderness permit, available at the entrances. Day hiking requires no permit.
Please exercise caution when hiking near the Tuolumne River or around waterfalls. These areas can be very slippery, and the force of the water can be dangerous, especially during high flows between late spring and early summer.

Photo: Two people with large backpacks are on a trail, facing away from the camera, looking down a deep valley that has a river running through it.

Caption: Leave no trace outdoor ethics
Plan ahead and prepare
Travel and camp on durable surfaces
Dispose of waster properly
Leave what you find
Minimize campfire impacts
Respect wildlife
Be considerate of other visitors.
Please learn, practice, and pass on Leave No Traces outdoor skills and ethics. Following these principles will help protect precious backcountry resources. For more information on Leave No Trace, call (800) 332-4100 or visit www.lnt.org.

Photo: A Native American woman with a long dress has a baby in a cradle basket on her back. She faces away from the camera. She is in a meadow with a tall waterfall in the background.

Caption: Suzie and Sadie McGowan (Mono Lake Paiute), Yosemite Valley, 1901.

Panel text reads, American Indians of the Yosemite region were the original stewards of this area, living sustainably from the ecosystem's plants and animals for many years before the first Euro-American visitors arrived. The very name "Hetch Hetchy" is derived from Indian words for grasses and seeds common to this area. Please respect these extraordinary lands, as portions are considered sacred by the tribes and are protected under federal law.

Photo: Two wildflowers are shown. One wildflower is deep red and is sprouting from a crack in a rock. It is labeled stonecrop. The other flower is pink and yellow and has multiple blossoms on one stem. It is labeled Harlequin Lupine.

Panel text reads, the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir, while providing water to millions of people, also provides access to spectacular beauty and some of the most pristine wilderness in California. Some of the most colorful and exotic plant species in North America can be viewed in the Hetch Hetchy watershed. More than 1,000 species of wildflowers can be found in the park including Heuchera, California poppy, lupine, wallflower, shooting stars, waterfall buttercups, bright California fuschia, brodiaea, dwarf monkey flower, clarkia, and Sierra leisiga.

In the center of the exhibit panel is a glass case that contains a poster that reads, each year, 200 people finish their hike like this...
A photo is shown of 8 people carrying a person in a stretcher, down stone steps.
Text continues to read, don't let it be you.
Stay on the trail! Traveling off trail is a leading cause of hiking accident in Yosemite.
Ask about trail conditions before you go.
Stay away from swift moving streams and rivers.
Carry 2-3 liters of water and stay hydrated.
Bring high energy foods.
Wear sturdy shoes that protect your ankles.
Rest often.
Bring a headlamp or flashlight in case you are delayed.
Hike smart, and have a safe day!

Looking down the hill from the small picnic area, past the parking area, allows for a great view of the blue waters of the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and the O'Shaughnessy Dam, which you can walk on.

data.title: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two popular hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.

images.altText: Wooden trailhead sign with mileages on it
images.title: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead

data.bodyText:
Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two day hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite.

Lookout Point

The Lookout Point trail is a two-mile hike with moderate elevation change. The trail leads to a rocky outcropping overlooking Hetch Hetchy.

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 680 ft (207 m)
Time estimate: 1 hour

Smith Peak

The Smith Peak (7,751 feet) trail takes you through forest and meadow to the highest point in the area and offers outstanding views of the Hetch Hetchy area. The Smith Peak trails can be used to access the Yosemite high country. Permits are required for all overnight hikes. Visit a wilderness center for more information.

Distance: 13.5 miles (21.6 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 3,700 ft (1128 m)
Time estimate: 6 to 8 hours

Route variation: Smith Peak can also be accessed via a trail at the Hetch Hetchy entrance station. This route is 16 miles round-trip.

Tips & Hours

Watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak in this area.

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open from sunrise to sunset only. Hetch Hetchy trailheads are not reachable by vehicle when the road is closed.

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

Pets are prohibited on all hiking trails. Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead is located on the right side of the road, across the street from the Hetch Hetchy Entrance Station. It is marked by a wooden sign that reads, Lookout Point - 1.0 miles, Cottonwood Meadows - 3.2 miles, Smith Meadows - 6.4 miles, Hetch Hetchy - 7.3 miles, Harden Lake - 11.7 miles, Pate Valley - 17.7 miles, Yosemite Valley - 20.9 miles. Another small sign is located on the wooden post, beneath the wooden sign. The metal sign is bright yellow and reads, Warning, burned watershed. Risks include rockfall, falling trees, washed out trails, and trees blocking trails.

data.title: Homestead Cabin
data.listingDescription: Much of the high country around Yosemite Valley had been claimed by individuals in the late 1800s. The Hodgdon family, ranchers from the San Joaquin Valley, built this cabin on their homesteaded land in Aspen Valley and grazed cattle there each summer.

images.altText: Two story wooden cabin with covered porch
images.title: Homestead Cabin
images.caption: Homestead Cabin

data.bodyText:
Much of the high country around Yosemite Valley had been claimed by individuals in the late 1800s. Thomas “Tom” Hodgdon acquired land for grazing cattle in Aspen Valley, now within Yosemite National Park. In 1879, Tom hired workers to build an access road, and a two-story cabin, on the land. To build the two-story log cabin, he hired a Chinese American cowboy named Ah Hoy and a neighbor named Franklin Babcock. The Hodgdon family, ranchers from the San Joaquin Valley, grazed cattled on their homesteaded land in Aspen Valley each summer.

Tom and family ran a ranching business, grazing cattle in nearby meadows. After these meadows became part of Yosemite National Park in 1890, U.S. Army troops enforced park regulations against grazing by dispersing cattle, and the Hodgdons lost grazing privileges. The family didn’t use the cabin for a while, and patrolling soldiers, and even Army horses, sheltered inside occasionally.

No longer able to earn a living with livestock in Yosemite, the Hodgdon family adapted to make money from tourism. In 1882, as part of the Great Sierra Wagon Road, the Hodgdons’ access road was improved upon by Chinese workers, and extended to Tioga Pass for silver mining. When the Tioga Road opened to the public, tourist traffic increased through Aspen Valley. The Hodgdon family used their cabin, and created a complex of new buildings, used for tourist lodging. Eliza Hodgdon, Tom’s spouse, added to the entrepreneurial effort by selling hot meals to hungry travelers.
data.audioDescription: From the walking trail, this two-story log cabin is approached from the side. There is a stairway leading up to a door on the second floor. In the front, the roof extends out beyond the house, creating a covered porch. There is a door in the middle with a vertical rectangle window on each side. A long wooden bench sits below each window.

data.title: Housekeeping Camp
data.listingDescription: Perfect for those who love camping outdoors but don't want the hassle of setting up a tent, Housekeeping Camp is a Yosemite favorite.

images.altText: A few of the housekeeping structures among trees
images.title: Housekeeping Camp
images.caption: Housekeeping Camp

data.bodyText:
Perched alongside the Merced River in the center of Yosemite Valley, Housekeeping Camp features three-sided concrete structures with canvas roofs, privacy curtains, and a covered patio. When water levels are low, sandy beaches along the river can be reached with a short walk from camp.

At Housekeeping Camp you'll find a camp store, laundry room, and shower house. Guests can rent sheets, blankets, pillows, chairs, cribs, cots and stoves for their stay at Housekeeping Camp. View a map of the property.

See website for more information and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open seasonally from approximately mid-April to early October, conditions permitting. For season dates see website. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

Amenities

Laundry. Washers and dryers available for a small fee. You do not need to be a guest at Housekeeping Camp to use the laundry facility.

Camp Store. Selection of convenience items and supplies.

Showers. The shower house is for guests only. Public showers are available at Curry Village for a small fee.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for amenity hours.

Food Storage Requirements

Guests staying overnight at Housekeeping Camp must follow these rules:

  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.
  • Keep your locker closed and latched at all times, just like you would a freezer.
  • Only have the food out that you are actually using; if you're not using it, put it back into the food locker.
  • Treat your trash and recycling like food: keep it in your food locker or dispose of it in a bear-proof dumpster; do not leave it sitting out.
  • During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed).
  • Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time. Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark.
  • When you check out, empty your food locker.
  • Failure to store your food properly may result in impoundment of your food or car and/or a fine of up to $5,000 and/or removal from your campsite or lodging facility.

Housekeeping Camp units come with two differently sized bear lockers measuring: 33 inches deep x 45 inches wide x 18 inches tall and 17 inches deep x 49 inches wide x 17 inches tall.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select lodging units within Housekeeping Camp are wheelchair accessible, with a nearby accessible restroom. Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The laundry, shower, and grocery store facilities are all wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription: Housekeeping Camp is a lodging area that offers a camp-like experience. It is located along the Merced River and has 266 lodging units scattered across the property. There is also a front office, store, laundry facility, and shower facility on site, near the entrance of the property. One unit includes a three-sided concrete structure that has a canvas roof and curtains for privacy. Each unit contains a cement floor, an electrical outlet, a light, bunk beds, shelves, and a mirror. A cement patio extends off the front of the unit and contains a circular picnic table and a light. An additional canvas roof covers two back-to-back units and their patio areas. A wooden fence surrounds a portion of each patio for privacy. Two small food lockers are stacked on top of two larger ones, both situated on the side of the back-to-back units. Communal restrooms are randomly placed throughout the property.

data.title: Indian Village
data.listingDescription: Go back in time and walk through a re-constructed Indian village to learn more about structures the native people lived in and the plants they used for survival. The reconstructed Indian Village of Ahwahnee offers outdoor displays about the culture and lives of the Ahwahneechee inhabitants of Yosemite Valley. Follow this trail through a re-constructed Yosemite Indian village of the 1870s. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants.

images.altText: Reconstructed bark houses within the Indian Village
images.title: Indian Village of Ahwahnee
images.caption: Reconstructed bark houses in the Indian Village

data.bodyText:
Walk through a reconstructed Indian Village offering outdoor displays about the culture and lives of the Ahwahneechee inhabitants of Yosemite Valley. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants used by native people.

This reconstruction is located on the former site of the largest Indian village in Yosemite Valley. The bark houses, ceremonial roundhouse, sweathouse, pounding rocks, cabin, acorn granaries, and chief's house are representative of the structures found in a Sierra Nevada Miwok village during the late nineteenth century. Today the village is still actively used by members of the local American Indian community for ceremonies and special gatherings.

Seasonal Information

Open year-round, 24 hours a day.

Accessibility

A short, partially paved loop trail winding through the Indian Village has displays that incorporate audio buttons. The village's central area is level but unpaved.
data.audioDescription: Behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, a path leads into the Indian Village. A sign is at the apex of the trail, that extends to the left and the right. The sign reads Welcome, heeyeko in Southern Miwok. An arrow points to the right and the sign reads self-guiding trail through the Indian Village of Ahwahnee. An illustrated map shows the layout of the Indian Village. A green circular path with counter clockwise arrows shows the direction to go. A red dot indicates You are here. A series of multi-sized brown circles indicate, from right to left, Acorn graneries, a ceremonial roundhouse, and a sweathouse, all on the outer side of the trail. In the center of the loop trail is the Chief's house, a cabin, indicated by a brown square, and a cluster of bark houses, otherwise known as umachas. A stream runs through the center of the loop trail, right next to the umachas, cabin, and Chief's house. Three-quarters of the way around the loop trail from where the red dot indicates 'You are here,' is an arrow that points downward and reads 'To Museum.' The rest of the sign reads We invite you to follow this trail through a re-constructed Yosemite Indian village of the 1870s. The largest Miwok village in Yosemite Valley, the Village of Ahwahnee, was once in this area. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants used by Native people. A stack of booklets are held in a dispenser that reads booklets, 50 cents. There's a coin slot to the right of it.

data.title: Jail, Powder House, and Morgue
data.listingDescription: As auto-touring increased, the newly-formed National Park Service recognized that roads needed improvement. Road-building in this region was not easy. Granite rock was blasted away to form roadbeds. Powderhouses were used to store blasting powder. In 1933, access to Yosemite Valley from Wawona was improved with the completion of the Wawona Tunnel. The tunnel's power lines, its carbon monoxide sensors, and its high-speed fans made it an engineering feat. Workers used 275 tons

images.altText: An old cot can be seen through the open door of a small stone structure with a pointed roof.

data.bodyText: As auto-touring increased, the newly-formed National Park Service recognized that roads needed improvement. Road-building in this region was not easy. Granite rock was blasted away to form roadbeds. Powderhouses were used to store blasting powder. In 1933, access to Yosemite Valley from Wawona was improved with the completion of the Wawona Tunnel. The tunnel's power lines, its carbon monoxide sensors, and its high-speed fans made it an engineering feat. Workers used 275 tons of blasting powder and spent nearly two years drilling the tunnel at a rate of roughly 20 feet per day.
data.audioDescription: This small, one-room stone structure has a wooden, pyramid style roof. There is only one wooden door, no windows. Inside, there is a very low ceiling and a lone steel-framed cot with exposed springs. An exhibit sign reads: Powder House - Jail: The black powder and dynamite used in the routine State work in Yosemite Valley were kept in the "Tool House" before John Degnan built this stone magazine in the 1890s. In addition to thick stone walls, the powder house also had six inches of sand in the ceiling as protection from fire. Later, the powder house was converted into a jail, a very poor one. In 1915, two young car thieves escaped by digging away the mortar between the rocks with a leg they had twisted off the rickety steel frame cot. The pair claimed the task was so easy that they waited until after breakfast to perform their escape. Patrol rangers recaptured them, and shackled them by leg irons to the corners. Following this incident, horseshoes were imbedded in the floor to provide a chain or base of greater security. Occasionally, the powder house-jail also served as a morgue.

data.title: Lembert Dome and Dog Lake Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Beginning from Dog Lake parking, the trail climbs through the forest to Dog Lake, then take a spur to the summit of Lembert Dome. There is no marked trail on the bare rock on Lembert Dome; choose the easiest path to the summit for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

images.altText: Bare rock in the foreground with snowy peaks and partly cloudy skies towering behind
images.title: Lembert Dome
images.caption: The summit of Lembert Dome in late fall looking toward the Cathedral Range

data.bodyText:
Beginning from the north end of Dog Lake parking, the trail climbs through the forest to Dog Lake, then take a spur to the summit of Lembert Dome.
