There is no marked trail on the bare rock on Lembert Dome; choose the easiest path to the summit for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

Lembert Dome is an example of a roche moutonnée, a glacial landform with an asymmetrical shape. The steep western face and gradual eastern slope indicate the direction of glacial flow when glaciers filled Tuolumne Meadows.

Dog Lake is a quiet, forested lake that is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies.

Distance: 3.8 miles (6.1 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 850 ft (260 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 3-4 hours

Route variation: return via Lembert Dome Parking for a 5-mile loop. Or, hike this route as an out-and-back beginning from Lembert Dome Parking instead of Dog Lake Parking, a slightly longer route to the same destinations.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay off domes during thunderstorms!

Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake or any other hiking trails.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: A slightly crescent shaped, paved parking area is near the Lembert Dome/Dog Lake trailhead. Just east of the parking lot, beyond a stand of tall pines, is a granite dome, Lembert Dome. The dome is shaped like a slide, the left side being a steep incline, while the right side has a long gradual decline. At the north end of the parking lot are two dumpsters, a brown one for trash, and a green one for recycling, each having a carabiner to clip their chutes shut. Near the dumpsters is a thin metal post with two signs. The top sign reads, no camping or overnight parking. The second sign reads, no parking any time, and has a two sided arrow pointing left and right. Not far to the right of the dumpsters are the vault toilets, which are two grey structures located on a wooden deck, accessible by steps or a ramp. Next to the restroom is a dirt path that leads into the forest. A wooden sign reads Lembert Dome, Dog Lake Trailhead. Two icons are located within two separate square outlines, and each have a red diagonal line slashing down it's center. The first icon is of a dog and the second icon is of a bicycle. To the right of the trailhead is a large, green tone, exhibit panel, inside a log frame, with log posts.Panel text reads, welcome to Lembert Dome parking. The dome above you was sculpted by glaciers, which have filled Tuolumne Meadows many times over millions of years. If you stood here thousands of years ago during a glacial period, you would be buried under 2,000 feet of ice! This trailhead accesses hikes to Lembert Dome, Dog Lake, Soda Springs, Glen Aulin, and Young Lakes. The upper half of the panel is a trail map of the area. Beginning at where the red dot indicates, you are here, in the middle of the map, yellow lines, representing trails, sprawl out from this point. To the upper left, the trails lead toward Soda Springs and Glen Aulin. To the upper right, the trail splits off to the right to Lembert Dome, before continuing to Dog Lake and Young Lakes. An icon for Parking, picnic area, and restrooms are next to the red dot. Blue indicates the water of Dog Lake and the Tuolumne River, and white represents Tioga Road, which runs left to right, with thinner white lines indicating smaller backroads. For more information about Yosemite maps, please call 209/379-1035The left column of panel text reads, take a hike! The trail to Lembert Dome or Dog Lake begins on your left (west) and passes in front of the bathrooms. Pay attention to signs, posted at every trail junction. Remember, this is the Lembert Dome Parking Area. Lembert Dome is moderately strenuous. The trail climbs 850 feet (259 km) through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks. Dog Lake is moderately strenuous. Surrounded by forest, this quiet lake is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies. Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake, nor on any other trails. The Loop is moderately strenuous. It is possible to combine the Lembert Dome and Dog Lake hikes into a five-mile loop. Study the map for details. Do not walk on the road from the Dog Lake parking area back to this parking area. Instead, use the trails indicated on the map. Soda Springs is easy. Follow the gravel Soda Springs Road on your left. When you reach the gate, continue straight for about a half mile to the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge. This easy, mostly flat walk opens up to views of the Tuolumne River, Tuolumne Meadows, and the surrounding peaks. Carbonated water bubbles out of the ground at Soda Springs. The Parsons Memorial Lodge has been a reading room, shelter, and place for lively discussion since it was built in 1915. The right column of panel text reads, before you go. Stay on trail. Careless steps damage this fragile landscape. Plants have a short growing season before winter snow blankets the land. Be prepared. Carry plenty of water and high energy food. Bring a map; don't rely on cell phones and GPS. Pack a flashlight in case your hike takes longer than expected. Wear appropriate clothes and shoes. Tell someone where you're going and when you plan to return. Pack out what you pack in. To help this wilderness thrive, leave no trace of your presence. You must pack out your used toilet paper and trash. Never feed wild animals. Human food is unhealthy for wildlife and encourages aggressive behavior. Respect animals at a distance. If an animal changes its behavior due to your presence, you are too close. Pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed only on roads accessible by vehicle, never on trails. Pets must be on a leash at all times, and owners must bag and dispose of pet waste. Weather can change quickly in the mountains. Be aware of building thunderstorms. Stay off of exposed granite domes, open meadows, and lakes when storms are approaching. Get there safely. Roads in the park are narrow and winding. Protect p

data.title: Lower Pines Campground Restroom Architecture

images.altText: A small single story building with a low angled roof with overhanging eaves
images.title: Lower Pines Campground Restroom
images.caption: Lower Pines Campground Restroom

data.bodyText:
During Mission 66, the park undertook significant efforts to improve visitor infrastructure, including modernizing campgrounds and building many additional restrooms.

While simple, these restrooms possess a small number of character-defining features. The low-angled roof and framed rectangular windows are unique to the many restrooms built in Yosemite during this era.

This is an active camping area. Do not enter any campsites or disturb the campers
data.audioDescription: The Lower Pines campground restroom is a small, single-story building made of concrete blocks painted brown. The roof has a low angle with overhanging eaves painted in a contrasting light brown. All around the upper edge of the building just below the roof line, single-pane rectangular windows surround the building. Wood fencing, also painted brown, shelters doors to the men’s and women’s restrooms, which are located on opposite sides of the building. The building has a small sign with the label “409.”

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Picnic beneath this awe-inspiring landmark, North America's tallest waterfall, Yosemite Falls. Picnic tables are conveniently located at this scenic spot that displays a remarkable view of Yosemite Falls. Drinking water and flush toilets are available. This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk.

images.altText: Wooden picnic tables, restroom building and waterfall in background
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Picnic Area
images.caption: Lower Yosemite Fall Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
Picnic tables are available beneath views of Yosemite Falls. Drinking water and flush toilets are available. The Lower Yosemite Fall loop trail is located directly next to this picnic site.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round from dawn to dusk.

Bicycles are permitted in this picnic area but are prohibited on the loop trail. A bicycle rack is located next to the picnic area.

Yosemite Falls is a seasonal waterfall fed mostly by snowmelt. By late summer, the waterfall is usually dry. Flow is typically strongest in spring.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area is fully paved, flat, and located next to wheelchair accessible restrooms, including a designated family restroom. There are no designated accessible parking spaces nearby. The Lower Yosemite Fall Shuttle Stop is located approximately 1000 ft (300 m) away via a paved, flat, accessible path.
data.audioDescription: The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area is located along Northside Drive, and along the walking path between the visitor center and the Yosemite Valley Lodge. The narrow walking path that cuts through the forest and leads to the base of Lower Yosemite Fall, allows for a view of the Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls from the picnic area. About seven randomly placed wooden picnic tables are available. Facing Yosemite Falls is due North. Short wooden fence posts and rails line the west side of the level, dirt, picnic area. Trash and recycle bins are located to the south, bike racks to the east and drinking fountains and a restroom are at the northeast corner.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Early Tourism & James Hutchings
data.listingDescription:
Early Tourism
After leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.

images.altText: Two wayside exhibits at the edge of a paved path with a wooden tree trunk bench in between them
images.title: Early Tourism & James Hutchings
images.caption: Early Tourism & James Hutchings

data.bodyText:
Early Tourism
After leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.
James Hutchings
After bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.
data.audioDescription:
Two wayside exhibits stand near the start of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. There is a bench between the two of them. On the wayside exhibit to the left, or north, on the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of Yosemite Falls. The caption reads, Thomas Ayres' drawing of Yosemite Falls, 1855.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Early Tourism, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of the Lower Yosemite Fall. Panel text reads, after leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.

Under a heading that reads, Inspiring a Nation, panel text reads, Artist Thomas Ayres, who accompanied Hutchings on his first trip to Yosemite, drew some of the first sketches of the Valley. Hutchings later published this work in his magazine, giving the nation its first glimpse of Yosemite's spectacular beauty. Ayres was the first of many artists inspired by the wonder and awe of Yosemite Falls.

Black and white photo 1: Eight people, four men and four women, sit on horses that are standing in an open meadow, with Yosemite Falls as their backdrop.

Black and white photo 2: A horse-drawn, covered wagon is parked in an open meadow with Yosemite Falls as the backdrop. One man is sitting in the driver's seat, while another man leans on the large, wooden, back driver's side wheel. â€˜Yosemite or Bust,' is painted on the wagon canopy.

Black and white photo 3: A group photo of six people posing in front of a four-team, horse-drawn wagon, with Yosemite Falls as the backdrop, fills the frame. Two men propped up on their elbow, lay on their side and face the camera. Two women in long dresses sit on luggage while one man props his right elbow on the front driver's side wheel. Another man stands with his arms behind his back.

Caption for the three photos: Since the days of these early tourists, millions of visitors - just like you - have captured their Yosemite experience in images of Yosemite Falls.
On the right, a wayside exhibit stands near the start of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of and older man with a long beard wearing a suit and bow tie. The caption reads, Writer Helen Hunt Jackson called James Hutchings "an enthusiast, a dreamer, a visionary...all this is plainly to be seen in his mobile, artistic face, and in the affectionate ring of every word that he speaks of the Valley."

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, James Hutchings, and has a faint, sepia-toned photograph of a basic two-story building with seven windows spaced out on the second floor, and five windows and three doors on the first floor. The caption reads, "upstairs, the rooms [at Hutchings House] were only divided by pieces of cotton cloth and were very small at that...Fanny J's soap slipped from her fingers when washing and flew into the parlor." - A New England guest, June 1864.

Panel text reads, after bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.

Under a heading that reads, Pioneer and Entrepreneur, panel text reads, James Hutchings built a family cabin directly in view of Yosemite Falls. It was located adjacent to the apple orchard he planted across the way, which still bears fruit after 150 years. Here, his family raised produce and livestock to feed the hotel guests. Where you are standing now, a smokehouse once cured meat.

Black and white photo: An older man with a white beard sits in a chair. A young boy is to the left of him and a woman, with a hat and long dress, stands, resting her right arm on the back of the chair. They are on a lawn in front of a wooden house with a high pitched roof.

Caption: James Hutchings (center) is pictured here with his son Willie and daughter Gertrude "Cosie" Hutchings, in front of their cabin, c. 1890s.

Black and white photo: A granite tombstone has the following words chiseled out of it: James Mason Hutchings, February 10, 1818, October 31, 1902, Father of Yosemite. Builder of the first trails, road, bridges, and dwellings of the Valley.

Caption: En route to the Valley in 1902, Hutchings was killed in a carriage accident. You can visit the family burial site in the Pioneer Cemetery in Yosemite Village.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - John Muir Woodcutter
data.listingDescription: In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young woodcutter named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.

images.altText: A wooden path with a wood railing circles around a large granite boulder.

data.bodyText: In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young woodcutter named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.
data.audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands in the curve of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of a man sitting on a rock, his legs crossed, his right hand holding onto a walking stick while his left arm rests on top of the walking stick. He has a long beard and wears a hat. The caption reads, Muir was instrumental in getting his beloved Yosemite and several other national parks established. In 1892 he became the founding president of the Sierra Club.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, John Muir...The Woodcutter, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of a young man with hair combed back, a long beard, and mustache. Panel text reads, In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young wilderness explorer named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.

Quote: "As long as I live, I'll hear waterfalls and birds and winds sing. I'll interpret the rocks, learn the language of flood, storm, and the avalanche. I'll acquaint myself with the glaciers and wild gardens, and get as near the heart of the world as I can." - John Muir

Under a heading that reads, Remains of the Millrace, panel text reads, this 1940 photograph shows the channel that was dug to divert water from Yosemite Creek, possibly to power the sawmill or irrigate Hutchings' apple trees. Directly below, you can see what may be the remains of this millrace.

Black and white photo: Four men stand in a flat, open area in a forest. One man in a black suit and hat is writing in a book. Another man holds a long, rolled-up, piece of paper while looking down at the ground. Another man, dressed in a National Park Service uniform, looks down at the ground, too. Another man, in the far background, looks toward the other men.

Black and white photo: A shabby wooden structure has water running beneath it.

Caption: In the shadow of Yosemite Falls, Muir lived in a "hang nest," a boxy retreat he attached to the sawmill.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Many Faces of Yosemite Falls
data.listingDescription:
James Hutchings
After bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile quarter panel
images.title: Many Faces of Yosemite Falls
images.caption: Many Faces of Yosemite Falls

data.bodyText:
Many Faces of Yosemite Falls
The ancient channel of Yosemite Creek once cascaded down the ravine to the left of Upper Yosemite Fall. About 130,000 years ago, a retreating glacier deposited ridges of geologic debris--known as a moraine--that blocked the channel. The creek was then diverted to its present route. Today, you can hike along that ancient creek's path. The 3.6-mile Upper Yosemite Fall Trail traverses the ravine. It rises 2,700 feet in elevation, and leads to the top of Yosemite Falls.
data.audioDescription: A wayside exhibit stands along a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel showing the ancient path of Yosemite Creek via a raised dotted line. Next to the tactile model, there is a monotone image illustrating the path of Yosemite Creek today with a solid line and a dotted line showing the ancient path of Yosemite Creek. The caption reads: "The dotted line shows where the ancient channel of Yosemite Creek once flowed. It branched off the current path of the creek and cascaded down the ravine to the left of Yosemite Falls." The remaining right side of the panel is titled "Many Faces of Yosemite Falls" and has a faint, sepia-toned photograph showing the full height of Yosemite Falls viewed from a distance. Under a heading that reads "Follow an Ancient Path", panel text reads: The ancient channel of Yosemite Creek once cascaded down the ravine to the left of Upper Yosemite Fall. About 130,000 years ago, a retreating glacier deposited ridges of geologic debris--known as a moraine--that blocked the channel. The creek was then diverted to its present route. Today, you can hike along that ancient creek's path. The 3.6-mile Upper Yosemite Fall Trail traverses the ravine. It rises 2,700 feet in elevation, and leads to the top of Yosemite Falls. On the far right side of the panel, the panel text reads: In spring when the water peaks, the torrential creek launches over the edge and the Falls thunder down the cliff face. As the snowpack dwindles, the waterfalls slow to a trickle and may appear dry by summer's end. During the winter, look for early-morning ice near the Upper Fall and an ice cone at its base.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Profile of a Waterfall
data.listingDescription: Do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? Learn more at this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief section stands next to a trail that leads toward a tall waterfall.

data.bodyText: Do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? Learn more at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
On a paved path lined with tall trees that leads toward Lower Yosemite Fall, a paved clearing on the right side of the trail holds a long log that has a one-quarter wedge cut out of it length-wise, letting it serve as a bench with a backing, and includes metal arm rests at the ends. A wayside exhibit stands nearby.

On the left one-quarter side of the wayside exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of the three tiers of Yosemite Falls. The caption reads, between Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls, the water tumbles through pools and rapids of the Middle Cascades before it careens down the Lower Fall. The water once again becomes Yosemite Creek as it meanders on its way to the Merced River.
The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Profile of a Waterfall, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of river water right before it goes over a waterfall. The caption reads, Yosemite Creek as it pours over the top of Upper Yosemite Fall. Panel text reads, do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? The Falls begin as snow in the granite reaches of Yosemite wilderness. When the snow melts each spring, Yosemite Creek transforms into a free-falling torrent. Watch the comets of spray. Hear the water roar. And from the Lower Fall Bridge, feel the shower of a lifetime!

Under a heading that reads, Seasonal Flow, four pictures of Yosemite Falls are shown.

Black and white comparison photo 1: Two waterfalls are stacked on top of each other. The upper fall is full of water and the lower fall has a slightly more narrow, shorter, stream of water.

Caption: Spring - The force and volume of melting snow reaches its peak.

Black and white comparison photo 2: Two waterfalls, stacked on top of each other, have dwindled down to a thin, hair-like strand of water.

Caption: Summer - As the snowpack in the high country recedes, the flow of water starts to diminish.

Black and white comparison photo 3: The Upper Yosemite Fall is more like a wet rock wall. No steady stream of water is seen, just darkened wet spot on the rock wall.

Caption: Autumn - When the water dries up, the lichen-stained cliff face traces the course of the waterfalls.

Black and white comparison photo 4: A thin stream of water falls over a large granite rock wall. White ice has built up on the rock face on both sides of the thin waterfall. The trees surrounding the lower half of the rock wall are all snow covered.

Caption: Winter - The meager spray dribbles over the cliff and freezes. Listen for ice crashing in the morning.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Shaping Yosemite Valley
data.listingDescription:
Shaping Yosemite Valley
Like giant bulldozers, ice-age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls-like Yosemite Falls.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief section stands along a path. A tall waterfall can be seen above the treeline.

data.bodyText:
Shaping Yosemite Valley
Like giant bulldozers, ice-age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls-like Yosemite Falls.
data.audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands in a clearing on the right side of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of a finger-like spire outcrop from off the side of a cliff face. The caption reads, to the right of Upper Yosemite Fall, you can see a finger of granite known as the Lost Arrow. Its name comes from a story about a deer hunter who was in the high country celebrating his conquests. From the cliffs above the Valley, he shot a victory arrow into the air. When the wayward point dropped to the ground, it turned to stone.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Shaping Yosemite Valley, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of a big pile of boulders. Panel text reads, like giant bulldozers, Ice-Age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls - like Yosemite Falls.

Black and white photo: The terrain above Yosemite Falls is covered with snow. Yosemite Falls is full of water as it plummets over the granite precipice.

Under a heading that reads, And the Rocks Come Down, panel text reads, all is peaceful and calm now. But imagine what it was like long ago when the boulders to your left tumbled and crashed to the Valley floor. Rockfalls are as central to shaping the face of Yosemite Valley as fire or flood. Long before recorded history, these boulders, known as talus, fell as a result of weathering and erosion. For eons, this ongoing natural process has worked upon Valley walls. When water in cracks repeatedly freezes and thaws, rocks break free. Likewise, lichens, moss, and plant roots can grow in the cracks, helping to pry fragments loose. Be aware that rockfalls can happen at any time.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Tactile Model
data.listingDescription:
Bronze Tactile Model of Yosemite Falls
Feel the trees, trails, rock formations, cliff faces, and Yosemite Falls, on this bronze tactile model of the Yosemite Falls area.

images.altText: A bronze tactile relief model sits on a granite rock pedestal along a paved trail leading toward a tall waterfall.

data.bodyText:
Bronze Tactile Model of Yosemite Falls
Feel the trees, trails, rock formations, cliff faces, and Yosemite Falls, on this bronze tactile model of the Yosemite Falls area.
data.audioDescription: On a paved path lined with tall trees leading to Lower Yosemite Fall, a clearing on the right side of the trail holds a bronze tactile model of Yosemite Falls. A mosaic of stonework covers the flat clearing in the path, and the bronze 2 foot by 2 foot model sits on a waist-high granite cube. The model mimics the terrain on which the Yosemite Falls is found, which includes the high cliff walls, its textures, and its trails. Small bumps found all over the model represent trees. A trail to the left of Yosemite Falls, represented by raised tick marks, has a series of switchbacks leading up about one-third of the rock face before it flattens out to the right for another one-third of the trail, then starts ascending to the immediate left of Upper Yosemite Fall for the remainder of the trail to the top of Yosemite Falls. At the top of the rock face, the trail disperses out to the left, straight, and to the right. Raised, flat lines indicate the trails and roads on the valley floor. Slightly concaved lines, with squiggly textured lines within, indicate waterways in Yosemite Valley. The model reads, Yosemite Falls Area, and has a line of tick marks labeled 0.25 miles.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Witness the strength of this mighty waterfall by site, sound, and the feel of its mist, when you stand at its base in spring and early summer when the waterfall peaks in volume. The falls are often only a trickle or completely dry by August.

images.altText: Visitors viewing Yosemite Falls from the trailhead with a full waterfall in the background.
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.caption: View of Yosemite Falls from the Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead

data.bodyText:
This short, easy walk rewards visitors with spectacular views of both Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. This paved loop trail offers different vantage points of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Creek. Numerous exhibits along the trail discuss the natural and cultural history of the area. Begin the loop from either the western or eastern end, following signs directing you toward the base of the waterfall. The loop may be walked in either direction.

Lower Yosemite Fall is the final 320-foot (98-meter) drop of Yosemite Falls. In spring and early summer when the waterfall peaks in volume, you can expect to get sprayed with water when standing on the footbridge near its base. The falls are often only a trickle or completely dry by late summer, then are sometimes revived again by late fall storms.

Distance: 1 mile (1.6 km) loop
Elevation gain: 50 feet (15 m)
Time estimate: 30 minutes

Caution: stay on the paved trail. Above the wooden footbridge that crosses Yosemite Creek, the rocks and boulders are slippery even when dry. Venturing off-trail in this area frequently leads to serious injuries.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Leashed pets are permitted on this trail. Bicycles are prohibited on the Lower Yosemite Fall loop trail. Several bicycle racks are located at the east and west end of the Lower Yosemite Fall loop. A restroom along with a water bottle filling station is located near the trailhead, on the western end of the loop across the street from Yosemite Valley Lodge.

While you can visit this trail and viewing area year-round, there is often no water in the waterfall by late summer. 

In winter, a cone of ice accumulates at the base of Upper Yosemite Fall, sometimes exceeding 300 feet tall. The ice cone is usually melted by mid-April. In early spring, frazil ice sometimes forms in waterfalls and creeks when waterfall mist becomes very cool.

When waterfall flow is especially high, generally in April and May, the full moon refracting light on the waterfall mist can create a phenomenon called a moonbow. The visibility of the moonbow is highly dependent on water flow, clear skies, and angle of the moon.

Accessibility

There is no designated accessible parking nearby. Visitors may use the shuttle stop to reach the trail or travel along the paved path from the accessible parking at the west end of Yosemite Village (approximately 0.3 mile to the eastern side of the loop trail).

The entire Lower Yosemite Fall loop trail is paved. The eastern part of the loop (0.6 mile one-way from the Yosemite Falls shuttle stop to the viewing area) is accessible to wheelchairs and crosses several braided streams before reaching the Lower Yosemite Fall viewing area, which has transferable seating to granite boulders at wheelchair height.

The western part of the loop (0.5 mile one-way to the viewing area) is wide enough for several people and is mostly accessible; however, a short, steep grade near the viewing area (the last 180 feet include a slope of 13.8%) may make assistance necessary for some visitors.

Along the western portion of the loop, about halfway to the falls, a bronze relief model depicts the Yosemite Falls area. Wayside exhibits along the trail also feature bronze relief panels.

An accessible restroom is located near the trailhead, on the western end of the loop across the street from Yosemite Valley Lodge. The restroom facility has a designated family restroom that is also accessible.
data.audioDescription: A paved walking path cuts through the forest and leads to the base of Lower Yosemite Fall. At the trailhead, the forged path allows for full views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area is nearby and has about seven randomly placed wooden picnic tables, trash and recycle bins, bike racks, a drinking fountain, and a restroom.

data.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Viewing Area
data.listingDescription: Yosemite Falls is made of the upper fall, middle cascades, and lower fall, all dropping a total of 2,425 ft. (740 m), and is one of the tallest waterfalls in the United States. Yosemite Creek, which flows over this waterfall, is fed entirely by snow melt. At its peak in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second can flow over the lip of the upper fall. Yosemite Falls usually runs dry by late summer.

images.altText: A tall waterfall flows strongly over a cliff and into boulders
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.caption: Lower Yosemite Fall

data.bodyText:
Yosemite Falls is made of the upper fall, middle cascades, and lower fall, all dropping a total of 2,425 ft. (740 m), and is one of the tallest waterfalls in North America. Take in a view of Lower Yosemite Fall from this iconic viewing area. In spring, when flow is strongest, expect mist and wind at this viewing area as the powerful waterfall cascades down the cliffs in front of you.

From this viewpoint at the base of the waterfall, the upper fall and middle cascades of Yosemite Falls are not visible. To get a view of the full height of the waterfall, walk the nearby Cook's Meadow loop or walk to the viewpoint on the west side of the Lower Yosemite Fall loop.

Caution: stay on the paved trail. Above the wooden footbridge that crosses Yosemite Creek, the rocks and boulders are slippery even when dry. Venturing off-trail in this area frequently leads to serious injuries.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Leashed pets are permitted on this trail. Bicycles are prohibited on the Lower Yosemite Fall loop trail, including this viewing area. Numerous bicycle racks are located at the two trailheads (east and west side of the Lower Yosemite Fall loop).

Yosemite Creek, the source of this waterfall, is fed entirely by snow melt. At its peak in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second can flow over the lip of the upper fall. While you can visit this trail and viewing area year-round, there is often no water in the waterfall by late summer. 

In winter, a cone of ice accumulates at the base of Upper Yosemite Fall, sometimes exceeding 300 feet tall. The ice cone is usually melted by mid-April. In early spring, frazil ice sometimes forms in waterfalls and creeks when waterfall mist becomes very cool.

When waterfall flow is especially high, generally in April and May, the full moon refracting light on the waterfall mist can create a phenomenon called a moonbow. The visibility of the moonbow is highly dependent on water flow, clear skies, and angle of the moon.

Accessibility

The entire Lower Yosemite Fall loop trail is paved. The eastern part of the loop (0.6 mile one-way from the Yosemite Falls shuttle stop to the viewing area) is accessible to wheelchairs and crosses several braided streams before reaching the Lower Yosemite Fall viewing area, which has transferable seating to granite boulders at wheelchair height.

The western part of the loop (0.5 mile one-way to the viewing area) is wide enough for several people and is mostly accessible; however, a short, steep grade near the viewing area (the last 180 feet include a slope of 13.8%) may make assistance necessary for some visitors.

An accessible restroom is located near the trailhead, on the western end of the loop across the street from Yosemite Valley Lodge. The restroom facility has a designated family restroom that is also accessible.
data.audioDescription: Upon approaching the Lower Yosemite Fall, the paved trail opens up to a viewing area. The open space is lined with mosaic stonework on the ground and large boulders. A fallen log also rests at the waterfall end of the viewing area. In the spring, the mist from the waterfall pelts everyone standing by, drenching them in seconds. Dependent on the season, the river either quietly or thunderously flows under a wood bridge nearby. Large rocks and boulders line the riverbed. Vibrant green trees surround the area.

data.title: Lukens Lake Trailhead from Tioga Road
data.listingDescription: Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer. This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Please stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy.

images.altText: A meadow blanketed in grasses and pink wildflowers surrounded by trees
images.title: Lukens Lake
images.caption: Meadow of wildflowers at Lukens Lake

data.bodyText:
This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy. The trail is typically wet and muddy until early August.

Distance: 1.6 miles (2.6 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 200 ft (60 m)
Time estimate: 1-2 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay on trail, even when muddy! Go through mud puddles rather than around them to preserve plant life in this sensitive ecosystem.

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available at the trailhead.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Lukens Lake Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has three green recycle bins, three brown trash bins, two brown food lockers, and one wayside exhibit titled, Upper Montane. The trailhead is across the street and marked by a brown sign with an icon of a hiker inside a white square outline.

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, this is snow country, where plants and wildlife must cope with a high-mountain climate that brings winter snow that can remain until June. Here, the summers are short, cool, and moist. Only specialized species can survive. The red fir is one such hardy tree that can handle snowloads that exceed 30 feet. This tree grows in pure stands in the upper montane zone.

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the bottom to top of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet).

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, The plants and animals of the habitat around you are uniquely connected. Interdependence is the only way to suvive within this extreme environment. One important interrelationship involves fungus, flying squirrels, and owls. Root fungi absorb food from trees, while simultaneously improving the roots' water and nutrient absorption. Truffle-like mushrooms growing from this fungus provide a food source for flying squirrels. In turn, owls prey upon the flying squirrel. In this circle of dependency, one missing link might threaten the survival of all.

Illustration: A tree above ground and its roots below ground are a part of the main focal point of this illustration. A squirrel digs into the soil and reaches an oval-shaped object that is growing on the tree's roots underground. An owl is hovering in the background.

data.title: Lukens Lake Trailhead from White Wolf
data.listingDescription: Enjoy this small mountain lake surround by a meadow full of shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers in the summer. Follow the trail through a mixed conifer forest to Lukens Lake. The trail crosses the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River and is wet and muddy until early August. Lukens Lake from White Wolf (Moderate)4.6 miles (7.4 km) round trip; 2-3 hours,400-foot (122-m) elevation gain. Hours :Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late

images.altText: A blue lake surrounded by conifer forest
images.title: Lukens Lake
images.caption: Lukens Lake

data.bodyText:
Walk through a mixed conifer forest to Lukens Lake, a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow full of shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers in the summer. The trail crosses the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River and is wet and muddy until early August.

Distance: 4.6 miles (7.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 400 ft (120 m)
Time estimate: 2-3 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay on trail, even when muddy! Go through mud puddles rather than around them to preserve plant life in this sensitive ecosystem.

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The trailhead to Lukens Lake begins across the street from the White Wolf Lodge front office building. There is a row of parking spaces that are lined with tall pine trees. The trail begins near the center of the parking row and enters into the forest. Two trailhead signs are posted. The first sign is brown with white text and shows the mileage of several hiking destinations that begin at this trailhead. The sign reads, Lukens Lake - 2.3, Harden Lake - 5.7, Ten Lakes - 9.7, Pate Valley - 10.4, Smith Meadows - 11.1, Yosemite Valley - 13.9, Hetch Hetchy - 17.0. The other sign is also brown with white text and lists wilderness regulations. The sign reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

data.title: Lyell Canyon Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Let the overwhelming views of Tuolumne Meadows' peaks and meadows compete for your attention as you venture into Lyell Canyon via the John Muir Trail. Begin across the road from Dog Lake parking area. This trail passes through Lyell Canyon, along the Lyell Fork of the Tuolumne River. Early in the season, the trail can be muddy in places. There are several creek crossings, including Rafferty Creek (bridged) and Ireland Creek (unbridged). Spectacular Kuna Creek cascades down th

images.altText: A trail carves through an open, grassy meadow with rolling mountain peaks
images.title: Lyell Canyon
images.caption: Lyell Canyon from the John Muir Trail in late summer

data.bodyText:
Hike along the Tuolumne River and through lodgepole pine forest, plus enjoy expansive views of meadows, Kuna Crest, and Mount Lyell. This trailhead is part of both the John Muir Trail and the Pacific Crest Trail. A sign reading "John Muir Trail" with various trail distances marks the trailhead south of the Dog Lake parking area.

A short distance from the trailhead, there is a bridged crossing over the Dana Fork of the Tuolumne River, then after another short distance, the trail reaches the Lyell Fork of the Tuolumne River. The two bridges at the Lyell Fork are known as Twin Bridges, a popular scenic destination.

This trailhead is used to reach many popular wilderness travel destinations, such as Donohue Pass, Vogelsang Pass, and many more. Permits are required for all overnight hikes. Visit a wilderness center for more information.

Twin Bridges via the John Muir Trail

Distance: 3 miles (4.8 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: mostly flat
Time estimate: 1-2 hours

Route variation: continue up the John Muir Trail along Lyell Canyon for a longer hike with gradual elevation gain. Turn around at any point and return the same way you came.

Tips & Seasonal Information

In early summer, the trail can be very muddy in places. Stay on trail and go through mud puddles rather than around them to preserve delicate plant life in this sensitive ecosystem.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
The John Muir Trail begins across the street from the Dog Lake Parking lot. Residential housing consisting of wooden cabins with canvas roofs, are located on the west side of the parking area. A large exhibit panel set inside a log frame, stands on log posts next to the Dog Lake trailhead. The panel text reads, welcome to Dog Lake Parking. This trailhead accesses the hike to Dog Lake, Lembert Dome, Young Lakes, and Lyell Canyon, among others. Hiking maps and guidebooks are available at the visitor center. For your safety, please follow trail signs and do not walk along the road.

The upper half of the panel is a trail map of the area. Beginning at where the red dot indicates, you are here, yellow lines, representing trails, sprawl out from this point. An icon for parking and accommodations are near to the red dot. A blue line indicates the water of the Tuolumne River and Dog Lake, and a thick white line represents Tioga Road, which runs left to right, with thinner white lines branching off Tioga Road, indicating smaller backroads. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at 209/379-1035.

The left column of panel text reads, take a hike! The hike to Dog Lake and/or Lembert Dome begins at the uphill (north) side of this parking lot. Pay attention to signs posted at every trail junction. Remember, this is the "Dog Lake" parking area.

Dog Lake (moderately strenuous) - Surrounded by forest, this quiet lake is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies. Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake, nor on any other trail.

Lembert Dome (moderately strenuous) - After Gaining 600 feet (183 m) of elevation, look for the trail junction to the summit of Lembert Dome. The trail climbs through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

The Loop (moderately strenuous) - It is possible to combine the Lembert Dome and Dog Lake hikes into a five-mile loop. Study the map for details. Do not walk on the road from the Lembert Dome parking area back to this parking area. Instead, use the trails indicated on the map.

Lyell Canyon (easy) - To hike up Lyell Canyon on the John Muir and Pacific Crest Trails, begin at the downhill (south) side of this parking lot. Cross the road at the crosswalk and follow the trail upstream. You can enjoy a short stroll along the river until you are ready to turn around. One mile up the trail you will reach Twin Bridges, a scenic crossing of the Lyell fork. If you're feeling more adventurous, this trail could take you to Mt. Whitney, over 200 miles (322 km) away, or all the way to Mexico.

The right column of panel text reads, before you go. Stay on trail. Careless steps damage this fragile landscape. Plants have a short growing season before winter snow blankets the land.

Be prepared. Carry plenty of water and high energy food. Bring a map; don't rely on cell phones and GPS. Pack a flashlight in case your hike takes longer than expected. Wear appropriate clothes and shoes. Tell someone where you're going and when you plan to return.

Pack out what you pack in. To help this wilderness thrive, leave no trace of your presence. You must pack out your used toilet paper and trash.

Never feed wild animals. Human food is unhealthy for wildlife and encourages aggressive behavior. Respect animals at a distance. If an animal changes its behavior due to your presence, you are too close.

Pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed only on roads accessible by vehicle, never on trails. Pets must be on a leash at all times, and owners must bag and dispose of pet waste.

Weather can change quickly in the mountains. Be aware of building thunderstorms. Stay off of exposed granite domes, open meadows, and lakes when storms are approaching.

Get there safely. Roads in the park are narrow and winding. Protect park wildlife, other visitors, and yourself by obeying posted speed limits and using turnouts.

Feeling the altitude? Give yourself a day or two to become accustomed to the altitude. Signs of altitude sickness can include nausea, dizziness, and headache. Descending to a lower elevation can help alleviate symptoms.

Wilderness use regulations. Wilderness permits and and allowed bear-resistant food containers are required year-round for overnight trips. They are available at the Yosemite Valley and Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Centers, Wawona Visitor Center, Big Oak Flat Information Station, and the Hetch Hetchy Entrance Station. No motorized vehicles are permitted.

In the middle of the left and right text columns is a small map outline of the entire park. The main roads and areas are the only things labeled. On the far left side of the park is a road that runs north to south. At the top point is Hetch Hetchy, coming down to Big Oak Flat, then down to Wawona, which is near the bottom tip of the park. A little less than half way up the road is an intersection the leads into the Yosemite Valley via a loop road. Just above Yosemite Valley is a road that extend from the left to the right of the park, the Tioga Road, With Tioga Pass labeled at the far right. To the far right of the Tioga Road, near Tioga Pass, is a red dot that indicates, you are here.

From north to south, the parking lot slopes downhill a bit. There is a neat line of recycle bins, trash bins, and food storage lockers in the south parking lot. A crosswalk leads across the street to the Lyell Canyon trailhead. A wooden sign reads, John Muir Trail, Tuolumne Pass 6.1 miles, Vogelsang H.S.C. 6.7 miles, Donohue Pass 11.9 miles, Merced Lake 14.7 miles, and Yosemite Valley 27.5 miles. A sign is posted prohibiting dogs on the trail.

data.title: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area and Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Explore and experience the wonder of being surrounded by some of the rarest and most remarkable living things on the planet in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias. Marvel at the towering giant sequoias in the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area, as you prepare to embark on your grand adventure into the grove. All trails begin here at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area.

images.altText: Wide flat accessible trail with place name sign and people walking on fence lined trail
images.title: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area

data.bodyText:
The Mariposa Grove home to hundreds of mature giant sequoias and is the largest sequoia grove in Yosemite National Park. All trails through the grove begin here at the arrival area. They range from a relatively flat stroll to half- or full-day hikes that require strenuous uphill hiking. Each has its own rewards. All trail distances are listed beginning and ending at the arrival area.

Route Information

Big Trees Loop Trail

Distance: 0.3 mile (0.5 km) loop
Elevation gain: flat pavement and boardwalk
Time estimate: 30 to 45 minutes

This trail features the Fallen Monarch and interpretive panels on the life and ecology of giant sequoias. This loop is relatively flat and is wheelchair accessible.

Grizzly Giant Loop Trail

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) loop
Elevation gain: 300 ft (90 m)
Time estimate: 1.5 to 2 hours

Start along the Mariposa Grove Trail at the Big Trees Loop and hike past notable trees such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Grizzly Giant, and California Tunnel Tree. Vehicles with a disability placard can drive as far as the Grizzly Giant accessible parking and enjoy this area of the grove via a section of trail that is wheelchair accessible.

Guardians Loop Trail

Distance: 6.5 miles (10.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,200 feet (366 m)
Time estimate: 4-6 hours

This trail follows a route that people have used to access the grove for generations. See famous sequoias such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Faithful Couple, and the Clothespin Tree along this hilly route to the upper reaches of the grove. After hiking to the tranquil upper portion of the grove, the return hike takes hikers past many famous features including the fallen Wawona Tunnel Tree, the Telescope Tree, and the Mariposa Grove Cabin.

Mariposa Grove Trail to Wawona Point

Distance: 7.75 miles (12.4 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,200 feet (360 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 4-6 hours

This trail follows a route that people have used to access the grove for generations. See famous sequoias such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Faithful Couple, and the Clothespin Tree along this somewhat strenuous route to the upper reaches of the grove. Continue to historic Wawona Point, an overlook with panoramic views. A number of alternative trails are used to access the upper portion of the grove. These trails are generally steeper and more rugged than the Mariposa Grove Trail.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Restrooms are available at:

  • Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and Parking
  • Mariposa Grove picnic area (off the Washburn Trail about one mile from the parking area) (vault toilet)
  • Mariposa Grove Trailhead and Arrival Area (flush toilets in summer/vault toilets in winter)
  • Near the Grizzly Giant (vault toilet)
  • Mariposa Grove cabin (flush toilet in summer/vault toilet in winter)

Drinking water is available at the arrival area in summer only. There is no drinking water in the grove.

There is no private vehicle access and no parking at the arrival area except for vehicles displaying disability placards. The Mariposa Grove shuttle typically operates from approximately early March through late November. From approximately late November to at least April 1, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to all vehicles. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers. See website for more information.

Pets are not allowed anywhere in the Mariposa Grove. Protect these ancient trees by staying behind boundary fencing and staying on established trails. Bicycles are allowed on the Mariposa Grove Road between the welcome plaza (near South Entrance) and the Grizzly Giant when the road is open for the season. Bicycles are not allowed elsewhere in the Mariposa Grove.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area; vehicles displaying disability placards can drive at 25mph and park in designated spaces.

The Mariposa Grove Arrival Area is wheelchair accessible, as well as the Big Trees Loop Trail, 0.3 mile (0.5 km). There is a bronze tactile exhibit at the arrival area. Use caution in hot weather as the tactile exhibit may be too hot to touch.

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive as far as the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area and enjoy a close up view of the Grizzly Giant and California Tunnel Tree via a section of trail that is wheelchair accessible, 0.13 mile (0.21 km).
data.audioDescription:
Approaching the Mariposa Grove Trailhead from either the parking area or the shuttle drop off area, the most noticeable feature is the fenced-in pathway that zigzags between towering giant sequoias as it makes its way deeper into the grove. On the right side of the path entranceway sits a row of trash and recycle bins and a split log that serves as a long bench. To the left of the entranceway are several interpretive panels, a drinking fountain, and a bronze, tactile relief model of the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias (Caution: The bronze, tactile relief model is often in direct sunlight and could be too hot to touch). Three interpretive panels are lined up against a waist high fence. The first panel is titled A Way of Life Continues and explains the origins of stewardship of the grove by local native tribes, the Bishop Paiute Tribe, Bridgeport Indian Colony, Mono Lake Kutzadika Tribe, North Fork Rancheria of Mono Indians of California, Picayune Rancheria of Chukchansi Indians, Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation, and Tuolumne Band of Me-Wuk Indians. There is a sepia toned picture of a group of people, with a caption that reads, some members of the Tribal Working Group, Yosemite Conservancy, and NPS staff. There is also an area titled Greetings from the Traditionally Associated Tribes of Yosemite National Park, that contains five different tribal translations. There is also a map that shows the ancestral homelands of the park's Traditionally Associated Tribes, which are marked by a red dot in areas surrounding Yosemite.

The second panel is titled Visiting the Mariposa Grove. There is a map showing all the trails in the Mariposa Grove, and a list containing hiking trail options that range from easy, to moderate, to strenuous. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. A call-out box titled Grove Etiquette reads, You are visiting a truly special place. Please take care to not damage this grove or impact the experience of other visitors. Please stay on designated trails and respect fenced areas. Be a steward of the grove - please no climbing or graffiti. Strive to leave no trace. No dogs, no collecting, no bikes. A third panel is titled A Legacy of Conservation and shows a sepia toned picture of Abraham Lincoln, as well as a picture of a National Park Service (NPS) uniform hat and belt, to show the significance of the sequoia cones featured on both the NPS uniform hat band and belt. Panel text reads, Welcome to the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias. This forest is legendary, and even sacred, to those who have experienced its majesty-from the seven Traditionally Associated Tribes of Yosemite, to important conservation leaders, and visitors who saw their first sequoia just yesterday. As you explore the grove, you'll be following in the footsteps of countless people who have revered and worked to protect these magnificent trees. This grove is also honored because it is one of our country's first protected public lands. The seeds of the national park movement were sown here when artists, writers, politicians, and early preservationists convinced the US Congress and President Abraham Lincoln to protect the giant sequoias from logging, tourism, and development in the mid-1800s. Every National Park Service ranger carries a reminder of the significance of these trees and the movement they inspired. Look closely at the NPS emblem, belt, and hatband pictured here with the sequoia cone and tree silhouette. A sign at the trailhead reads, Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.

data.title: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is a terrific place to enjoy your meal amongst nature! Whether it's before or after your visit to the Mariposa Grove, refuel your energy levels here, then continue seeing all that Yosemite National Park has to offer. The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is open at all times to vehicles displaying a disability placard and to those who are hiking the Washburn Trail.

images.altText: Picnic tables and restroom, grill, and garbage and recycling containers
images.title: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
Located along Mariposa Grove Road, the Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is open at all times to vehicles displaying a disability placard and to those who are hiking the Washburn Trail. Vehicles not displaying a disability placard may use the picnic area when shuttle buses are not operating.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round. From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area features wheelchair accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible. Surfaces within the picnic area are unpaved and flat.
data.audioDescription: As you face the picnic area, knee-height granite boulders separate the gravel parking area from the picnic area. To the far left of the parking lot, a path leads into the picnic area. Trash and recycle bins and a vault toilet are on the left side of the path. To the right of the path are three picnic tables, in close proximity to each other. Each table has an extended top and each have their own grill. Trees and shrubs surround the dirt area.

data.title: Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 1: Arrival Area and Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and board the free shuttle bus to get a glimpse of these giants. The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free shuttle service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite's South Entrance, and the Mariposa Grove from early March through late November. This is the primary way to get to the Mariposa Grove. From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates.

images.altText: Bus at covered bus shelter in Mariposa Grove
images.title: Mariposa Grove - Shuttle Stop #1
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area - Shuttle Stop #1

data.bodyText:
The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza & Parking (stop 2) and the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area & Trailhead (stop 1). Shuttles arrive approximately every 15 minutes.

The Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is the park's largest stand of giant sequoias, with about 500 mature sequoias in the grove. Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and board the free shuttle bus to get a glimpse of these giants.

Dates are subject to change according to weather and road conditions, which may vary from year to year. In any given year, shuttle service will begin no earlier than April 15 (possibly later), and will close on or before November 30 (depending on conditions).

Shuttle hours vary throughout the season, with longer hours in summer. See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for current operating hours and season dates.

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.
data.audioDescription: The Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 1 has a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath. The Bus stop sign reads "1, Mariposa Grove Trailhead, Grove Shuttle, Shuttle Route," and shows a basic map of the shuttle route as well as the schedule, which both change with the seasons. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. The shuttle stop area is surrounded by giant sequoias and is near a restroom and water filling station.

data.title: Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 2: Welcome Plaza and Parking
data.listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free shuttle service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite's South Entrance, and the Mariposa Grove from early March through late November. This is the primary way to get to the Mariposa Grove. From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates.

images.altText: Shuttle bus near stop with map displayed nearby
images.title: Mariposa Grove - Shuttle Stop #2
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza - Shuttle Stop #2

data.bodyText:
The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza & Parking (stop 2) and the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area & Trailhead (stop 1). Shuttles arrive approximately every 15 minutes.

The Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is the park's largest stand of giant sequoias, with about 500 mature sequoias in the grove. Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and board the free shuttle bus to get a glimpse of these giants.

Dates are subject to change according to weather and road conditions, which may vary from year to year. In any given year, shuttle service will begin no earlier than April 15 (possibly later), and will close on or before November 30 (depending on conditions).

Shuttle hours vary throughout the season, with longer hours in summer. See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for current operating hours and season dates.

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.
data.audioDescription: The Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza is built on a downward slope, allowing for four tiered areas. The lower first and second tiers are parking areas, where as the third tier is an information station containing interpretive panels, a bookstore, restrooms, drinking fountains, and benches. Steps lead to the fourth, upper most tier, where Mariposa Grove shuttle stop 2 is located. There is a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath. The Bus stop sign reads "Stop 2, Mariposa Grove Parking, Mariposa Grove Shuttle, Shuttle Route," and shows a basic map of the shuttle route as well as the schedule, which both change with the seasons. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

data.title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza & Parking
data.listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is awe-inspiring. Leave noise and civilization behind to walk among these stately giants. Visitors have access to parking, restroom facilities, visitor information, and can board a free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area.

images.altText: Wooden and stone building that houses the restrooms and Depot bookstore.
images.title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza

data.bodyText:
Park at the Welcome Plaza before you take the shuttle to the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias. The plaza features parking, restrooms, a Yosemite Conservancy bookstore, and visitor information. Board the free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. See local postings for shuttle information.

The road to the grove, beyond this parking area, is closed to private vehicles. Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive up to the Mariposa Grove Road during the hours the shuttle is operating. There are very limited designated accessible parking spaces at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area and at Grizzly Giant accessible parking area.

Tips & Seasonal Information

From approximately December through March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates.

When shuttle service is not available, the Mariposa Grove can be reached via a two-mile hike (each way) on the Washburn Trail or the Mariposa Grove Road (each has approximately 500 feet in elevation gain). Several miles of trails are available in the grove from that point. During winter, trails may be snowy and/or icy.

See website for more information.

Bicycles are allowed on the Mariposa Grove Road between the welcome plaza (near South Entrance) and the Grizzly Giant when the road is open for the season. Bicycles are not allowed anywhere else in the the Mariposa Grove, including hiking trails.

Pets are not allowed on any trails in the Mariposa Grove. Pets are allowed on leash in the parking lots only. Pets are not allowed on shuttles.

Accessibility

Visitors can use the designated accessible parking at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza then ride the shuttle, all of which is wheelchair accessible. Or, vehicles displaying a disability placard may drive up the Mariposa Grove Road and park at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or at the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is very limited.
data.audioDescription:
The Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza is built on a downward slope, allowing for four tiered areas. The lower first and second tiers are parking areas, which include designated spaces on the second tier parking area, where as the third tier is an information station containing interpretive panels, a bookstore, restrooms, drinking fountains, and benches. Steps lead to the fourth, upper most tier, where Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 2 is located. There is a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath.

The interpretive panels includes information about Giant Sequoia ecology, stewardship of the grove, how to visit the grove, and contains a map of Yosemite, highlighting other areas of the park. In the center of the interpretive panels is a large slice of a giant sequoia, with a sign titled A history revealed, which shows an illustration of the sequoia slice, and dates according to it's rings. One of the inner most rings dates back to 1149. There are also some bronze, tactile relief models of Sequoia trees, a chipmunk, and various paw prints.

data.title: May Lake Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Spend a day, or a night, at this stunning alpine lake that reflects a picturesque view of Mt. Hoffmann. A short trail leads through a conifer forest and across granite slabs to reach May Lake. Enjoy views of Half Dome and surrounding mountains on the way.If the dirt road is closed, the trailhead will require an additional 2 mile hike uproad, one way. May Lake (moderate)2.4 mi (3.9 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours 485 ft (150 m) elevation gainFor hiking and trail information, plea

images.altText: A blue alpine lake below a granite peak
images.title: May Lake
images.caption: May Lake

data.bodyText:
A short trail leads through a conifer forest and across granite slabs to reach May Lake. Enjoy views of Half Dome, Clouds Rest, and surrounding peaks on the way.

Distance: 2.4 mi (3.9 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours
Elevation gain: 485 ft (150 m)
Time estimate: 1-2 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Depending on conditions, particularly in early summer, the unpaved road to reach the trailhead may be closed. When closed, hikers must hike an additional 1.75 miles each way along the road. A vault toilet is available at the parking area. A flush toilet may be seasonally available at the May Lake High Sierra Camp.

Begin at the May Lake parking area, 1.75 miles (2.8 km) north of Tioga Road. This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
The May Lake Trailhead is in a small parking lot located, on a rugged, paved, one-lane road east of the Tioga Road. When the parking lot is at capacity or the road is closed due to snow and ice, an additional two-mile hike, one-way, from the Tioga Road is necessary. A brown trash bin, green recycle bin, and small, brown structure, which holds the vault toilet, line the parking lot. The dirt trail begins in the midst of trees, near a small pond, next to the vault toilet, and is marked by two signs.

The first metal sign reads, May Lake High Sierra Camp - 1.2 miles.

The second metal sign is brown and reads, Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry watercourses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

data.title: McGurk Meadow Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Traipse through a meadow of wildflowers (while staying on the trail, of course), and embrace the cool sub-alpine air this remarkable hike has to offer. The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk. During early summer, look for a tremendous show of wildflowers.

images.altText: Green grassy meadow with blue skies and trees
images.title: McGurk Meadow
images.caption: McGurk Meadow

data.bodyText:
McGurk Meadow

The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk. During early summer, look for a tremendous show of wildflowers.

Distance: 1.6 miles (2.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 150 ft (45 m) on return
Time estimate: 1-1.5 hours

Dewey Point

Past the meadow, hikers can continue along the trail an additional mile (1.6 km) to reach the junction with the Pohono Trail. Turn left (west) at this junction to reach Dewey Point, a panoramic viewpoint overlooking Yosemite Valley.

Distance: 8.2 miles (13.2 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 750 ft (230 m)
Time estimate: 4-5 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available at this trailhead.

This trailhead is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
A small, dirt, roadside parking area is located about 10 yards away from a brown and white sign that reads McGurk Meadow, which has an icon of a hiker inside a white square outline.
