In the parking area, which is lined with trees, one green recycle bin and one brown trash bin sit next to two brown food lockers. At the McGurk Meadow trailhead sign situated along the road, a dirt path leads into the shaded forest. Two signs are bolted to a metal post. The top sign is brown and white and it reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness. Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least 6 inches deep 100 feet away from water. Bury or pack out toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

The second sign is a metal sign with text cut out of it that reads, view of Yosemite Valley 3.9 miles, Dewey Point 3.9 miles, Taft Point 4.2 miles, Crocker Point 4.6 miles, Stanford Point 5.3 miles, Glacier Point 7.6 miles, Inspiration Point 9.8 miles, Yosemite Valley via Union Point 12.4 miles.

data.title: Merced Grove
data.listingDescription: Visit Yosemite's quietest stand of giant sequoias at the Merced Grove.The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias, accessible only on foot. This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves. The trail drops down 1.5 miles, making this a moderate hike on the uphill portion.

images.altText: Six giant sequoias behind a wood barrier fence clustered together in a forested area
images.title: Merced Grove
images.caption: Giant sequoias in the Merced Grove

data.bodyText:
The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias and is reachable only on foot (there are no giant sequoias visible from the parking area). This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves. The trail slopes downhill into the grove, making this a moderate hike on the return to the parking area. An old ranger patrol cabin, the former summer retreat of park superintendents, is part of the grove's history. Look for dogwoods blooming here in the spring.

Distance: 3 miles (4.8 km) round trip
Elevation gain: 520-foot (158 m) on return
Time estimate: 1.5-3 hours

Tips

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on this trail. A vault toilet is located near the trailhead parking area. There is no drinking water at the parking area or in the grove. Be sure to bring drinking water with you.

Seasonal Information

In winter, ski or snowshoe touring in Yosemite can be a magnificent experience! The first half mile is level and easy, providing a good warm-up for the steep 1 mile (1.6 km) descent into the grove. This trail requires heavy snowfall from a cold, lower-elevation storm to be skiable. Trails are not groomed in the Crane Flat area. Icy or crusty conditions as well as deep snow can make winter travel on trails much more difficult.
data.audioDescription:
A small, paved, parking area is next to a main road and is surrounded by forest. A green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, brown, wood, structure, which holds a vault toilet, all line the parking lot. A wayside exhibit, framed in thick, log posts, stands at the trailhead, which appears to be a wide dirt road that is gated at the entrance.

The green-toned exhibit panel is titled Merced Grove Trailhead and has an illustrated map, which takes up a majority of the left side of the panel. The map shows a red dot at the bottom of the map, which is labeled, you are here. A yellow squiggle line, representing the trail, makes its way through a faint canopy of trees to the grove. An aerial view of about 12 bold tree tops are shown at the end of the trail, as well as a small cabin.

Caption: The path to the Merced Grove is the roadbed of the historic Coulterville Road. Started in 1870, John Taylor McLean invested his entire fortune to ensure the success of the project. Although his efforts failed financially, his contribution resulted in the historic accomplishment of completing the first road into Yosemite Valley. Regularly scheduled stage travel began June 18, 1874.

Black and white photo: A classic car is stopped next to a large tree, on a narrow dirt road that passes through a forest of tall trees.

Caption: This small grove of about twenty trees was named Crane Flat Grove by the Whitney Survey in 1870. The grove was later re-named Merced Grove, reportedly due to its proximity to the Merced River.

Text on the right side of the panel reads, the smallest of Yosemite's three giant sequoia groves, the Merced Grove offers perhaps the best opportunity for a solitary experience among these colossal giants.

While enjoying your walk to the grove, consider the rarity of this experience. At one time, sequoias covered an extensive range, but now grow only in isolated groves on the Sierra Nevada's western slope. Limited by specialized growing needs, these trees require both moisture-mostly from winter snowfalls-as well as periodic fire. Frequent burns expose bare mineral soil for seeds to take root. Fire also reduces the number of competing species and opens the forest canopy for sunlight to reach the sun-loving trees. Sequoias appear large and strong; however, their shallow roots are quite vulnerable to damage. Avoid walking in areas immediately surrounding the bases of the trees. Leave cones and other natural items that you find.

Illustration: A wedge-like, cross-section illustration that is thick on one end and tapers to a thin edge on the other, shows the slope of the trail. A red dot at the top of the wedge reads, you are here. A yellow line, indicating the trail, squiqqles downhill to the grove of trees. At the bottom of the wedge, an arrow goes from one end to the other and is labeled, 1.5 miles.

Trail Conditions: Carry enough drinking water for a fairly rigorous hike. Make sure to allow 3 to 4 hours for a 3-mile round-trip hike. There are no restrooms or running water in the grove. The return uphill is moderately strenuous (600ft. (183 m.) elevation gain). This trail is marked for cross-country skiing and snowshoeing in winter.

Black and white photo: A small log cabin sits in the midst of a forest. On the front side of the cabin, a door is in the center with one window on each side. A stone chimney rises out of the roof.

Caption: The old cabin along this trail was built in 1934 as a summer retreat for park superintendents. More recently, it has served as a retreat and learning space for school children visiting the park.

data.title: Mirror Lake Trailhead
data.listingDescription: With a fresh perspective looking up at Half Dome directly from its base, you'll be rewarded with views of Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, Washington Column, and more. While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake is fullest in spring and early summer. When water is calm, the lake offers beautiful reflections of surrounding cliffs. Mirror Lake is often referred to as Mirror Meadow in late summer due to the lack of water.

images.altText: Signs and service road at Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.title: Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.caption: Mirror Lake Trailhead signage and service road to Mirror Lake

data.bodyText:
This hike features views of Half Dome, Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, and Washington Column. While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake typically only has water in spring and early summer. When water is calm, the lake offers beautiful reflections of surrounding cliffs, creating the mirror effect for which the area is named. In late summer and fall, the dry lake bed becomes a meadow.

The first mile of this trail is a paved service road that leads directly to Mirror Lake. You may access the loop trail from the end of the paved path. The loop follows Tenaya Creek beyond the lake, and crosses two bridges after the Snow Creek Trail junction before returning past Mirror Lake on the south side of Tenaya Canyon. There is no safe access to the north side of Mirror Lake directly from the south side of the loop.

Distance: 2 mi (3.2 km) round-trip
Elevation: 100 ft (30 m)
Time estimate: about 1 hour

Route variation: consider hiking the full loop past Mirror Lake and around Tenaya Creek for a longer, 2-3 hour hike. The loop is approximately 4.5 mi (7.2 km) with minimal elevation gain.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Vault toilets are available about 0.5 miles (0.8 km) from the trailhead and also at Mirror Lake. There is no drinking water at the trailhead or along the trail.

Leashed pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed on the first paved mile of the trail. Beyond that, they are prohibited.

The south side of this loop can be slick, muddy, or flooded during winter and early spring. In winter and spring, consider avoiding this area and hiking an out and back trip along the north side of the loop.

Caution: During spring and early summer, when water levels are highest, entering the water can be dangerous.

Accessibility

A one-mile road, from the Mirror Lake shuttle stop, leads to Mirror Lake and is easy to walk due to its paved surface. The last 1,000 feet of the trail up to the lake is on a slope from 6.6 percent to 10.6 percent.

Vehicles with a disability placard are permitted to drive up to 15 mph, with hazard lights on, to Mirror Lake. Be cautious as the road is shared with bicyclists and hikers. There are two designated accessible parking spaces available.
data.audioDescription:
A green and white shuttle stop sign stands next to the roadside turnout where the shuttle bus stops. The sign reads, Valley shuttle, Mirror Lake Trailhead, and has the number 17 in white font within a green circle. Next to the sign is a wooden shelter that holds two benches. A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a wayside exhibit and a sign that has three small panels across the top and a large map on the bottom, are near the shuttle stop shelter. A paved path/road retreats into the trees behind the shelter. The first panel on the sign is yellow with a green bar across the top. Text in the green bar reads, shuttle bus schedule. The text in the yellow section reads, shuttle stop 17, Mirror Lake. From 7am to 10am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The second panel is white with a blue bar across the top. Text in the blue bar reads, Did You Know? Text in the white section reads, Mirror Lake is not really a lake at all. Until the middle of the 20th century, park personnel dredged sand to maintain a pond that reflected the cliffs above. Current park policy is to let the natural succession of pond to meadow occur. During high water, however, you can still see a stunning reflection of Half Dome. Photo: One person stands in ankle-deep snow, with a backpack on the ground by his side, and his back turned from the camera. He is facing a small body of water and the large face of Half Dome which towers over this lake. Snow covers the landscape.

Caption: At Half Dome's base, Mirror Lake forms in winter and spring, but is more of a sandy beach during the dry season. NPS photo by Erik Skindrud.

The third panel is white with an orange bar across the top. Text in the orange bar reads, Be Bear Aware. Text in the white box reads, Keeping bears away from your food isn't just a way to avoid a fine-it could save a bear's life. Do not store food in vehicles after dark. When not stored in a locker or cabin, food must be within arm's length. Stay at least 50 yards from a bear. If a bear approaches, yell to scare it away.

Photo: A reddish-brown black bear with yellow plastic tags on both ears, is hanging halfway out of a parked car's side door window. The door frame is bent half way down, the side view mirror is dangling, and the glass has been busted out. It is dark out.

Caption: Bear break-ins can cost thousands of dollars and put visitors and bears at risk. NPS photo by Tammy Evans.

A large map showing three different shuttle routes in Yosemite Valley is below. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

The wayside exhibit panel is located on the right side of the path and is titled, Mirror Lake. The panel has a faint, black and white, background photo of a body of water lined with trees and tall, granite, rock faces. Text reads, in the 19th century, Mirror Lake became famous for its magnificent views of surrounding peaks reflected in the water's glassy surface. But the "lake" was misnamed - it is simply a broad shallow pool in Tenaya Creek. The reflecting pool varies with the season. By late summer, when Tenaya Creek is no longer fed by melting snows from above, the pool disappears.

Under a heading that reads, A Well-Traveled Path, text reads, Mirror Lake was a much publicized attraction for late 19th century tourists. It is still one of Yosemite's most popular hiking destinations. The view of Half Dome's 4,800-foot sheer face, seen from its base, is an attraction any time of the year.

Another section of the panel is about mountain lion habitat and reads, you are in a mountain lion habitat. Children should not run ahead or lag behind on the trail. Hiking alone and jogging are not recommended. In the unlikely event that you see a mountain lion, do the following:

Stay calm. Do not run. Do not turn your back on the lion.
Adults should pick up small children.
Make yourself appear as large as possible; raise your arms over your head and open your jacket.
If it acts aggressively, wave your arms, shout, and throw rocks and sticks at the lion.
If attacked, fight back!

Illustration: A mountain lion, standing on a downhill slope, faces to the left with its mouth slightly open and its ears perked.

data.title: Mist and John Muir Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Climb along nature's "giant staircase," where you will be rewarded with close-up views of two waterfalls and numerous geologic features (depending on how far you choose to hike). Powerful and turbulent, these two waterfalls will soak you in spring and entice you year-round.

images.altText: A full Vernal Fall with hikers along the rock steps of the Mist Trail
images.title: Mist Trail and John Muir Trail Trailhead
images.caption: Mist Trail leading to Vernal Fall

data.bodyText:
From June 30 through October, the Mist Trail from its junction with the John Muir Trail (above Vernal Fall footbridge) to the top of Vernal Fall will be open Fridays through Sundays and on holidays  (and on Thursday, July 3). It will normally also be open Mondays through Thursdays from 3:30 pm to 7 am (when safe). The John Muir Trail is an alternate route to the top of Vernal Fall at other times; this detour facilitates Mist Trail repair work.

The John Muir Trail from Clark Point to its junction with the Panorama Trail near Nevada Fall will be under construction from September 10 through December 3, 2025, for trail repair. A detour is available for hikers via the Mist Trail (from the top of Vernal Fall to the top of Nevada Fall; be sure to read additional detour information above). 

Additionally, the following route may have intermittent delays up to six hours due to blasting on weekdays from October 6 through October 24: the full Mist Trail (from just above Vernal Fall footbridge to near the top of Nevada Fall). For more details and a map, see trail information page.

The very popular John Muir and Mist Trails offer spectacular, up-close views of two large waterfalls, enjoyable scenery along the Merced River, and unique views across Yosemite Valley. About 1 trail mile from the trailhead, beyond the Vernal Fall Footbridge, the Mist Trail and the John Muir Trail diverge. Consider accessing Vernal and Nevada Fall via the Mist Trail, looping around and taking the John Muir Trail back down to the Valley. Prepare for slippery footing and a tremendous amount of waterfall spray in spring and early summer. See more information about trails. 

Access the trailhead via the Valleywide Shuttle or East Valley Shuttle. There is no parking at the trailhead. The closest parking lot is located at Curry Village, approximately 1 mile (1.6 km) one-way from the trailhead.

Route Information

Vernal Fall Footbridge

Distance: 1.6 miles (2.6 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 400 feet (120 m)
Time estimate: 1-1.5 hours

Top of Vernal Fall

Distance: 2.4 miles (3.8 km) round-trip as out-and-back via Mist Trail
Elevation gain: 1000 feet (300m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 2-3 hours

Top of Nevada Fall

Distance: 5 miles (8 km) round-trip as out-and-back via Mist Trail
Elevation gain: 2,000 feet (610 m)
Time estimate: 4-5 hours

Route variation: Hikers can take the John Muir Trail on the return from the top of Vernal or Nevada Fall for a semi-loop that is slightly longer than the out-and-back routes. See map for this area.

Tips

  • Pets, bicycles, and strollers are prohibited.
  • Stay on the established trail: do not swim or wade in the river and do not walk along the edge of the river. Observe warning signs and railings: these exist for your safety.
  • Drinking water is available at the shuttle stop near the trailhead, and also at the Vernal Fall Footbridge (May to October). This is the only drinking water available along the trail, so carry plenty of water for your hike.
  • Restrooms are located at the shuttle stop near the trailhead. On trail, restrooms are located at the Vernal Fall footbridge, approximately 1 mile up the trail (May to October). Vault toilets are available beyond the top of Vernal Fall (along the Mist Trail) and at the top of Nevada Fall (along the Mist Trail).
  • Do not shortcut switchbacks, which causes rapid trail erosion and results in injuries.
  • Shortly beyond Vernal Fall, you will pass by Emerald Pool and Silver Apron. Both of these look may look inviting on a hot summer’s day, but it is illegal and dangerous to swim here due to the extremely hazardous current.

Seasonal Information

Both Vernal Fall and Nevada Fall can be reached year-round, however, seasonal closures may impact your route. The lower portion of the Mist Trail along Vernal Fall closes in winter due to risk of falling ice and rock; use the John Muir Trail to access the top of Vernal Fall.

The upper portion of the John Muir Trail between Clark Point and the top of Nevada Fall is closed in winter due to dangerous icy conditions; from the top of Vernal Fall, use the Mist Trail to reach the top of Nevada Fall.

Sections of trail that remain open in the winter may be very icy and/or snowy. View current conditions for trail closures.
data.audioDescription: At the trailhead, a brown sign with a hiker icon reads, Mist Trail, Vernal Fall, Nevada Fall and John Muir Trail, and has an arrow pointing right. A sandy path next to a river eventually ends and takes a hard left up an immediately steep, paved trail. The hike has started at this point and proceeds uphill, into the forest. Not too far up the trail, which is lined with shed-sized boulders in some areas, is a large wooden sign that lists the destinations reachable on this trail.

data.title: Mono Meadow Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome, from Mono Meadow. The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow-an area that is very wet throughout the summer. Expect log crossings over creeks and lots of mud. Follow the trail from the east end of the meadow for a half mile (0.8 km) to an unmarked clearing. From here, the views will open up to the Clark Range and beyond.

images.altText: Trail sign in a wooded area
images.title: Mono Meadow Trailhead
images.caption: Mono Meadow Trailhead

data.bodyText:
Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome from this trail. The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow. Follow the trail from the east end of the meadow for a half mile (0.8 km) to an unmarked clearing. From here, the views will open up to the Clark Range and beyond.

Distance: 3 miles (4.8 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 900 ft (275 m) on return
Time estimate: 2-3 hours

Tips & Seasonal information

This area is very wet throughout summer. Expect log crossings over creeks and lots of mud. Stay on trail and go through mud puddles rather than around them to prevent trail widening and protect this ecosystem.

This trailhead is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The Mono Meadows Trailhead is found at the east end of a dirt parking lot. The parking area is surrounded by forest, with Glacier Point Road to the north. Two brown trash bins and two green recycle bins, along with a row of brown, metal food lockers line the outskirts of the parking lot. Two signs are bolted to a metal post at the trailhead to Mono Meadows. The top sign is metal with letters that are cut out of it. The sign reads, Mono Meadows 0.6 miles, Illilouette Creek 2.0 miles, Nevada Fall 6.1 miles, and Buck Camp 15.3 miles. The lower sign is metal with words etched out of it. The words were painted red, but a majority of it has faded or chipped off. The text reads, entering Yosemite wilderness. Wilderness permit required, overnight users only. Pets and firearms prohibited. No wood fires above 9,600 feet. Pack out all that you pack in. Bear habitat - proper food storage required by federal law.

data.title: Mono Pass Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east. This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks. At the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon.

images.altText: An alpine lake in a meadow surrounded by cured, golden vegetation
images.title: Mono Pass trail
images.caption: View from Mono Pass in early fall

data.bodyText:
This historic trans-Sierra trail climbs gradually through lodgepole pines and past wet meadows. In mid-summer, look for red mountain heather blooming trailside. After the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon: from the pass, hike a bit farther toward Upper Sardine Lake.

Distance: 8 miles (12.9 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,000 ft (300 m)
Time estimate: 5-7 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

This trail includes several unbridged stream crossings. Early in the season, when water can be very high, cold, and swift, use caution when crossing streams or turn back when crossing is not safe.

In early summer, the trail can be very muddy in places. Stay on trail and go through mud puddles rather than around them to preserve delicate plant life in this sensitive ecosystem.

Bicycles and pets are not permitted on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available at the trailhead parking area.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The small, paved, parking area for Mono Pass Trailhead is located along the south side of Tioga Road. It is marked by a brown metal sign that has a white icon and text. The sign reads, 'Mono Pass,' and has an icon of a backpacker and an arrow that pointing to the right.In the parking area, there are two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, a row of food lockers, and a small, brown facility, which holds a vault toilet. Two small signs that read, 'no camping,' and 'no dogs,' line the curb, near the trailhead. A wooden fence separates the parking area from the wilderness area.Six signs line the dirt path at the Mono Pass Trailhead. The first sign is a wayside exhibit titled Yosemite Ghost Mines, and has a faded black and white photo of a log structure, too shabby and small to be a cabin, but very cabin-like. Text reads, as early as 1860, prospectors explored Mono Pass in search of rich rock. Here, among the glacially carved granite and craggy peaks of the Sierra crest, these hardy men discovered silver deposits and went to work in hopes of fortune.Buildings of the Past - five log cabins mark the location of the Golden Crown and Ella Bloss miners near Mono Pass. This windswept site was established in 1879 during the Tioga silver boom that also produced Bennettville and the Great Sierra Mine near Tioga Pass. Significant wealth was predicted, but around 1890, the mines were abandoned.A Past Preserved - The cabins are increasingly fragile reminders of mining on the Sierra crest. Please help preserve these valuable historic resources by not using them as campsites or fire shelters. It is illegal to damage, deface, or remove archaeological objects or features from federal land. The second sign is separated into five sections. Two small square panels on top, a large map in the middle, and two small square panels on bottom. The Top left panel is maroon with white text and reads, Mono Pass Trailhead, follow the path of Yosemite's first people, the Miwok, over their trade route to the east.Mono Pass is 3.7 miles and Parker Pass is 5.2 miles. The entire watershed of the Dana Fork of the Tuolumne is closed to overnight camping to protect water quality.The top right panel is blue with white text and reads, Wilderness Regulations, the natural integrity of Yosemite's high country depends on you. Help protect the wilderness, and avoid a citation, by following these regulations.Camp at least four trail miles from all developed areas.Pets, firearms, and bicycles are prohibited in wilderness.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks kills vegetation and causes erosion. Maximum group size for cross-country travel is eight people.Avoid disturbing wildlife and other visitors by keeping quiet on the trail and in camp.Use a gas stove for cooking; wood fires are allowed only below 9,600 feet in existing fire rings using dead and downed wood.Leave campsites as you find them; do not build windbreaks, fire rings, hitch racks, chairs, drainage trenches, or other "improvements."Pack out everything you carry in; do not burn trash.Wilderness permit required for all overnight use.A series of three white circles containing three different icons are outlined in red and have a red diagonal line slashing through the middle. The three icons are of a gun, a dog, and a person on a bicycle.The large middle panel is a detailed map of the eastern portion of the park. Roads, trails, peaks, and lakes are labeled. For more information about Yosemite maps, please call 209/379-1035.The bottom left panel is blue with white text and reads, Water Quality - clean, sparkling water is one of the joys of the high country. Wildlife, wilderness visitors, and people downstream all need clean water to stay healthy.Protect your water suppy by following these regulations and suggestions:Camp at least 100 feet (40 steps) from water.Deposit human waste in a six-inch-deep hole at least 100 feet from water; carry out toilet paper.Wash dishes and yourself at least 100 feet from water; even biodegradable soap pollutes.Carry a large water container and limit your trips to collect water; eroded stream banks and lake shores contribute to poor water quality.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks increases erosion and leads to silt-filled streams.Giardia lamblia is a disease-causing protozoan that can be present in all Sierran water; treat all water before drinking. The bottom right panel is yellow with black text and reads, Black Bears - the health and well-being of Yosemite's bears depends on you.Bears are intelligent, curious, adaptable, and hungry. Human food, however, is harmful to bears and other animals here. Keep wildlife wild by using these food storage methods.At the trailhead: Remove all food, ice chests, and scented items from your car. Store them in food storage lockers where available. Never feed bears or other wildlife.In the backcountry: Store food, garbage, and scented items in bearproof canisters, available at front country locations. Keep items s

data.title: Murphy Creek Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Enjoy this magnificent high-country lake surrounded by granite domes, lodgepole forests, and Yosemite's vast wilderness. Picnic tables are available at this pleasant spot near Tenaya Lake. Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations not accepted).

images.altText: Two picnic tables on a sandy beach with a large lake and towering peaks
images.title: Murphy Creek picnic area
images.caption: Murphy Creek picnic area at Tenaya Lake

data.bodyText:
The Murphy Creek picnic area is located along Tenaya Lake, offering beach access and beautiful views of Tenaya Peak. The picnic area is located a short walk from the parking area.

Vault toilets and trash/recycling are available in the parking area. There are no facilities in the immediate area of the picnic area or the beach.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

This picnic area is not wheelchair accessible. The paved pathway from the parking area is wheelchair accessible and connect to a long pathway along the north shore of Tenaya Lake. Vault toilets at the parking area are wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription: On the east side of a large paved parking area are two wooden picnic tables, a food locker, a brown facility holding four vault toilets, and a wayside exhibit, placed among tall trees. In the east corner of the parking lot are two large brown trash dumpsters, and one large green dumpster for recycling. The wayside exhibit panel is blue and is bolted to a frame made of thick wooden posts, and is titled, welcome to Tenaya Lake. Half of the panel background is a two-toned picture of a lake that is surrounded by domes and peaks. The other half of the panel is a map. The caption reads, caught between immense granite domes and the clear High Sierra sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite National Park. Here, at its eastern end, Tenaya Creek forms a series of braided streams before flowing into the lake. Text reads, if you have a few hours, stroll the flat, paved trail (less than a quarter-mile, round-trip). You'll be rewarded with glimpses of the glacially carved peaks and domes and a spectacular view of the lake emerging through the trees. If time permits, take a picnic to one of the tables on the beach and enjoy a lazy High Sierra afternoon exploring or relaxing in the smooth granitic sand. While hardy souls may be tempted to jump in, remember...Tenaya Lake is fed by snowmelt and stays quite cold!If you have half a day, don't miss the boardwalk, a picnic, or the beach, but (if conditions permit) cross the Tenaya Creek inlet at the southeast end of the beach and follow the trail west along the shore of the lake. This mostly-level stroll takes you toward the Sunrise Lakes Trailhead, joining back with the Tioga Road. Here, you can retrace your steps back or hop on the free shuttle at Stop #10, and ride one stop back to your car (stop #9). It is possible to walk all the way around the lake (2.8 mi/5.2 km), but requires walking along the shoulder of busy Tioga Road. A full-day hike to Tuolumne Meadows - Pick up a trail heading east from Tenaya Lake. This 9-mile one-way hike parallels the Tioga Road, leading to Tuolumne Meadows. At Tuolumne Meadows, pick up the free shuttle for the short ride back to Tenaya Lake. Shuttle Information - The free Tioga Road shuttle runs between Tuolumne Meadows and Olmsted Point. Shuttle schedule changes seasonally and as conditions permit. Check local postings for current schedule. During times of high water, unbridged river or creek crossings can be hazardous. Take extra time and use good judgement when crossing rivers and creeks. Check the weather! Be especially aware of the potential for thunderstorms. If you are hiking, take a map and compass. Tell someone where you are going and when you'll be back. Avoid exhaustion and dehydration. Carry plenty of water and high-energy snacks. The altitude at Tenaya Lake is just over 8,000 feet above sea level. Signs of altitude sickness can include nausea, dizziness, and headache. Descending to a lower elevation can help alleviate symptoms. Scrambling or climbing on rocks can be dangerous. Remember, coming down can be much harder than going up, and wet rocks are slippery. Be prepared to pack out what you pack in; garbage and recycling receptacles are located near the parking area. Map: The map shows Tenaya Lake, indicated by a large, blue, oval shape, slightly tilted, in the center of the map. A white line extends diagonally across the map, from the bottom left to the top right, passing by the north shore of Tenaya Lake. A trail, indicated by red dotted lines, passes by the south shore of the Tenaya Lake and partly follows a few creeks, indicated by a blue solid line, before splitting off into different trails to the left and right. To the left of the lake, icons indicate the start of hiking trails, restrooms, and parking. To the right of the lake, a red dot indicates you are here, and icons indicating trailheads, parking, restrooms, and picnic areas are shown. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. A flat dirt path leads into the forest with several wayside exhibits along the way to the Tenaya Lake shoreline. The first wayside exhibit is titled, disappearing wetlands. Text reads, wetlands like this one have likely been here for the last 10,000 years, providing homes and food for a great variety of plant and animal species. In Yosemite, wetland areas make up only about 3% of the landscape, but are estimated to harbor up to one-third of all the plant species in the Park. They also capture, store, and release melting snow, extending the availability of life-giving water during the dry summer months. Here in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and across the globe, wetlands are disappearing rapidly. Effects from trampling, development, and climate change threaten to alter the delicate wetland ecology forever. In Yosemite National Park, park managers work to prevent loss of wetlands by preserving and restoring wetland areas and building boardwalks to help minimize damage from visitors. Photo:

data.title: O'Shaughnessy Dam
data.listingDescription:
The O'Shaughnessy Dam
Named for the chief engineer, the O'Shaughnessy Dam was completed in 1938. Today, this 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies pristine drinking water to 2.7 million Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.

images.altText: A large body of water is seen in the distance behind a wayside exhibit.

data.bodyText: Named for the chief engineer, the O’Shaughnessy Dam was completed in 1938 and is 430-feet tall. Today the 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies drinking water to about 2.5 million San Francisco Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourth of six located along this path across the O'Shaughnessy Dam. The view is looking at the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir, a large body of water that is surrounded by granite mountains. A waterfall flows to the left.

Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a colorful photo of snow capped mountains beyond a line of trees. In the foreground water flows toward the viewer.

Caption: The Tuolumne River flows gracefully through Yosemite National Park.

At the top of the panel, the header reads Water Quality at Hetch Hetchy. Text reads: The Tuolumne River supplies 85% of the water for 2.4 million people. It originates from pristine spring snowmelt as far upstream as Mt. Lyell at an elevation of 13,114 feet.

The City and County of San Francisco protects the resources entrusted to its care by continuously monitoring this watershed and working with the park to minimize pollution.

Natural occurrences such as fire and erosion can affect water quality. More than 1,000 water samples are taken annually to protect the water quality of the Hetch Hetchy System.

Photo: A person set up a monitoring station on a riverbank. Two lawn chairs, an open umbrella, large plastic jugs, and other tools are strewn about.

Caption: Water quality specialists take samples from the river in Tuolumne Meadows to test for microorganisms.

Illustration: Clouds produce precipitation, represented by little white tick marks, over snow capped peaks. Blue scraggily lines that look like veins come from the mountains and meet up with a thick blue line, representing a river, which flows through a valley, past forests and towns that are indicated by small triangles.

Caption: A watershed is an ara that is delineated by high ridges such as cliffs, hills, and mountains. Rain or snowmelt flows down from the ridges and collects in streams, rivers, and other water bodies, such as lakes and reservoirs. Watershed protection is a top priority because it affects the quality of water for people downstream and everything that lives within these boundaries.

data.title: Olmsted Point
data.listingDescription: Visit the vista famous for its picture postcard views of Half Dome, Tenaya Lake and Clouds Rest. Olmsted Point looks down on Yosemite Valley from the east - and from a very different angle. Though you might not immediately recognize Half Dome, it is one of the most prominent peaks you can see from Olmsted Point. Olmsted Point was named after famed landscape architects, Frederick Law Olmsted (best known for his design of New York's Central Park) and his son Frederick, Jr.

images.altText: Bronze tactile model of the area with the same area shown behind the model at sunset
images.title: Olmsted Point tactile model
images.caption: Olmsted Point tactile model and scenic vista at sunset

data.bodyText:
Located along Tioga Road at approximately 8,400 feet above sea level, Olmsted Point offers panoramic views of Half Dome, Tenaya Lake, Clouds Rest, and many other granite domes and peaks. While beautiful any time of day, this overlook is an excellent place to watch sunset.

Enjoy the views from the roadside parking area or take a short, hilly 0.25-mile walk (one-way) further out onto the point on the established trail. Along this trail, you'll see examples of glacial erratics, which are boulders carried along by glaciers then left behind after those glaciers melted away.

Olmsted Point was named after famed landscape architects Frederick Law Olmsted and his son, Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. The senior Olmsted was an early advocate of public parks, including serving as chairman of the first commission to manage Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove in the 1860s. As chairman, he wrote a report recommending policy for the care and protection of Yosemite's scenery and wildlife, an important precursor to the national parks system. Continuing this legacy, Olmsted, Jr. drafted portions of the Organic Act, the 1916 legislation that created the National Park Service.

Seasonal Information

Olmsted Point can only be reached by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces available at both ends of the parking lot. The viewpoint can be seen from the parking area or on paved, wheelchair-accessible walkways next to the parking area. The trail leading out to the point is not wheelchair accessible. There is also a bronze relief tactile model of the surrounding landscape.
data.audioDescription: A view to the left of the large, slightly arched, one-row, parking area shows a ridge line that peaks at Cloud's Rest and continues down to an oddly shaped dome, which is the backside of Half Dome. To the right of and behind the parking area are smooth granite domes that have large boulders randomly scattered across its surface and trees growing out of the cracks of the granite. Near the center of the parking row, is an exhibit area that has three wayside exhibits and a bronze tactile model of the surrounding landscape. The background picture of the first wayside exhibit shows a perspective from a smooth granite dome with large boulders randomly scattered about, allowing views of Cloud's Rest and the backside of Half Dome, and is titled Olmsted Point. A black and white photo of the side profile of an older man with white hair and a white beard and mustache, looking to the left, is in the bottom right corner. The photo is captioned Frederick Law Olmsted, Sr. A subtitle reads, A family legacy. Text below reads, This turnout was named in honor of famed landscape architect, Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), and his son, Frederick, Jr., when Tioga Road opened to automobile traffic in 1961. Olmsted senior was considered the father of American landscape architecture and best known for his design of New York's Central Park. He was chairman of the first commission to manage Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove and wrote a report recommending policy for the care and protection of Yosemite's scenery and wildlife. It is considered a classic national park treatise. Black and white photo: A man with short hair and glasses, wearing a heavy coat and a tie, sits at a table with a pen in his right hand, drawing on a map. Photo caption: Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. Text to the right of the picture reads, Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. (1870-1957) also worked in the field of landscape architecture. He collaborated with the National Park Service and was a member of the Yosemite Advisory Board, a group of experts who helped park managers solve problems. He maintained a lifelong commitment to conversation, contributing the guiding language in legislation establishing the National Park Service in 1916. A second exhibit panel titled, Forces of Change, shows a black and white, faded, background photo of a large peak labeled Cloud's Rest and a dome with a smaller dome attached to it, labeled Half Dome. In the forefront, a large boulder rests on a smooth granite surface. Text on the left side of the panel reads, panoramic view. Half Dome stands before you. With a pair of binoculars, you can often see a line of hikers, like ants, climbing up cables to the summit. To the left is the massive northwest face of Cloud's Rest. From its summit (9,926 feet elevation) the sheer granite face, one of the largest in the world, drops nearly 5,000 feet to lower Tenaya Creek. A brief walk to the east side of the parking area will lead to spectacular views of Tenaya Lake, and Mount Conness. Powerful geological forces shaped this landscape. Evidence emerges throughout this granite scene. Chambers of magma deep within the earth slowly crystallized 100-80 million years ago to form hard granite rock. Over time, erosion by rivers and extensive glaciers exposed and sculpted the rock. Black and white photo: Two large boulders sit on a smooth granite surface, that has cracks criss-crossing each other. A man walks on the granite surface, and is a small figure in comparison to the the two large boulders. Caption: These large boulders randomly placed on the bedrock are evidence of the most recent glaciation. The rocks either toppled down slopes onto the glacier or were plucked from the bedrock. They landed here as the ice melted away. Black and white photo: Portions of a smooth granite bedrock seems buffed and shiny as the sun shines on it.Caption: Glacial Polish - Over the last million years, major glaciers have come and gone in Yosemite. Only 20 thousand years ago the most recent glacier extended from the high peaks to the distant horizon. Like rough sandpaper smoothing wood, these glaciers polished the rock you see near here. A third wayside exhibit panel titled Experience Yosemite has a faded background picture of trees and mountains that surround a lake. The lake is labeled Tenaya Lake. Text on the left side of the panel reads, Look and listen - Within this vast granite setting are the sounds of Yosemite's year-round residents. Listen for the occasional alarm whistle of the yellow-bellied marmot, the raucous calls of the Stellar's Jay or Clark's Nutcracker, or maybe the distant rhythmic booming of the male blue grouse trying to attract a mate. Stay long enough and a golden eagle may circle above. Growing twisted and gnarled out of cracks in rocks, Sierra junipers have red, ribbon-like bark and overlapping scales for leaves. Their blue, berry-like cones have a pungent gin-like smell. Juniper berries do not readily germinate unless they pass through the digest

data.title: Ostrander Lake Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Retreat to nature and encounter the beauty and radiance of this glimmering lake.The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep 1,500 foot (450 m) elevation gain opens up to views of granite domes, Mt. Starr King, and the Clark Range just prior to arriving at Ostrander Lake.

images.altText: Lake with granite peaks around it.
images.title: Ostrander Lake
images.caption: Ostrander Lake

data.bodyText:
The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep climb toward the end of the hike opens up to views of granite domes, Mt. Starr King, and the Clark Range just prior to arriving at Ostrander Lake.

Distance: 12 miles (19.3 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,500 ft (450 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 8-10 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available at the trailhead.

This trailhead is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

In winter, when Badger Pass Ski Area is open (typically mid to late December through March), the Glacier Point Road is groomed for cross-country skiing beyond the ski area, conditions permitting. See website for more information.
data.audioDescription:
The Ostrander Lake Trailhead is found on the south side of a dirt parking lot. The parking area is surrounded by forest, with Glacier Point Road to the north. Two trash bins and two recycle bins, along with a row of food lockers line the outskirts of the parking lot, to the left of the trailhead. A small brown structure serves as a vault toilet near the main road. At the trailhead, the dirt path leads through a forest of tall trees. Two signs are posted next to the path. The first sign is a metal sign that reads, Ostrander Lake 6.2 miles, Deer Camp 6.7 miles, Buck Camp 14.1 miles, Wawona 14.6 miles, Chiquita Pass 18.9 miles, and Fernandez Pass 22.8 miles.

The second sign is brown and reads, Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible.
Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

data.title: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
data.listingDescription: Some of Yosemite's most iconic natural features can be seen and experienced along these trails. Panorama Trail: This longer route to Yosemite Valley brings hikers past Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls. Combining this trail with the Four Mile Trail will make for a long, strenuous loop! Pohono Trail: This trail rewards hikers with several viewpoints of Yosemite Valley from the south rim. East to west, these views include Taft Point, Dewey Point, Crocker Point, and others.

images.altText: Wooden and metal signs at the trailhead
images.title: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
images.caption: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads

data.bodyText:
Starting from Glacier Point, both trails offer stunning vistas of Yosemite Valley's iconic landmarks along the descent to the valley floor.

There is NO shuttle service available to transport hikers from Yosemite Valley or Tunnel View back to Glacier Point. If you hike down, plan to hike back up or arrange your own transportation.

Panorama Trail

The Panorama Trail will be closed in the vicinity of the John Muir Trail junction, with no access between Glacier Point and Nevada Fall, on the following dates, from 7 am to 6 pm, due to helicopter operations:

  • September 22–24

  • November 17–18 (subject to change)

  • November 20–21 (subject to change)

Additionally, the following trails may have intermittent delays up to six hours due to blasting on weekdays from September 29 through October 24:

  • The Panorama Trail in the vicinity of the John Muir Trail junction

  • The full Mist Trail (from just above Vernal Fall footbridge to near the top of Nevada Fall).

    For more details, see     trail information page.

This route to Yosemite Valley takes hikers past Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls. Some of Yosemite's most iconic natural features can be seen and experienced along this trail. Though this trail is mostly downhill, there a significant 800-foot climb after crossing Illilouette Creek before descending again. At the junction above Nevada Fall, hikers can take either the Mist Trail or the John Muir Trail to the valley floor.

Distance: 8.2 miles (13.2 km) one-way
Elevation change: 3,200 ft (975 m) net descent one-way
Time estimate: 6-8 hours

Pohono Trail

This trail rewards hikers with several viewpoints of Yosemite Valley from the south rim. East to west, these views include Roosevelt Point, Taft Point, Dewey Point, Crocker Point, and Stanford Point. While this trail is net downhill, expect several moderate and steep uphill sections along the way.

Distance: 12.5 miles (20 km) one-way
Elevation change: 2,800 ft (975 m) descent one-way
Time estimate: 8-10 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls run year-round, though flow decreases significantly by late summer.

There are several unbridged stream crossings along the Pohono Trail. Use caution in late spring and early summer when water levels can be high.

This trailhead is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The Panorama and Pohono Trailheads begin in a rocky area, near the Glacier Point Amphitheater. A wooden post holds four signs at the trailhead. The top sign is an orange and black metal sign that reads: No shuttle service between Yosemite Valley and Glacier Point. The second sign is a wooden sign that has the following text carved out of it: Trailhead, Panorama Trail. Illilouette Fall - 2 miles, Nevada Fall - 5.2 miles, Vernal Fall - 7 miles, and Yosemite Valley - 8 miles. Pohono Trail, Sentinel Dome - 1.5 miles, Taft Point - 3.8 miles, and Wawona Tunnel - 13.8 miles. The third sign is a brown metal sign that reads: Entering Yosemite Wilderness. Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least 6 inches deep 100 feet away from water. Bury or pack out toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate squares with a red slash line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle. The last sign reads: Hiking Half Dome? Don't forget your permit. Half Dome permit required 7 days a week.

data.title: Parsons Memorial Lodge
data.listingDescription: Constructed in 1915, the Sierra Club commissioned the Parsons Memorial Lodge to serve as an early gathering place for the organization and a base from which club members could explore Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding Sierra Nevada high country.

images.altText: A small, single-story building with thick stone walls, a low-angled roof, and arched doorway
images.title: Parsons Memorial Lodge
images.caption: Parsons Memorial Lodge

data.bodyText:
Constructed in 1915, the Sierra Club commissioned the Parsons Memorial Lodge to serve as an early meeting place and starting point for the club's wilderness excursions in the surrounding Sierra Nevada high country.

The pink feldspar and grey granite stones that form the walls of the lodge were gathered on-site during construction. The peeled log rafters that make up the low-pitched roof were brought in by mule. An elegant example of environmental harmonization in the First Bay Tradition architectural style, the design of this building is credited to acclaimed architect Bernard Maybeck.

The lodge is named for Edward Taylor Parsons, a conservationist and early director of the Sierra Club. The National Park Service acquired the lodge and surrounding acreage from the Sierra Club in 1973. Parsons Memorial Lodge was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1979 and was designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1987.

Operating Hours & Seasons

The building is open to the public with limited hours in summer only. When open, visitors can browse the reading room and interpretive exhibits. Ranger programs may be offered at the lodge in summer.

See the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours and program schedule.

Accessibility

This building is not wheelchair accessible. To reach this building, visitors must walk approximately 1.4 mi (2.3 km) round-trip from either of two nearby parking areas. The walk has minimal elevation change except for a short hill along the final approach to the lodge. Surfaces to reach the lodge are unpaved and irregular. The entrance to the lodge includes several stone steps.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the thirteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. On top of a small hilltop is a cobblestoned structure. The building is mostly made of stacked granite stones. Vertical logs that make up the slightly pitched roof, overhang a few feet on the front side of the building. Five large structural log posts that make up the framework of the building, jut out the sides. An arched doorway with a wooden, arched door is in the center of the front, and one window is on each side of the door. A wooden bench is placed on both sides of the doorway. Large boulders scatter the area. A bronze plaque is affixed to one of the boulders near the building's entrance, which reads, Parsons Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987, National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior. The nearby wayside exhibit is titled, Parsons Memorial Lodge, and has a black and white photo on the left, two-thirds of the panel. The photo shows a line of over fifty people, most with walking sticks, hiking up a smooth, snowy, slope, in a wavy, snake-like pattern.

Caption: An early Sierra Club outing.

Panel text reads, as a guide for the early Sierra Club, Edward Taylor Parsons (1861-1914) led hundreds of people on unforgettable high mountain adventures. He also campaigned with John Muir, without success, to keep Yosemite National Park's Hetch Hetchy Valley undammed.

In 1915, the Sierra Club built this lodge in Parsons'memory. Orignally a meeting place and reading room. Parsons Lodge continues to be a refuge from afternoon thunderstorms, as well as a center for exhibits and special programs.

Photo: A middle-aged man with a full mustache and a top hat, wears a thick suit jacket over a white shirt with gloves that cover his sleeves, and knee-high boots that cover his long pants.

Caption: Edward Taylor Parsons

data.title: Poopenaut Valley Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Enjoy the wildflowers in spring as you hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley. Poopenaut Valley (strenuous)2.5 miles (4 km) round-trip; 3 to 4 hours1,229 feet (375 m) elevation gainVisit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area. Hours :Year-round, however, winter weather conditions may cause road closures. Call 209-372-0200 for the latest road and weather conditions,Hetch Hetchy Road Daily Hours:8am to 7pm, (April 1 to April 3

images.altText: A grassy valley in a granite gorge viewed from high above
images.title: Poopenaut Valley
images.caption: Poopenaut Valley

data.bodyText:
This short, steep hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley is a great spot for wildflowers in spring. Be aware that this is a steep hike on the return trip to the parking area. If you hike down, you must be able to hike back up! Parking is very limited.

Distance: 2.5 miles (4 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,229 feet (375 m)
Time estimate: 3-4 hours

Tips & Hours

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open from sunrise to sunset only. Hetch Hetchy trailheads are not reachable by vehicle when the road is closed.

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

Pets are prohibited on all hiking trails. Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.
data.audioDescription: A brown sign with an icon of a hiker, located on the left side of the Hetch Hetchy Road, four miles past the entrance station, marks the trail. A small roadside turnout is located on the right side of the road and has a food locker and very limited parking. It is noticable how steep the decent is from the trailhead. Hetch Hetchy Reservoir can be seen in the distance.

data.title: Porcupine Creek Trailhead
data.listingDescription: A day hike to North Dome will reward you with exceptional views of the dome of all domes, Half Dome, and the landscape that makes up Yosemite Valley and beyond.Wind through mixed-conifer forest for 0.7 miles (1 km) on a paved path, and cross Porcupine Creek. At each of several trail junctions, follow the signs toward North Dome. The trail passes through a small grassy meadow and descends along a ridge. Near the end of the hike, descend steep rock steps to the base of North Do

images.altText: Panorama of Half Dome and granite gorges below pink sunset skies
images.title: North Dome panoramic view
images.caption: Panorama of Tenaya Canyon, Clouds Rest, and Half Dome at sunset from North Dome

data.bodyText:
This longer day hike provides rewarding views of classic Yosemite landmarks. Wind through mixed-conifer forest, crossing Porcupine Creek within the first mile. The trail passes through a small grassy meadow and descends along a ridge. Near the end of the hike, descend steep rock steps to the base of North Dome. Climb the dome's rounded summit to take in a magnificent view of Half Dome, Tenaya Canyon, Clouds Rest, and Yosemite Valley.

Along the trail, hikers can take an optional short, steep spur (0.3 mile or 0.5 km each way) to Indian Rock, a natural granite arch.

Distance: 10.4 mi (16.7 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 580 ft (180 m) on return
Time estimate: 5-7 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available at this trailhead. Parking is limited.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
The Porcupine Creek Trailhead paved parking area is on the west side of Tioga Road and has two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, and a brown restroom facility near the center of the parking row. The trailhead is on the south side of the parking lot and is marked by a big wooden sign with white text.

Text that has been carved out of the wooden sign reads, Porcupine Creek Trailhead, North Dome 4.4 miles, Yosemite Falls 6.9 miles, Yosemite Valley (Mirror Lake) 8 miles, and Yosemite Valley 9.5 miles. A dirt path descends into the forest. Granite boulders are scattered about.

data.title: Pothole Dome Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows. Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome, an approachable hiking route that accesses the top of the dome along with its unobstructed, exciting panoramic views.

images.altText: A granite surface in the foreground backdropped by distant rolling granite peaks
images.title: Pothole Dome
images.caption: View from the top of Pothole Dome

data.bodyText:
Take a short, easy hike to reach magnificent views of high Sierra peaks, meadows, and domes. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome. From there, walk up to the top of this short granite dome.

Distance: 1 mi (1.6 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 200 ft (60 m)
Time estimate: 1 hour

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay on designated trails to protect this fragile meadow ecosystem! Off-trail travel compacts meadow soil and crushes plants, damaging the ecosystem that is important to the many plants and animals that thrive in this fragile environment.

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

This trail is not wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription: A roadside turnout with limited parking on the north side of Tioga Road hosts views of a large open meadow and surrounding peaks and domes. A trail to the west of the parking area leads around the outskirts of the meadow, to Pothole Dome, a smooth granite dome that would allow for a slightly higher panoramic view. In the distance, a forest lines the perimeter of the meadow and pointed peaks rise above the tree line. Several signs are posted at the parking area and the start of the path. The first sign in the parking area is a brown sign, outlined in white, and has white text that reads, no camping or overnight parking.The second sign is a small, white, metal sign on a wooden post located on the meadow side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the dirt parking from the meadow. A photo on the upper right side of the sign shows several bright, tall, wildflowers in a lush green meadow with a snow covered peak rising above the pine treeline in the distance. The sign reads, meadow restoration in progress. Trails that pass through sensitive habitats, such as Tuolumne Meadows, can have an impact that reaches far beyond the trail. We are currently working to restore this area. Please stay on the main trail shown in blue on the map. Please stay on designated trail.Photo: Two people walk off-trail through a large meadow. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a dense forest. Map: In a square frame, the Tioga Road is indicated by a blue and white tick line that leads from the upper left corner to the bottom right corner. Above that line, sandwiched between the road and a large white area that indicates the granite of Pothole dome is a meadow, a wetland area represented by an upward-turned, banana shape filled with blue marks. A yellow star and text that reads, "you are here," along with an icon of a hiker inside a red square, which is a trailhead, are along the Tioga Road, one quarter of the way from the top. A blue solid line, which is the Pothole Dome Trail, makes its way around the left side of the banana-shaped wetland area then leads to the right, all the way to the right side of the frame. A red, solid line cuts through the meadow from Tioga Road to Pothole Dome and forks out into two paths, they are marked closed.A wayside exhibit titled Sub-Alpine Zone, is located on the parking side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the meadow from the dirt parking area. Text on the left side of the panel reads, the plants and animals in this zone sometimes have only two and a half months to complete a year's work. At this elevation, the snow can be on the ground well into June, only to return as early as September. Bevause this sub-alpine meadow ecosystem is so fragile, even one person crossing it can cause serious damage - especially if it is wet. By following the trail to your left on your hike to Pothole Dome, you can protect plants and animals during their active season.Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of both labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. At the start of the Pothole Dome Trail, a brown sign outlined in white has white text that reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. data.title: Ranger Patrol Cabin
data.listingDescription: In 1914, the U.S. Cavalry left Yosemite. The management of this huge park fell to a small group of 15 men who had served as cavalry scouts. Their duties were made more difficult by the fact that automobiles had been allowed to enter the park in August 1913. Buildings such as this were used as automobile check stations. Here drivers paid a $5 fee to enter the park and were informed of regulations.

images.altText: Wooden cabin
images.title: Ranger Patrol Cabin
images.caption: Ranger Patrol Cabin

data.bodyText:
After twenty-three years protecting the park, the U.S. Army was called away from Yosemite in 1914, and civilians began to assume ranger roles. It was the job of these rangers to protect the natural resources, stop forest fires, and assist visitors. Their duties were made more difficult as automobiles had recently been allowed to enter the park.

The ranger patrol cabin was built in 1915 to house rangers at Crane Flat, a busy road junction. Buildings such as this were used as automobile check stations. Here drivers paid a fee to enter the park and were informed of regulations. Along sections of the Big Oak Flat and Wawona roads, automobiles were only permitted to go east, downgrade, on odd hours and west, upgrade, on even hours. At Crane Flat and others Yosemite locations, rangers needed to live close to backcountry patrol routes and roadside stations where they assisted visitors arriving by automobile. In 1916 the National Park Service was created and the rangers living here became some of the first National Park Service Rangers.

Gabriel Sovulewski, a Polish immigrant, embodied the administrative transition from the military to the National Park Service in Yosemite. He first saw Yosemite in 1895 while on a summer deployment to the park with the U.S. Army. In 1902, he left the Army and returned to Yosemite to work as a packer and guide. In 1906, Gabriel was placed in charge of Yosemite National Park, serving as the top park official for thirty years. During that time he directed the construction of trails and buildings such as the Ranger Patrol Cabin. Gabriel Sovulewski remained in Yosemite for the rest of his life, and is buried next to his wife, Rose in the Yosemite Cemetery.
data.audioDescription:
This long log cabin has a brown wooden door just right of center. There are two windows on the left side of the door and one window on the right. There is a stone chimney on the left side of the structure, and a wooden stump stool in the front. An exhibit sign reads:

Ranger Patrol Cabin
In 1905, California ceded Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias for inclusion in Yosemite National Park. The ceded land was accepted by the federal government in 1906, adding 31,104 acres to the Park. Thus, after 16 years, the Valley and Grove became part of Yosemite National Park.

In 1913, the army stopped coming to the Yosemite, but the National Park Service had not as yet been established. In the intervening three years, fifteen civilian rangers, most of whom were formerly army scouts, were hired to protect the Park and its visitors - a big change from 150 cavalry men the previous year.

They were provided with three patrol cabins. This one, built at Crane Flat, incurred the following costs: Materials were $250.98 and Labor equalled $685.36...a wise use of your tax dollar in the early 1900's. These civilian rangers were absorbed into the fledgling National Park Service, created in 1916 to administer or unique national preserves.

data.title: Rangers' Club Architecture

images.altText: A two-story, U-shaped building with a steeply pitched roof, dormers, and a central courtyard
images.title: Rangers' Club
images.caption: Rangers' Club

data.bodyText:
The Rangers' Club was the first structure build in the National Park Service Rustic architecture style. Stephen T. Mather, the first director of the National Park Service, employed park rangers to guide tourists and protect the park from poachers. In 1920, Mather hired architect Charles Sumner to construct a home for members of his newly organized ranger force, paying $39,380 for the building out of his own pocket. It was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1985 for significance in the development of the Rustic style and is still in use today as a home for seasonal rangers.

Sumner designed a large, modified chalet with wood shingles and steeply pitched roofs. Instead of leaving simple corners, every edge of the building is defined with heavy log pilasters, strengthening the connection between the building and surrounding forest edges. The steep roofs shed the winter snows and emphasized the structure's verticality—an homage to the surrounding mountains.

Rangers’ Club is a private residence, do not approach the building or disturb the residents.
data.audioDescription: The Rangers’ Club is a somewhat large two-story, U-shaped building with many ornate details. The first story of the building is covered in wood shingles painted a dark, muted shade of red. The upper story features wood paneling painted the same color, with ornate details at the lower terminus of each wood panel. The grey roof shingles are very clearly visible on the second story of the building, as the building has an extremely steeply pitched roof. Dormer windows feature throughout the outer faces of the building. All the windows are vertically oriented, multi-paned, and the frames are painted a contrasting light tan. Both wings of the building have an exterior wooden staircase leading up to a second-story door on the ends of the wings. The central courtyard surrounds a large mature dogwood. There is a tall stone chimney at the center of the building just behind the dogwood.

data.title: Sentinel Beach Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Savor the moment while standing amidst the magnificent landscape before you, a landscape showcasing views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces. Picnic tables and grills are conveniently located at this scenic spot along the Merced River that offers views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces. Hours :This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk. Getting Here :Sentinel Beach Picnic Area, is located on Southside Drive, several miles east of Bridalveil Fall. R

images.altText: Picnic tables under tall trees and a towering granite wall
images.title: Sentinel Beach Picnic Area
images.caption: Sentinel Beach Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
Picnic tables, grills, and seasonal river access are available beneath towering Sentinel Rock. The adjacent beach offers access to the Merced River when water levels are low. Upper Yosemite Fall and surrounding cliff faces are visible from the beach area. Vault toilets are available in the area.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round from dawn to dusk.

Swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river is flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Sentinel Beach Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible vault toilets, and grills. The road and footpaths in the area are unpaved and generally flat.
data.audioDescription: The Sentinel Beach Picnic Area is on a dirt road that is located on the left side of Southside Drive, the eastbound, one-way road leading into Yosemite Valley. The dirt road almost immediately splits into two roads. The road to the right leads into a dense forest that has cleared areas that have picnic tables and permanent standing grills. There are no designated parking spots. The dirt road loops around, passing vault toilets and trash and recycle bins along the way, before meeting up with the main road again. In the picnic area, an obvious path leads out of the forest and onto an open sandy and pebbled beach, along the Merced River. The massive granite walls rise above the trees that line the riverbanks.

data.title: Sentinel Bridge
data.listingDescription: Sentinel Bridge provides breathtaking views of Half Dome directly, or of its reflection in the waters of the Merced River, especially at sunset.

images.altText: A large granite formation reflects in still water surrounded by trees
images.title: Half Dome reflection at Sentinel Bridge
images.caption: Half Dome reflects on the Merced River as seen from Sentinel Bridge

data.bodyText:
Sentinel Bridge provides an excellent view of Half Dome and its mirrored reflection on the Merced River, especially at sunset.
