Tips & Seasonal Information

Sentinel Bridge can be reached by car year-round. This bridge is a short walk from Yosemite Village Parking. Additionally, a small parking lot is located next to thebridge, which can only be reached via the northbound traffic lane from Southside Drive.

The reflection of Half Dome on the Merced River is best viewed when water is low and relatively still, such as fall or winter.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby. There is a pedestrian path that leads from the bus stop and parking area, across the street, to a paved sidewalk leading onto the bridge.
data.audioDescription: Sentinel Bridge is a great place to experience Half Dome. Many photographers enjoy gathering here to take pictures of Half Dome and its reflection in the Merced River, especially when the colors of sunset play on its rock face. The bridge is completely made of stone and is slightly arched. Wayside exhibits are affixed to the metal railing that is adhered to the rock barrier-walls on each side of the bridge. On the east side of the bridge, tall trees line the banks of the river and Half Dome rises over the tree line. The wayside exhibit is titled, The Story of Half Dome, and has a orange-toned, faint, background photo of textured granite rock. Text reads, millions of years ago the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there never was a matching half. Undercut by glaciers near the base, slabs of rock fell away from a broad vertical crack in the granite, leaving a sheer face. Remnants of the missing rock still project from Half Dome's rim. There are more granite domes here than in any other place in the world. Massive granite domes from when large curved layers of rock "exfoliate" or slab off. Illustrated brochure: A side profile of Half Dome, with dark shadows in the front and low laying clouds floating below its face. In the background, some grey peaks cross the skyline and the sky is a bright orange and yellow. The text reads Yosemite Valley, on top, and Southern Pacific, on bottom.Caption: c. 1910Black and white postcard: Half Dome and trees surrounding it have an almost symmetrical reflection in the Merced River. Caption: Half Dome from Sentinel Bridge, postcard, c. 1940. Since the mid-19th century, countless images of the park's most famous dome, Half Dome, have been circulated. Its profile has become an enduring and instantly recognizable symbol of Yosemite. A section on the left side of the panel has a header that reads, An Ahwahneechee Tale of Half Dome. Text below it reads, long ago, two travelers, Tissiak and her husband, Tokoyee, fought with each other. He became so angry that he began to beat her; enraged, she hurled her basket of acorns at him. As they stood facing each other, they were turned to stone for their wickedness. The acorn basket (Basket Dome) lies upturned beside Tokoyee (North Dome) and the rock face of Tissiak (Half Dome) is stained with her tears. Photo: Half Dome is illuminated with the orange light of the alpen glow. Behind Half Dome, other mountains a lit as well, and the sky is full of dark clouds. Across the street, on the opposite side of the bridge, another wayside exhibit is affixed to the bridge barrier-wall. The wayside exhibit is titled, River of Mercy, and has a orange-toned, very faint, background photo of an old map of Yosemite Valley. Text reads, early Spanish explorers named the Merced River for Our Lady of Mercy. In Yosemite Valley, later settlers saw the Merced and its tributaries as troublesome as well as merciful. They channeled the wild river, dynamited the glacial moraine at the Valley entrance to lower the water table, and diverted water to quench the thirst of livestock and to power a sawmill. Black and white photo: The banks of a river have receded, and about three feet of roots of two tree stumps are exposed. The river flows nearby.Caption: Overuse damages the riverbanks and riparian life. Black and white photo: A woman in white, water-resistant pants with suspenders, a white t-shirt, boots, and a ponytail inserts a pole into the muddy ground on the banks of a river. Another woman with a t-shirt and gloves, bends down on her knees, and inserts a pole in the ground in the same spot. The river flows nearby. Caption: Volunteers assist park resource managers in revegetating riverbanks.Human alterations have harmed the riparian (river-related) habitat. Introduced fish species gradually outnumbered the native rainbow trout. Human feet have trampled the riverbanks and destroyed streamside plants. Restoration efforts such as replanting, fencing, and elimination of fish stocking are returning the river to a more natural state. A section on the left side of the panel has a header that reads, A Wild and Scenic River. Text below it reads, the Merced River watershed begins in the southeastern portion of the park, primarily in the high country of the Clark and Cathedral Ranges. The river plunges over Nevada and Vernal Falls, then meanders across the flat Yosemite Valley floor. Leaving Yosemite Valley, it winds down the Merced Canyon into the San Joaquin Valley far below. In 1987, recognizing the Merced's pristine beauty, Congress designated its upper reaches in and below the park as a National Wild and Scenic River. Black and white Photo 1: A mountain landscape with sloping hills and pine trees is covered in snow. Snowcapped peaks are in the distant background.Caption: The Merced's pristine waters originate in the melting snows of Yosemite's high country.Black and white Photo 2: A mountain lake glistens and is framed by tree branches. Large granite rock formation

data.title: Sentinel Bridge Parking Area
data.listingDescription: Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially in the evening when the reddish-orange alpenglow is brought on by the setting sun. Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

images.altText: A line of cars are parked in a parking lot next to an open meadow that showcases a view of a tall waterfall.

data.bodyText:
Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially during the alpenglow, when a reddish-orange glow is brought on by the setting sun.

Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

Half Dome
The profile of Half Dome has become a recognizable symbol of Yosemite. Millions of years ago, the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there was never a matching other half. Passing glaciers undercut the base, and slabs of rock fell away, leaving a sheer face.

Merced River
The Merced River is a National Wild and Scenic River. Its waters originate in the melting snow of Yosemite's high country in the southeastern portion of the park. The river plunges over Nevada and Vernal Falls, then meanders across the flat Yosemite Valley. It continues its journey down the Merced River Canyon and spills into the San Joaquin Valley. Early Spanish explorers named the Merced River for Our Lady of Mercy.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
Located on Sentinel Drive, just over the Sentinel Bridge, and before Yosemite Village Day Use Parking.

Rules & Regulations:
Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility:
There are designated accessible parking spaces available.
data.audioDescription:
The Sentinel Bridge Parking area is a prime spot to experience Yosemite Falls. The north side of the parking lot is lined with a wooden fence that separates the sidewalk from the large open meadow that shows views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. Bus stop #11 stands at the southeast side of the parking lot. Four benches, a green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, wood, shelter are all by the bus stop. Further south from the bus stop, a crosswalk leads across the street to the Sentinel Bridge. A few wayside exhibits are located in the parking lot, along the meadow.

The first exhibit panel is titled Ecotones: Life on the Edge, and has a faint background photo of a small patch of meadow, containing long grasses and sedges, surrounded with pine trees. Panel text reads, the zone where two habitats merge is called an ecotone. The meadow/forest ecotone is visible here. The water-saturated meadow gives way to the oaks and towering conifers, which can't survive in flood-prone areas. The greatest diversity of wildlife exists in these transition areas where a variety of food and shelter is present.

The Changing Landscape - By the 1860s, hotel owners were converting meadows to pastures, gardens, orchards, and hay fields. They suppressed fires because they threatened wooden buildings. They also channeled the Merced River to control flooding and drained boggy areas of the Valley.

Black and white photo: Black and white spotted cows graze in an open meadow with towering cliffs surrounding them.

Caption: Yosemite Valley, 1918.

Meadows in Peril - Only a century ago the meadows of Yosemite Valley were far more extensive than they are today. With the right balance of water, fire, and soil conditions, a meadow can survive indefinitely. But with the altercation of the water table and fire cycle in the Valley, the natural balance was lost.

Black and white comparison photo 1: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows larges patches of open meadows with trees scattered here and there.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1899

Black and white comparison photo 2: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows dense stands of trees with only a few small patches of meadow showing.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1991

Next to the first wayside exhibit, a second one is titled Meltdown, and has a faint background photo of a waterfall coming over a tall, granite rockface. Panel text reads, the high-country snowpack is Yosemite's reservoir. As the snow melts in the spring, torrents of water cascade over Yosemite Falls (on the cliff before you) and over dozens of other waterfalls.

Upstream, shallow soil on granite slopes absorbs very little water, Once the snow is gone, usually by late summer, most of Yosemite's waterfalls quickly dwindle.

Black and white comparison photo 1: A close up view of a wet rock face.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Autumn

Black and white comparison photo 2: A thin stream of water falls over a large granite rock wall. White ice has built up on the rock face on both sides of the thin waterfall. At the bottom of the fall, a pile of snow has built up.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Winter

Black and white comparison photo 3: Two waterfalls are stacked on top of each other. The upper fall is full of water and the lower fall has a slightly more narrow, shorter, stream of water.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Spring

Black and white comparison photo 4: The two waterfalls that are stacked on top of each other have dwindled down to a think, hair-like strand of a waterfall.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Summer

Quote: "You should stop a while...a little below the head of the fall beside the enthusiastic throng of starry, comet-like waters to learn something of their strength, their marvelous variety of forms, and above all their glorious music, gathered and composed from the snow-storms, hail-, and rain- and wind-storms that have fallen on their glacier-sculptered, domey, ridgy basin." - John Muir, The Yosemite, "How Best to Spend One's Yosemite Time"

Lost Arrow - Seasonal changes affect more than just the waterfalls. Water seeping into cracks and fissures in the cliff face freezes and expands in winter, wedging off blocks of stone. This action constantly reshapes Yosemite Valley. Lost Arrow, the isolated granite pinnacle to the right of Yosemite Falls, was once a part of a solid wall of rock.

Black and white photo: A granite spire is shown from above, rising up like a tower.
Caption: Lost Arrow from above

A nearby sign reads, flood water level, 11pm, January 2, 1997. A double-sided arrow points from left to right. The sign itself stands over six feet high.

data.title: Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Get a 360-degree view of the park at Sentinel Dome and/or hike to an expanse on the south rim of Yosemite Valley, getting a close view of El Capitan and Yosemite Valley, at Taft Point.

images.altText: Pink and blue skies over sweeping views of granite cliffs and mountain peaks
images.title: Sentinel Dome sunset
images.caption: View from the top of Sentinel Dome at sunset

data.bodyText:
Sentinel Dome

This wide trail leads mostly across open granite with little shade. Scramble up Sentinel Dome's granite slope to enjoy 360-degree views of Yosemite Valley and the high Sierra. Consider taking this hike at sunset or during a full moon, but remember to bring a flashlight or headlamp.

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 400 ft (120 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 1-2 hours

Taft Point

This trail leads through forest and meadow to the rim above Yosemite Valley, including superb views of El Capitan and Yosemite Falls. Near Taft Point, you'll see The Fissures, which are narrow fractures in the granite called joints. Use caution around these fractures, which include drops of up to 2,000 feet.

Distance: 2.2 miles (3.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 200 ft (60 m) elevation gain on return
Time estimate: 1-2 hours

The Sentinel Dome and Taft Point trails can be combined into a longer loop hike by connecting via the Pohono Trail.

Tips

  • Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails.
  • Stay off domes during thunderstorms.
  • Pit toilets are available at the trailhead parking area.

Seasonal Information

These trailheads are only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, typically late May through October or November.
data.audioDescription: The Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead begins down a boulder-lined dirt path that leads from the parking lot. The path then comes to an intersection, where it splits to the left and right. A wooden post at the dirt intersection has two signs bolted to it. The top sign is a small wooden sign with the words Taft Point 1.1 miles with an arrow pointing to the left, carved out of it. It also reads, Sentinel Dome 1.1 miles, with an arrow pointing to the right. A faded metal sign below shows the icon of a dog and has a red line slashed diagonally through the icon. The area is sandy with chinquapin bushes around as well as tall pine trees.

data.title: Soda Springs
data.listingDescription: Let your senses take over and take in the sight, sound, and smell of Soda Springs, then read the wayside exhibit about drinking the water. Is it drinkable?

images.altText: A simple, small log structure surrounded by muddy, reddish waters
images.title: Soda Springs
images.caption: Soda Springs in early fall

data.bodyText:
At Soda Springs, carbonated water bubbles up out of the ground. The log enclosure surrounding the springs was built in the 1880s by John Baptiste Lembert, for whom Lembert Dome was named. Outside the log enclosure, notice other areas where water percolates up into the meadows. Iron content in this area gives the mud its rusty hue.

To reach Soda Springs, walk a short distance from Parsons Lodge parking or Lembert Dome parking area.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Read the nearby wayside exhibit to learn more about the mineral waters of Soda Springs.

Trails to reach Soda Springs are only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

Trails leading to Soda Springs are not wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the eleventh stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The meadow transitions into a waterlogged area. Many rocks are scattered about and have turned a rusty color and have a chalky, white, residue around them. A log enclosure that has an open top and an open door, protects the main hub of the springs. Inside the enclosure, air bubbles are constantly working their way to the surface of a small puddle, bubbling up around small rocks. The wayside exhibit is titled, Soda Springs, and has a black and white photo of four men at the springs, on the right, two-thirds of the panel. The man on the far left is on his hands and knees and has his face down to the ground. The next man to the right is facing away from the camera and has a bucket in his left hand and a ladle in his right. The next man to the right is kneeling down on his right knee, with his left knee propped up and his left arm resting on it. He is holding a cup in his right hand, ready to scoop up some water from the spring. The man on the far right stands with his left hand in his pant pocket and his right hand holding a cup, looking down, watching the spring bubble. Trees and peaks are in the distant background.

Caption: Early visitors to Soda Springs, 1872. Jean Baptiste Lembert built the enclosure you see today to protect these springs from grazing animals, c. 1885.

Panel text reads, can I drink the water? For thousands of years animals and people have visited these springs. Deer and birds obtain needed minerals. People enjoy the taste of the spring water.

These small, carbonated mineral springs are a mystery - even geologists cannot explain why they are here. Although the bubbling water comes out of the ground pure and clean, there is a possibility that people or animals have contaminated the water.

data.title: Soda Springs and Parsons Memorial Lodge Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Explore the mystery that is Soda Springs and delve into the history of Parsons Lodge on this delightful walk through Tuolumne Meadows. Walk along the gravel road and pass the locked gate (signed Glen Aulin and Soda Springs). Soda Springs-cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure. Historic Parsons Memorial Lodge offers exhibits (limited hours-see Yosemite Guide for schedule). A path to the bridge below the lodge continues to the Tuol

images.altText: A hiker along a gravel path through a meadow with domes in the distance
images.title: Parsons Lodge & Soda Springs trail
images.caption: Meadows, domes, and peaks along the trail to Parsons Lodge and Soda Springs

data.bodyText:
Explore the natural and cultural history of Tuolumne Meadows as you enjoy views of the Tuolumne River, many species of wildlife, and granite peaks and domes.

Soda Springs is a natural source of cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground. The spring is protected within a historic log enclosure. Parsons Memorial Lodge may be open during limited hours in summer. The lodge, which features historic exhibits and interpretive programs, may be open during limited hours in summer.

Begin this walk from Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center, Parsons Lodge parking, or Lembert Dome parking. Distance may vary slightly depending on exact starting point.

Distance: 1.4 miles (2.3 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: flat
Time estimate: about 1 hour

Tips & Seasonal Information

Along this walk, you may get a glimpse of the many wildlife that inhabit the meadows, such as Belding's ground squirrels, mule deer, yellow-bellied marmots, and many others. Stay on designated trails to protect this fragile meadow ecosystem!

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. A vault toilet is available near Parsons Memorial Lodge.

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

This trail is not wheelchair accessible. Some of the trail is a wide gravel path while other sections are narrow, rocky, and uneven. The western trail from the visitor center and Parsons Lodge parking includes a bridge that crosses the Tuolumne River; this bridge has several stone steps on either side.
data.audioDescription: The trailhead to Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge is located along a dirt road that has limited, undefined, roadside parking. Five food storage lockers, a green recycle bin, and a brown trash bin sit on a slab of cement, along the road, near a closed metal gate. A sign on the gate shows two illustrations. The first illustration is an icon of a dog inside a white, square outline, and a red diagonal line slashing through it. The second illustration is an icon of a bicycle inside a white, square outline, and a red diagonal line slashing through it. To the right of the closed gate is a walkway to get to the trail, which also appears to be a dirt road. Next to the walkway is a wooden sign that reads, Soda Springs, Parsons Lodge, and Glen Aulin Trail, which all have a white arrow pointing forward in front of each name. Text continues to read, pets and firearms prohibited. Tall trees line the parking area and the beginning of the trail.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Glacier-Carved Landscape
data.listingDescription: You're standing where glaciers once passed through. Look for evidence of glaciers and read the wayside exhibit to learn more.

images.altText: Several large boulders randomly sit on an expanse of granite bedrock, which is streaked with lines and cracks.
images.caption: Glacial Erratics and striations can be seen on the granite bedrock near Olmsted Point.

data.bodyText: You're standing where glaciers once passed through. Look for evidence of glaciers and read the wayside exhibit to learn more.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the second stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Trees start to thin out as this area begins to open into a meadow. Large granite boulders are randomly sitting throughout the meadow. Granite peaks are peaking through the trees to the west. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Glacier-Carved Landscape, and has an illustration of the surrounding area covering the upper two-thirds of the panel. Two domes that overlap each other are in the foreground. The front dome shows the close-up detail of the granite's patchy surface...some areas are textured and gritty, shown by different variances of speckled grey, while other patchy areas are white to indicate its smoothness. The white, smooth areas are labeled, glacial polish and striations. The next dome, a little further in distance, is white and smooth. There are about 13 large round boulders that sit atop its surface, which are labeled erratics. Beyond the domes is a large, flat, open space - the meadow. Beyond the meadow, the terrain slopes upward into a range of high peaks. A sharp, pointed, craggy peak is labeled Cathedral Peak.

Panel text reads, imagine a time when it was colder and snow did not melt in summer. The accumulated snow turned to ice. As the ice deepened, its weight caused it to flow as a glacier down the canyon to the west. Glaciers formed here many times in the past two million years. As recently as 20,000 years ago, glaciers covered all but the highest jagged peaks around you.

Look for evidence of glaciers such as erratics (boulders moved by glaciers), glacial polish, and striations in the bedrock. Only sharp peaks, such as Unicorn and Cathedral, poked above the 2,000 feet of glacial ice.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Place for People
data.listingDescription: For thousands of years, the trade routes of local Native Americans passed through this area. What did they trade and who traded with who? Read this wayside exhibit to learn more.

images.altText: Sunlight hits bowl-shaped depressions that were pounded into granite rock.

data.bodyText: For thousands of years, the trade routes of local Native Americans passed through this area. What did they trade and who traded with who? Read this wayside exhibit to learn more.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the ninth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Tall trees stand nearby to the left. To the right, an open meadow shows off the sharp, pointed, granite peaks that rise above the distant forest. A narrow river snakes its way through the center of the meadow, from left to right. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Place for People. On the right, two-thirds side of the panel, there is a colored photo of an older woman with glasses, wearing a scarf around her head. She is wearing a red, button-down dress with white polka-dots, and a blue and white floral apron around her waist. She is on her knees on a large rock, leaning forward, with both hands grasping a pestle that is pressed down into a pile of acorns inside a shallow hole in the rock.

Caption: Acorns were an important food source for both the Sierra Miwok and the Mono Lake Paiute people. The acorns were pounded into flour in bedrock mortars; some of these mortars can be found near Lembert Dome and elsewhere in Tuolumne Meadows. Photo right: Maggie Howard, Mono Lake Paiute, 1942.

Panel text reads, for thousands of years, when the snow melted and the deer returned, Native Americans traveled here. During the 1800s, the Mono Trail crossed Tuolumne Meadows, linking Sierra Miwok people from the west and Mono Lake Paiute from the east. For a lengthy period, they traded pine nuts and obsidian from the Mono Basin for acorns and shell beads from west of the Sierra.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Short Growing Season
data.listingDescription: Tuolumne Meadows is often covered in snow from approximately October or November to late May, giving plants and animals only a short window of time to prepare for winter again. Read the wayside exhibit to learn about Tuolumne Meadows' short growing season.

images.altText: Trees surround the perimeter of a meadow. Two tall peaks rise above treeline in the distance.

data.bodyText: Tuolumne Meadows is often covered in snow from approximately October or November to late May, giving plants and animals only a short window of time to prepare for winter again. Read the wayside exhibit to learn about Tuolumne Meadows' short growing season.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fifth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. This particular part of the meadow has a bunch of trees enclosing the view. Different types of sedge and grasses grow, as well as some small saplings. Granite boulders are randomly scattered. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Short Growing Season, and has an illustration of a meadow on the bottom two-thirds of the panel. Short grasses grow in different sized, connected, ring-shapes, throughout the meadow. A line of trees and mountainous terrain are along the back edge of the meadow.

Panel text reads, few types of plants can survive where the growing season is so short. Almost all of Tuolumne's plants are perennial; most annuals cannot grow here. They do not have enough time each summer to sprout, flower, and seed. The dominant grass-like plant is shorthair sedge. By late summer, the meadow turns amber as the sedge matures and becomes dormant.

Illustration: A wispy, tuft of hair-like grasses grow upward, some with small oval-shaped growths at the ends. The roots are short, brown, and just as hairy looking.

Caption: Meadow soils are shallow and fragile. Unauthorized trails compact the soil and the ruts can last for centuries. Please stay on designated trails.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Summer Home
data.listingDescription: Jean Baptiste Lembert enjoyed this view back in the 1800s. How did he suvive the Tuolumne Meadows winters? Read this wayside exhibit for more information.

images.altText: A dirt road that doubles as a walking trail leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: Jean Baptiste Lembert enjoyed this view back in the 1800s. How did he suvive the Tuolumne Meadows winters? Read this wayside exhibit for more information.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the eighth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour and is located at a fork in the path/road. The path to the left leads into the open meadow that allows views of surrounding peaks and domes. The path to the right goes slightly uphill and into a stand of pines. A little way up the path is a metal trail marker that reads, Soda Springs .1 mile, Parsons Lodge .15 mile, Glen Aulin 5.4 miles, and Pacific Crest Trail. The wayside exhibit is titled, Summer Home, and has a black and white photo of an old log cabin on the right, two-thirds of the panel. The small, rugged cabin has a roof made of wooden shingles, no door, and airy spaces between the logs. A large pile of boulders sit next to the cabin.

Caption: The old Tioga Road leads off to the left. Continue to the right to Soda Springs.

Panel text reads, Jean Baptiste Lembert (1840-1840), one of the many people drawn to this landscape, claimed 160 acres around Soda Springs in 1885.

He raised angora goats and gathered insect specimens for the Smithsonian and other museums. Like the native people, Lembert moved to lower elevations in the winter.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Baptism in Nature's Warm Heart
data.listingDescription: Immerse yourself in the meadows and think about all the people who have crossed through this area. To learn more read the wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A black and white photo shows an elderly man sitting on a boulder. He white hair and a long beard.

data.bodyText: Immerse yourself in the meadows and think about all the people who have crossed through this area. To learn more read the wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the first stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A dense stand of pines surround the area as the dirt path, which also appears to be a dirt road, transitions into an open meadow. A metal sign with text cut out of it reads, PCT and John Muir Trail, with upward pointing arrows. The wayside exhibit is titled, Baptism in Nature's Warm Heart and has a photo of an older man, with a white beard and mustache, on the left side of the panel. The man is wearing a long-sleeved white shirt, a black vest, and dark pants. He is sitting on a rock, with his legs dangling and crossed, his arms reached out, crossed, and leaning on a walking stick, looking off into the distance, to the right.

Quote: "This is the most spacious and delightful high pleasure-ground I have yet seen...and though lying high in the sky, the surrounding mountains are so much higher, one feels protected as if in a grand hall." - John Muir

The panel text reads, thousands of people - Native Americans, pioneers, sightseers, and rangers - have traveled through Tuolumne Meadows and returned often. It was here that conservationist John Muir introduced his friends to the mountain wilderness and began the discussion that created Yosemite National Park.

You, too, can stroll down the old Tioga Road into the heart of Tuolumne Meadows toward Soda Springs and immerse yourself in these high meadows.

Black and white photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest.

Black and white photo: Two Caucasion children wearing hooded jackets sit on a rock and look at the camera.

Black and white photo: A close-up photo of a Caucasion man wearing a ranger hat, looking off into the distance toward the right.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Birth of A Park
data.listingDescription: It took a discussion around a campfire here, and two magazine articles to convince the American public that this area was worth preserving. Learn more about this area on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: It took a discussion around a campfire here, and two magazine articles to convince the American public that this area was worth preserving. Learn more about this area on this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the twelvth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The marshy, waterlogged area of Soda Springs, seen just down the dirt path to the left, transitions back into a meadow with tall grasses. A narrow river flows to the right, and pointed granite peaks can be seen above the distant treeline. The wayside exhibit is titled, Birth of a Park, and has a black and white photo of a man and two women sitting on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest, on the right, two-thirds of the panel.

Caption: Visitors to Tuolumne Meadows on the old Tioga Road, c. 1890

Panel text reads, around a campfire here in 1899, John Muir and publisher Robert Underwood Johnson discussed ways to protect this area. Johnson printed two articles by Muir in his Century Magazine, proposing to the American public that this land be preserved for all time. One year later Yosemite National Park was born.

In 1892, Muir founded the Sierra CLub to encourage others to explore, protect, and cherish their new park.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Eloquent Spokesman
data.listingDescription: Throughout Yosemite, you'll see quotes by John Muir that express his observations, experiences, and spiritual connection with the area. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about John Muir and how this scenery you're looking at now, inspired him.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: Throughout Yosemite, you'll see quotes by John Muir that express his observations, experiences, and spiritual connection with the area. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about John Muir and how this scenery you're looking at now, inspired him.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the tenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. An open meadow with no trees directly obstructing the view. A river snakes through the meadow and a granite mountain range rises over the distant forest, spanning the panoramic view from left to right. The wayside exhibit is titled, Eloquent Spokesman. A sketch of two large masses, side by side, one in front of the other with the front edges slanting downward, and multiple arrows pointing left. At the front of the masses are five trees. Cursive scribblings accompany the sketch.

Caption: One of Muir's journal pages, 1872. His observations of glacial evidence led to new theories about Yosemite's origins.

Black and white photo: an older man, with a white beard and mustache, is wearing a long-sleeved white shirt, a black vest, and dark pants. He is sitting on a rock, with his legs dangling and crossed, his arms reached out, crossed, and leaning on a walking stick, looking off into the distance, toward the right.

Caption: John Muir, 1907

Quote: "In every walk with nature one receives far more thane he seeks." - John Muir, 1877

Panel Text reads, John Muir (1838- 1914), first came to these meadows in 1869 as a sheepherder. He was so moved by Tuolumne that he returned here throughout his life, often with friends. Muir wrote about how the mountains changed him.

At first he was overwhelmed by the beauty and grandeur. Then he wanted to explore the mysteries of the geology and biology. In time, he experienced a spiritual connection that inspired him to protect the mountains he loved.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - McCauley Cabin
data.listingDescription: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wood cabin sits on a hilltop above a meadow. Pointy granite peaks can be seen in the distance.

data.bodyText: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A rustic log cabin sits on a small hilltop, overlooking Tuolumne Meadows, the river, and the granite landscape that surrounds it. The front of the cabin has a wooden door with a window, offcentered to the right, and a window with shutters on each side end of the building. There are now windows in the back. The nearby wayside exhibit is titled, The McCauley Cabin, and has a black and white photo on the left, two-thirds of the panel. The photo shows a man, a woman, and two young blonde girls standing in front of them. The young girl to the left is shorter than the girl on right, who is wearing checkered pants. A log cabin home is in the background, with boulders and trees surrounding it.

Caption: The campground caretakers stayed in the McCauley Cabin. As a young girl, Margaret Eissler (in checkered pants) lived here with her family for six summers (1956-1961). Her childhood experience instilled a love for Tuolumne Meadows that influenced all aspects of her life. She later returned as a ranger-naturalist.

Panel text reads, Following Jean Baptiste Lembert's death, the McCauley brothers bought his land for pasture in 1897 and built this cabin. When the land was again put up for sale, Sierra Club members raised money to purchase it in 1912 to keep it uncommercialized.

The Sierra Club opened a small campground, and summer after summer campers returned here to renew their connection with these meadows and mountains. In 1973, the National Park Service bought the Sierra Club property.

Tuolumne Meadows has found its way into many people's hearts. Follow the river. Take some time to explore. Discover for yourself the wonders of these high meadows.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadow Dwellers
data.listingDescription: To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. How do other local animals adapt to the winter? Learn more on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. How do other local animals adapt to the winter? Learn more on this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the sixth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The meadow has several trees that obstruct the open view. Small patches of grass grow mixed with small patches of bare, granitic sand. Granite rocks and boulders are randomly scattered. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadow Dwellers, and has an illustration of a cross-section of a meadow on the top two-thirds of the panel. The illustration projects four layers of a meadow during the winter - an underground layer, a thin layer of air between the ground and the snow, a large layer of snow, and then what is above the snow. The left side of the illustration shows a large tree with its roots spreading out beneath the ground. Perched on one of the tree branches is a small, chipmunk-like animal, with a long, fuzzy, curled tail, labeled chickaree. To the bottom left of the tree is a small, mouse-like animal walking in the air pocket between the ground and snow layer; it is labeled a shrew. Below the ground, in the midst of the trees' roots is a grey squirrel, curled into a ball, sleeping in a pocket that has a tunnel leading to the grounds surface. It is labeled Belding Ground Squirrel. To the right of the tree are two large boulders that are half underground and half above ground. A tunnel leads underground into a pocket beneath a large boulder where an animal with a long, slender body rests on its haunches; it is labeled pocket gopher. A mouse nestles in an airpocket between the ground and snow, next to one of the large boulders. Above the snow layer, a coyote has his head tilted up with its mouth open, as if its howling, and a longtail weasel slithers down the snow. A mountain range is in the background.

Caption: There is an air layer called the subnivean zone bewteen the snow and ground where small creatures live during the long winter.

Panel text reads, when you look for wildlife here, think small. Birds and rodents are abundant. Deer and bears are here, though seldom seen. To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. Mice, shrews, and gophers remain active under the snow, where they are hunted by small predators like weasels.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadow in the Sky
data.listingDescription: Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows. Learn about how this meadow changes over the winter season on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows. Learn about how this meadow changes over the winter season on this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the seventh stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, several trees pop up in an otherwise open meadow full of tall grasses. The granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadow in the Sky, and has a colored photo of an open landscape, blanketed in thick snow, leading to and showcasing snow-capped, pointed mountain peaks. Pine trees are on the left and right of the open area. The sky is clear and blue.

Panel text reads, these meadows stretch along the Tuolumne River for ten miles. At 8,600 feet, winter lasts for eight months, forcing the plants and animals to adapt to deep snow and a short growing season.

The climate is typically Mediterranean; winters bring ninety percent of the precipitation and summers are dry and warm. The meadows change visibly from week to week as they adjust to a compressed spring-summer-fall season.

Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadows
data.listingDescription: Take a look at the vast meadow before you. Meadows are always changing. To learn more about how and why, read the wayside exibit about meadows.

images.altText: A small pine tree grows in a dry, brown meadow.
images.caption: A small pine tree grows in a dry meadow.

data.bodyText: Take a look at the vast meadow before you. Meadows are always changing. To learn more about how and why, read the wayside exibit about meadows.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, a meadow containing tall grasses, several mature pines and a few small saplings spans outward. Granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadows, and has an illustration of a cross-section of the Tuolumne Meadows area covering the upper two-thirds of the panel. The bottom quarter of the illustration depicts a white wave that starts at a small hill on the left, slopes down into a slump, then slopes back up into another small hill. Beneath the ground, the white wave, which represents granite bedrock is broken up into multiple wavy parallel lines. On top of both the left and right hill is a tree with roots that vein down and outward through the layers of granite, beneath the ground surface. In the downward slump, or basin, between the two hills, an open green meadow is shown. A few granite peaks rise above a tree line in the background.

Panel text reads, after the glaciers melted 10,000 years ago, shallow, broad depressions in the bedrock began to fill with sand. Because granite basins hold spring snowmelt, these areas are too wet for trees. Sedges and grasses thrive in these saturated low spots, creating meadows. Meadows are always changing. As they get drier, trees invade the edges and high areas. In wetter times, the trees die and the meadows expand.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Picket Pins
data.listingDescription: As you stand here, can you hear the sounds of nature? Birds? Picket Pins? To learn more about "picket pins," otherwise known as Belding ground squirrels, read the wayside exhibit, then keep your ears and eyes open to see if you cross paths with one.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along the dirt trail that leads on the outskirts of a meadow.

data.bodyText: As you stand here, can you hear the sounds of nature? Birds? Picket Pins? To learn more about "picket pins," otherwise known as Belding ground squirrels, read the wayside exhibit, then keep your ears and eyes open to see if you cross paths with one.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the third stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, several trees pop up in an otherwise open meadow full of tall grasses. The granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Picket Pins, and has a black and white photo of a squirrel covering the right half of the panel. The squirrel is facing toward the left, standing straight as an arrow with its arms hanging down in front of it.

Caption: The nickname "picket pin" likens the straight posture of the alert squirrel to the metal pin once used to picket horses in meadows.

Panel text reads, the most commonly seen and heard meadow dwellers are teh Belding ground squirrels, or "picket pins." They stand up and watch for danger, then whistle to warn the others.
Adult females and juveniles live in extended family groups, while adult males live alone at the edge of the meadows. In late summer, only the young are still active; the adults are already hibernating.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Tuolumne River Bridge
data.listingDescription: Finish off your tour by standing on this bridge and taking in the panoramic view of the meadows, peaks, domes, and river, and reflect on the natural and cultural history that made this moment possible.

images.altText: A bridge crosses over a river that flows through a meadow.

data.bodyText: Finish off your tour by standing on this bridge and taking in the panoramic view of the meadows, peaks, domes, and river, and reflect on the natural and cultural history that made this moment possible.
data.audioDescription: This is the fifteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A wooden bridge with knee-high wood railings, crosses over the glistening Tuolumne River as it narrowly meanders through the meadows. Standing on the bridge, looking west, a granite mountain range with several pointed peaks, the Cathedral Peak, Unicorn Peak, and Eichorn Peak, panoramically extends across the landscape, beyond the distant treeline. Looking east, a distinct granite dome, Lembert Dome, is not to far off. Beyond the dome, further in the distant, beyond treeline, are more mountains. Looking down, the water is clear and the bottom of the river, which has smooth rocks and pebbles, can be seen.

data.title: South Entrance
data.listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

images.altText: Three small wooden buildings at the entrance with the American flag on a pole
images.title: South Entrance
images.caption: South Entrance

data.bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! The South Entrance is a fee station located along Wawona Road, the continuation of Highway 41 within the park.

Visitors can pay the park entrance fee, show their parks pass, or purchase a pass as they enter the park. Park brochures may be available. Entrance stations at Yosemite do not accept cash. Learn more about entrance fees and passes. 

Seasonal Information

Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year (conditions permitting).

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
data.audioDescription: As you approach the entrance station, the road splits into three separate, inbound lanes. There is one outbound lane. Each inbound lane has a ranger-managed booth on its left side. The American flag waves on a tall flagpole at the entrance station.

data.title: Stoneman Meadow
data.listingDescription: With views of Half Dome, North Dome, Upper Yosemite Fall, and Washington Column, Stoneman Meadow is an excellent spot for sunset and for appreciating the area's rich meadow ecology. In mid-to-late summer, watch Hooker's evening primrose blossoms open at dusk, attracting sphinx moths to their bright yellow blooms.

images.altText: A grassy, open area with granite cliffs above
images.title: Stoneman Meadow
images.caption: Stoneman Meadow in summer

data.bodyText:
With views of Half Dome, North Dome, Upper Yosemite Fall, and Washington Column, Stoneman Meadow is an excellent spot for sunset and for appreciating the area's rich meadow ecology.

In mid-to-late summer, watch Hooker's evening primrose blossoms open at dusk, attracting sphinx moths to their bright yellow blooms.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay on designated paths and boardwalks to protect fragile meadow ecosystems!

This area can be reached year-round. Boardwalks may be very slippery from frost or snow in winter.

To reach this meadow, take the free shuttle to Curry Village, or park your vehicle in nearby Curry Village or in designated roadside parking. Parking or driving on vegetation is prohibited.

Accessibility

Wheelchair accessible paved paths and boardwalks are available in and around this meadow.
data.audioDescription: A large, open area rich with vegetation such as grasses, sedges, and wildflowers. In spring and summer, the meadow is a verdant green and may even have some standing water dampening the soil as snow melts. Vegetation gradually cures to a golden color in late summer and fall. Vegetation often reaches heights of over three feet from the ground. The meadow is bisected by a paved and gravel pathway that is closed to vehicles but frequently used by bicyclists and pedestrians. A road that is open to vehicles flanks part of the meadow from west to east, with vehicles often parallel parked on the north edge of the road next to wood barrier fencing that protects the meadow from vehicles. A smaller portion of the meadow exists on the south side of this path, with the larger part of the meadow on the north side. A boardwalk traverses the large meadow area from south to north, curving gently to the east and eventually reaching Lower Pines Campground. In many directions, tall trees such as pines and oaks border the meadow. Overhead, Half Dome, a granite monolith with a distinct half-sphere shape, looms high above to the east, with North Dome and Washington Column just to the north. In the opposite direction, to the east, Upper Yosemite Fall may be seen cascading over a sheer cliff during the wetter times of year.

data.title: Summit Meadow
data.listingDescription: In the summer, an explosion of color lure people toward this sub-alpine meadow to delight in the spectacular display of wildflowers.

images.altText: Grassy meadow with purple wildflowers in bloom
images.title: Summit Meadow
images.caption: Summit Meadow

data.bodyText:
In the summer, this sub-alpine meadow to delight features a spectacular display of wildflowers. To protect fragile meadow ecosystems, please stay out of the meadow.

Parking is extremely limited.

Tips & Seasonal Information

A vault toilet is located next to the parking area for this meadow.

This area is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

There are no designated accessible parking spaces. The meadow can be viewed from the paved parking area.
data.audioDescription: The forest opens up into a large meadow along the south side of Glacier Point Road. In the summer, a full display of wildflowers carpet the meadow. In the fall, the plush, green meadow turns light brown. The far side of the meadow is lined with forest. A paved roadside turnout offers limited parallel parking. A few clusters of tall trees are near a wooden fence that zigzags between the parking area and the meadow. A small yellow sign bolted to the wooden fence reads, give plants a chance, please stay off. An illustration of a foot, ready to step on small flowers and plants is inside a red circle with a line slashed diagonally through the circle. A green recycle bin and a brown trash bin are near the parking turnout. A small, brown, structure that houses a vault toilet is at the west end of the parking area.

data.title: Sunrise Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: If you're seeking a challenge with a picturesque payoff, Sunrise Lakes won't disappoint. Indeed, a beautiful place to see a sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. There is also a High Sierra Camp located at Sunrise, whose origin dates back to 1916, the earliest days of the National Park Service.

images.altText: A narrow granite ridgeline extends toward the horizon and many distant peaks
images.title: Clouds Rest
images.caption: Ridgeline near Clouds Rest summit

data.bodyText:
Sunrise Lakes

Indeed, a beautiful place to see sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. A short distance from the lakes, the Sunrise High Sierra Camp faces east for sunrise views. Reservations are required for lodging at all High Sierra Camps.

Distance: 10.4 mi (16.7 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,300 ft (396 m)
Time estimate: 6-8 hours

Clouds Rest

Situated at 9,926 ft above sea level, the summit of Clouds Rest affords hikers spectacular, 360-degree views of Tenaya Canyon, Yosemite Valley, and countless high Sierra peaks. The final ascent toward the summit follows a narrow granite ridgeline. Caution: stay off this summit and ridgeline during thunderstorms or when wet.

Distance: 14 mi (22.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 2,300 ft (700 m)
Time estimate: 8-10 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. Vault toilets are available at this trailhead. A composting toilet is available seasonally at Sunrise High Sierra Camp (this is not on the route to Clouds Rest).

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription: The Sunrise Trailhead is found on the south side of a small, paved, loop driveway and parking area, along the south side of Tioga Road. The turn-off to the parking area is marked with a brown and white sign that shows a white icon of a person hiking inside a white square outline. The parking area is surrounded by trees, with Tioga Road to the north. A brown dumpster, six food lockers, and a small structure containing a vault toilet, line the outskirts of the parking lot. At the trailhead, the dirt path leads through tall trees. Three signs are posted next to the path. The first sign is a metal sign that reads, Sunrise H.S.C. 5.2 miles, Clouds Rest 7.4 miles, and Half Dome 12.5 miles. The second sign is brown and reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle. The third sign is a small sign that reads, Hiking to Half Dome? Don't forget your permit. The sign has the silhouette of a man with a backpack climbing up a dome with the aid of cables.

data.title: Swinging Bridge
data.listingDescription: Experience a view like none other while standing on the Swinging Bridge. Get a glimpse of Yosemite Falls and its reflection in the Merced River during the day or by full moon at night. The first thing you may notice about Swinging Bridge is that it does not swing. Multiple years of high flood waters took its toll on the previous swinging bridge, until it was finally replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after being damaged in the 1964 flood. Picnic tables and grills are co

images.altText: Visitors on the beach and in the water below a granite cliff with a dry waterfall
images.title: View from Swinging Bridge
images.caption: View of the Merced River and Yosemite Falls from Swinging Bridge in late summer

data.bodyText:
Picnic tables, grills, seasonal river access, and a walking/biking path are available at this scenic spot along the Merced River with views of Yosemite Falls and the surrounding cliffs. The adjacent beach offers access to the Merced River when water levels are low. Vault toilets are available in the area. Parking is extremely limited.

Despite its name, Swinging Bridge does not swing. Multiple floods repeatedly damaged the former swinging bridge, until it was replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after the 1964 flood.

The paved pathway connects to nearby points of interest and visitor services such as Cook's Meadow, Yosemite Chapel, Yosemite Valley Lodge, and Lower Yosemite Fall trail.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round.

Swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river is flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Diving or jumping from the bridge is prohibited at all times.

Yosemite Falls is a seasonal waterfall fed by snowmelt; it is usually completely dry by late summer then is sometimes revived again by late fall storms.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Swinging Bridge Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible vault toilets, and grills. The picnic area is unpaved but flat. The paths leading to both the picnic area and bridge can be reached by paved, mostly flat walkways. The beach is not wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
data.audioDescription: The Swinging Bridge Picnic Area has a small parking lot. A green recycle dumpster and brown trash dumpster are in the lot. A paved path leads from the parking area to the Swinging Bridge, a permanent wooden bridge with wood railing barriers on each side, crossing over the Merced River. A small yellow sign affixed to the wooden railing reads, diving or jumping from bridge prohibited. Beyond the bridge is a meadow that allows for open views of the 2,000-foot plus rock walls that line both sides of the Valley at this point. Along the paved path as you walk to the bridge, near the parking lot, a brown facility holds four separate vault toilets. On the right side of the path, a heavily shaded area has picnic tables and permanently placed grills, situated among the tall trees that grow in the area. The terrain slopes down a slight hill to the riverbank. A metal sign posted near the river reads, no ground fires, and shows an icon of a campfire, with a red diagonal line slashed through it. A sandy beach area is located across the river.

data.title: Tenaya Lake
data.listingDescription: Caught between immense granite domes and clear Sierra Nevada sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Because of its remarkable scenic qualities, its inviting blue water, and its proximity to Tioga Road, Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular destinations for summer visitors in Yosemite. It is quite popular for picnicking, swimming, and canoeing. Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, who was the last chief of the Yosemite Indians.

images.altText: Lake with granite cliffs at its edge
images.title: Tenaya Lake
images.caption: Tenaya Lake

data.bodyText:
Situated amidst granite domes and peaks, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular summer destinations for picnicking, swimming, and kayaking. There are several parking areas along the lake for beach access, picnic tables, and scenic views. Vault toilets are available at some parking areas.

Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, an American Indian tribal leader living in Yosemite Valley at the time of invasion by the Mariposa Battalion.

Non-motorized watercraft such as paddleboards, kayaks, and canoes are permitted on the lake. Every person must have a personal flotation device immediately available for each occupant of the watercraft. Children under age 13 must be wearing a personal flotation device.

Seasonal Information

Tenaya Lake is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

The east end of Tenaya Lake has designated accessible parking spaces, an accessible vault toilet, and an accessible, paved path that leads to open views of Tenaya Lake.
data.audioDescription: A large body of water is surrounded by granite domes and peaks. Granite bedrock leads into the lake along most of the shoreline. The east end of the lake has a sandy beach. Large clusters of tall trees surround the perimeter of the lake and partially lead up the granite slopes before thinning out at their peaks. A road follows the northern edge of the lake.

data.title: Tenaya Lake Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Enjoy this magnificent high-country lake surrounded by granite domes, lodgepole forests, and Yosemite's vast wilderness. Picnic tables are available at this pleasant spot near Tenaya Lake. Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations not accepted).

images.altText: A wood picnic table, tall trees, and a large lake visible in the distance
images.title: Tenaya Lake picnic area
images.caption: Tenaya Lake picnic area

data.bodyText:
Several picnic tables are available near the eastern beach of Tenaya Lake, a short, easy walk from the parking area.

Vault toilets and trash/recycling are available in the parking area. There are no facilities in the immediate area of the picnic area or the beach.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

This picnic area is located approximately 700 ft (215 m) from the parking area along mostly paved, wheelchair accessible paths. The final stretch is a short, flat unpaved section. Some picnic tables may only be reached by traveling over surfaces that may be uneven or sandy. The vault toilet at the parking area is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
data.audioDescription: On the east side of a large paved parking area are two wooden picnic tables, a food locker, a brown facility holding four vault toilets, and a wayside exhibit, placed among tall trees. In the east corner of the parking lot are two large brown trash dumpsters, and one large green dumpster for recycling. The wayside exhibit panel is blue and is bolted to a frame made of thick wooden posts, and is titled, welcome to Tenaya Lake. Half of the panel background is a two-toned picture of a lake that is surrounded by domes and peaks. The other half of the panel is a map. The caption reads, caught between immense granite domes and the clear High Sierra sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite National Park. Here, at its eastern end, Tenaya Creek forms a series of braided streams before flowing into the lake. Text reads, if you have a few hours, stroll the flat, paved trail (less than a quarter-mile, round-trip). You'll be rewarded with glimpses of the glacially carved peaks and domes and a spectacular view of the lake emerging through the trees. If time permits, take a picnic to one of the tables on the beach and enjoy a lazy High Sierra afternoon exploring or relaxing in the smooth granitic sand. While hardy souls may be tempted to jump in, remember...Tenaya Lake is fed by snowmelt and stays quite cold!If you have half a day, don't miss the boardwalk, a picnic, or the beach, but (if conditions permit) cross the Tenaya Creek inlet at the southeast end of the beach and follow the trail west along the shore of the lake. This mostly-level stroll takes you toward the Sunrise Lakes Trailhead, joining back with the Tioga Road. Here, you can retrace your steps back or hop on the free shuttle at Stop #10, and ride one stop back to your car (stop #9). It is possible to walk all the way around the lake (2.8 mi/5.2 km), but requires walking along the shoulder of busy Tioga Road. A full-day hike to Tuolumne Meadows - Pick up a trail heading east from Tenaya Lake. This 9-mile one-way hike parallels the Tioga Road, leading to Tuolumne Meadows. At Tuolumne Meadows, pick up the free shuttle for the short ride back to Tenaya Lake. Shuttle Information - The free Tioga Road shuttle runs between Tuolumne Meadows and Olmsted Point. Shuttle schedule changes seasonally and as conditions permit. Check local postings for current schedule. During times of high water, unbridged river or creek crossings can be hazardous. Take extra time and use good judgement when crossing rivers and creeks. Check the weather! Be especially aware of the potential for thunderstorms. If you are hiking, take a map and compass. Tell someone where you are going and when you'll be back. Avoid exhaustion and dehydration. Carry plenty of water and high-energy snacks. The altitude at Tenaya Lake is just over 8,000 feet above sea level. Signs of altitude sickness can include nausea, dizziness, and headache. Descending to a lower elevation can help alleviate symptoms. Scrambling or climbing on rocks can be dangerous. Remember, coming down can be much harder than going up, and wet rocks are slippery. Be prepared to pack out what you pack in; garbage and recycling receptacles are located near the parking area. Map: The map shows Tenaya Lake, indicated by a large, blue, oval shape, slightly tilted, in the center of the map. A white line extends diagonally across the map, from the bottom left to the top right, passing by the north shore of Tenaya Lake. A trail, indicated by red dotted lines, passes by the south shore of the Tenaya Lake and partly follows a few creeks, indicated by a blue solid line, before splitting off into different trails to the left and right. To the left of the lake, icons indicate the start of hiking trails, restrooms, and parking. To the right of the lake, a red dot indicates you are here, and icons indicating trailheads, parking, restrooms, and picnic areas are shown. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. A flat dirt path leads into the forest with several wayside exhibits along the way to the Tenaya Lake shoreline. The first wayside exhibit is titled, disappearing wetlands. Text reads, wetlands like this one have likely been here for the last 10,000 years, providing homes and food for a great variety of plant and animal species. In Yosemite, wetland areas make up only about 3% of the landscape, but are estimated to harbor up to one-third of all the plant species in the Park. They also capture, store, and release melting snow, extending the availability of life-giving water during the dry summer months. Here in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and across the globe, wetlands are disappearing rapidly. Effects from trampling, development, and climate change threaten to alter the delicate wetland ecology forever. In Yosemite National Park, park managers work to prevent loss of wetlands by preserving and restoring wetland areas and building boardwalks to help minimize damage from visitors. Photo:

data.title: The Ahwahnee
data.listingDescription: Known for its stunning interior design and architecture, The Ahwahnee was specifically designed to highlight its natural surroundings, featuring Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Glacier Point.The hotel holds a historic heritage as it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is a National Historic Landmark. The destination of queens and presidents alike, this dis

images.altText: A sheer cliff face serves as a backdrop behind a building made of stone and wooden planks.
images.title: The Ahwahnee
images.caption: The Ahwahnee at dusk.

data.bodyText:
Known for its stunning interior design and architecture that combines rustic and art deco influences, The Ahwahnee offers hotel rooms, suites, parlors, and cottages. Designed by architect Gilbert Stanley Underwood and completed in 1927, The Ahwahnee was built to draw more affluent visitors to Yosemite National Park. An experiment in construction methods, it was built with mostly fireproof materials, including concrete and granite textured and stained to resemble redwood.

See website for more information about the rooms and to make a reservation.

Parking at The Ahwahnee is currently valet only and requires a fee. Visitors who do not wish to use valet parking may reach the hotel via shuttle stop 3 or by walking or biking.

Operating Hours & Seasons

The Ahwahnee is open year-round. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

Dining & Shopping

The Ahwahnee Dining Room. Fine dining serving breakfast, lunch, dinner, and Sunday brunch. Indoor seating only. Appropriate attire required for dinner. Dinner reservations strongly recommended: 209/372-1489 or OpenTable.com.

The Ahwahnee Bar. Table service, indoor and outdoor seating. Beer on tap, cocktails, and light dining for lunch and dinner.

Coffee Bar. Serving tea, espresso drinks, and brewed coffee. Order at The Ahwahnee Bar.

Sweet Shop. Snacks, sweets, wine.

Gift Shop. Gifts, Native American pottery, jewelry, clothing, books.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for dining and shopping hours.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select rooms and cottages are wheelchair accessible. Valet parking is available, and designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot. A wheelchair accessible path of travel connects the hotel with the cabins.
data.audioDescription: The Ahwahnee is a 5-plus story building with wooden plank siding and cobblestone columns. Turquoise shutters are on each side of all windows, and several cobblestone chimneys stand atop its roof. Tables with green umbrellas line the patio behind the building. The granite landscape rises up behind the building.

data.title: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located at the southwestern end of The Ahwahnee parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features six level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector. You do not need to be a guest at The Ahwahnee to charge your vehicle, however, you must move your vehicle from the space once it is finished charging.

images.altText: A vehicle plugged into a charging station in a parking area with a large hotel in the background
images.title: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station
images.caption: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located at the southwestern end of The Ahwahnee parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features six level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector. You do not need to be a guest at The Ahwahnee to charge your vehicle, however, you must move your vehicle from the space once it is finished charging.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the southernmost row of parking near the main hotel building, just west of the hotel, there are six standard-sized parking stalls in front of three electric vehicle charging stations. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. The stations are located just behind the curb of the parking lot. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." Behind the charging stations there is a dirt area with a few trees, boulders, and low-lying vegetation.

data.title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
data.listingDescription: Visit The Ansel Adams Gallery to explore the works of Ansel Adams, contemporary artists, or to sign up for half-day photography classes, workshops , or camera walks. From its origin in 1902 in a tent in the California Wilderness, Best's Studio, now operating as The Ansel Adams Gallery, has evolved into a center that celebrates the arts and grandeur of our environment.

images.altText: A single story building with a large covered porch and log details extending at its corners
images.title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
images.caption: The Ansel Adams Gallery

data.bodyText:
Experience a variety of fine arts, books, art supplies, handcrafts, and an outstanding collection of Ansel Adams’ original photographs. Originally known as Best's Studio, this family-owned business has operated in Yosemite Valley since 1902.

The Ansel Adams Gallery offers a variety of both free and paid photography education programs. Learn more and register at the gallery or on the website.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open daily year-round. See the Yosemite Guide or gallery website for current hours.
Closed Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.

Accessibility

The gallery's main floor is accessible by ramp at the front. The upper level is accessible by an outside path (with a short slope of 8 percent) or by steps inside.
data.audioDescription: The Ansel Adams Gallery is a one-story, light grey building with wooden shingled siding. A covered porch, supported by large beams and posts extends around half the building. Large picture windows showcase the the items inside. Wooden signs cross the top of the entire porch. One sign reads: art, photographs, handcrafts, since 1902, while another reads film processing, gifts, postcards, books, and another reads quality designs, postcards, handcrafts, film, indian arts, posters. Two wooden signs dangle off a large porch beam by chains, and both read The Ansel Adams Gallery. Potted plants line the porch as well as wooden benches. Two sets of steps access the raised porch as well as a ramp on the side of the building.

data.title: The Cascades Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: During the spring, torrents of water from melted snow thunder over a precipice to form The Cascades waterfall. Bring a picnic and enjoy it while listening to the water of The Cascades and the Merced River.Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall and along the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :Located on El Portal Road (Highway 140), between the Arch Rock Entrance and Yosemite Valley. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas

images.altText: A picnic table and grill in a dirt area surrounded by trees
images.title: The Cascades Picnic Area
images.caption: The Cascades Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
About 10 minutes away from Yosemite Valley by car, picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall, Cascade Creek, and the Merced River. Mature canyon live oaks and ponderosa pines provide shade across the picnic area.
