The Cascades waterfall, situated just across the road, is a lesser-visited waterfall that is stunning in spring as winter's snow melts into the creek.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round. A vault toilet is available at the parking area.

Swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river and creeks are flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Cascades Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available nearby. The pathway to the picnic area is on a slight incline and unpaved. The path may be uneven or slightly rocky in places.
data.audioDescription: The paved parking area has a brown wooden structure that holds two vault toilets, a green recycling dumpster, and a brown trash dumpster. A brown, metal sign with a white icon of a picnic table also stands near the parking lot. The sign reads no camping or overnight parking. A path leads to a flat area, dense with tree cover, that has picnic tables and grills spread throughout. The river flows nearby. On the other side of the river, tall rock walls rise above the tree line. Across the street is a waterfall viewing area with a few wayside exhibits.

data.title: Tioga Pass Entrance
data.listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

images.altText: Small wooden building with a car at the window
images.title: Tioga Pass Entrance Station
images.caption: Tioga Pass Entrance Station

data.bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! The Tioga Pass entrance is a fee station located on Tioga Road, the continuation of Highway 120 from the east. Situated at 9,945 feet (3,031 m) above sea level, Tioga Pass is located along the crest of the Sierra Nevada mountains.

Visitors can pay the park entrance fee, show their parks pass, or purchase a pass as they enter the park. Park brochures may be available. Entrance stations at Yosemite do not accept cash. Learn more about entrance fees and passes. 

Seasonal Information

Tioga Road is closed seasonally from approximately November through May or June. Check road status or call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

When Tioga Road is closed, it is not possible to drive to Tuolumne Meadows or enter Yosemite National Park from the east. All other park entrances, including those accessed via Highway 120 from the west, Hetch Hetchy, Highway 140, and Highway 41, remain open all year.

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
data.audioDescription: One inbound lane and one outbound lane are on each side of a small wooden kiosk at the Tioga Pass Entrance. The National Park Service logo is placed below the front window on the kiosk. The logo consists of a downward pointing arrowhead, a sequoia tree, a mountain range, a lake, a bison, and text that reads National Park Service. A small triangular sign bolted on to the side of the kiosk, below a service window reads, U.S. Fee Area and has the National Park Service logo. Another sign, posted on the front side of the kiosk reads Tioga Pass, Elevation 9,945 feet. On the right side of the incoming lane, a tall cobblestone pedestal holds a wooden sign that reads Yosemite National Park. A flag pole waving the American Flag is located in front of a cobblestoned building just beyond the entrance sign, along with a bronze plaque that reads, this tablet commemorates the successful labors of Stephen T. Mather, Director of the National Park Service, in securing for the people the Tioga Pass Road, dedicated to the enduring memory of a faithful public servant by members of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle National Park Development Tour, July 20, 1924. On the southside of the road, small lakes, open meadows, and forests stand at the bottom of a few peaks.

data.title: Tioga Road - Cones and Needles Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands beneath a tall tree.

data.bodyText: Have you ever wondered how to tell a fir from a pine? Or why you don't really see rattle snakes or giant sequoias at 9,000 feet elevation? Learn more about red firs and Yosemite's life zones and micro-climate at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This paved roadside turnout is on the west side of Tioga Road and has five wayside exhibits. The area is surrounded by different pine and fir trees and has an open view looking westward.

The first wayside exhibit is titled, Cones and Needles. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, Because of its wide range of elevations, Yosemite encompasses several life zones determined by elevation, moisture, temperature, and exposure to storms. Sometimes, conditions vary significantly within a zone and allow for a micro-climate, a place where the climate contrasts with that of the entire zone. You are in one such micro-climate. Around you, trees that typically grow at higher or lower elevations live in close proximity. Stroll around this area and discover stories of four common Yosemite trees, their relationships with wildlife, and struggles to survive. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, cache crop - ever forget where you left your keys? Chipmunks, ground squirrels, and many birds have the same problem. They bury small caches of seeds here and there, and then forget where they put many of these food caches. Consequently, forgetful birds and animals planted many of the trees nearby. 

A series of four photos show different types of trees. 

Photo one is a Red Fir forest, shown with their long branches drooping from the weight of snow that covers them. The trees are tall with pointed tips and reddish bark. 

Photo two is a single Lodgepole Pine, which has a conical shape that tapers, and grey bark. 

Photo three is a single Jeffrey Pine, which has several large branches shooting off a rather bare trunk. Smaller secondary pine branches shoot off the large primary branches. There is no conical shape to this tree, it is randomly fanned out in all directions. 

Photo four is a single Western White Pine, which is a tall, very narrow, slender conical shape, with branches that are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers.

The second wayside exhibit is titled, Red Fir, abies magnifica, and has a close-up photo of Red Fir bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is reddis-brown and has deep striations. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the red fir is a spectacular tree, impressive for its height and girth. It can sometimes rise above 200 feet tall, and be nearly 10 feet in diameter. The bark of mature trees is deeply furrowed with a distinctive reddish hue. 

Illustration: A brown pine branch shows green needles that are rounded off at the ends, growing directly out of the branch. A rounded pine cone, which has layers upon layers that closely overlap each other, appears to be closed and smooth. Cone size is 9 inches (23 cm).

Caption: Tree ID hint - How can you tell a fir from a pine? Think "F" for friendly fir. The needles of a fir are soft, and they grow from the branch instead of in bunches. 

When Lightning Strikes - Lightning often hits the tallest of these red firs, leaving snag-topped crowns. These damaged areas provide fertile foraging areas for woodpeckers and sapsuckers looking for grubs. The snags also provide homes for nesting owls and squirrels. 

Illustration: A speckled owl with horn-like pointy ears sits on a snaggled tree trunk that seems to have snapped apart.

The third wayside exhibit is titled, Western White Pine, pinus monticola, and has a close-up photo of Western White Pine bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is brown and looks like square plates or bricks that are stacked vertically. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, look beyond the red fir log in front of you. The tree with square-like plates on its bark is the Western White Pine. Their trunks are usually straight, and typically their branches are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers. They cannot tolerate deep shade and generally grow in open spaces where they can soak up the rays of the sun. The Western White Pine is a hardy tree, thriving under conditions produced by ground fires that create the ide

data.title: Tioga Road - Disappearing Meadows Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A stream snakes through a meadow. Pebbles, rocks, and boulders line the bottom and outskirts of the shallow stream. Two mountain peaks rise up above treeline.

data.bodyText: How and why do we seem to be losing our meadows to trees? Is that a good thing? And, are you in the midst of an ancient volcanic mountain range? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
A small, paved, roadside turnout on the south side of Tioga Road has an open view of the area's iconic peaks through meadows with flowing streams. There are also two wayside exhibits and three portable restrooms, one of which is designated accessible. 

On the west side of the driveway, an open meadow that has large boulders scattered about, transitions into a dense pine forest. A wayside exhibit titled, Disappearing Meadow, sits at the edge of the meadow and paved driveway. Text on the left side of the panel reads, as recently as the 1960s, this area was an open wet meadow that dominated the foreground in this view of the Cathedral Range Mountains. However, the meadows are beginning to dry up, providing better conditions for trees to grow. Current science is documenting the increase in Earth's temperature which is advantageous for trees due to longer, warmer growing seasons. While scientists are still investigating other possible reasons for the changes you see, climate change is likely a primary factor. 

Photo: An open meadow has small saplings growing throughout it. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a line of mature, tall trees. 

Caption: 1963 view of Cathedral Range from this meadow. 

Photo: A small grassy area has a dense stand of pine trees.

Caption: In 2009, young trees dominate the same view. 

Black and white photo: a man, dressed in a long sleeved shirt, long pants, and cap, stands among hundreds of sheep bunched together in a meadow, with tall trees surrounding the open pasture.

Caption: In the late 1800s, cattle ranchers and sheep herders drove their herds into these lush grassy meadows to graze. Human occupation and use increased to accommodate the silver mines established in the Tioga area during the 1870s. These human impacts to vegetation and hydrology may accentuate the effects of climate change. 

On the east side of the driveway, a stream snakes through an open meadow that also transitions into a dense forest. A reddish peak rises on the left while a grey, granite peak rises to the right. A wooden sign by the stream reads, domestic water supply - do not contaminate. A wayside exhibit is also stationed here titled, The Core of Volcanoes. Text on the left side of the panel reads, rising before you are two of the highest peaks in Yosemite, Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs. Their reddish-brown color hints at a different origin than the white granites of the other mountains in the park. The metamorphic rocks forming the summit areas of Mounts Dana and Gibbs are the exposed core of an ancient volcanic mountain range that once graced the Pacific coast. Once miles beneath tall volcanoes, they were slowly revealed as erosion stripped away the overlying rocks. 

Photo: Two peaks rise above a treeline. The silhouette of the two mountain peaks that are labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, is outlined with a red dotted line.

Illustration: The cross-section illustration of the inner and outer workings of a volcano are shown, below and above ground. In the ground, a layer of reddish-orange, oval-like chambers of magma lay horizontally, overlapping and connecting to each other. Thick vein-like paths of magma extend upward through a layer of earth, connecting with the layer of oval chambers above. A small portion of the upper part of the reddish-orange oval chambers is white and is labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, and is noted as crystallizing granite. Above the chambers is a brown area, labeled as metamorphic rock, that slopes up into a peak. A red, thin, vein-like line leads from the magma chambers to the peak and exits as a plume of smoke. Other peaks are in the background.

Caption: Magma, or lava, that erupted at the surface created the reddish-brown metamorphic rock of the volcanoes core. Magma that cooled deep beneath the surface crystalized and formed the white granite of the other peaks and domes you see here.

data.title: Tioga Road - Form Follows Fracture Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands at a scenic roadside pullout that overlooks the high country landscape.

data.bodyText: As you drive along the Tioga Road you may notice the granite bedrock is riddled with fractures. You may even see trees taking root in the granite bedrock! How is that possible? Learn more about it at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives an open view looking west. The granite bedrock extends for miles, with boulders strewn about, and trees growing out of fractures in the rock. A wayside exhibit titled, Form Follows Fracture, is near the parking area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the granite bedrock of the Sierra Nevada is riddled with fractures. Major fracture zones dictate where water flows and thus where trees and plants grow. Water in the cracks decomposes the rock and forms soil, creating the conditions for life to grow in this harsh environment. 

Two photos: One photo shows a large mature tree growing out of a granite slab. The second photo shows a one-foot tall sapling growing out of a granite fracture.

Caption: Only the hardiest vegetation is able to grow in this rocky terrain. The Jeffrey pine to your left has two roots growing straight out on either side like a gymnast stretched along a balance beam. 

Photo: An aerial view of a portion of the surrounding terrain, framed in a square, show a squiggly grey line across the top of the square from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." The rest of the square is covered with tree canopies, that look like splotchy dark spots, and a web of lines that crisscross each other. A heavy diagonal line that extends downward and slightly to the left from the red dot is labeled Yosemite Creek. 

Caption: This aerial view of the Yosemite Creek drainage shows that the granite is fractured into a network of cracks, or joints, trending in relatively straight lines. These joints result from tectonic stresses associated with uplift of the Sierra Nevada. Linear joints such as these dictate where the major streams flow, and also control the general shape of the landscape.

data.title: Tioga Road - Glacial Moraine Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands next to a small hillside scattered with different sized boulders.

data.bodyText: Get a personal glimpse of a glacial moraine and learn how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons, at this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives a view of a hill strewn with many different-sized granite boulders, on both sides of the Tioga Road. A wayside exhibit titled, Glacial Moraine, is near the turnout area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, The hill in front of you is a clue to how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons. Look over your left shoulder, where the road cuts through the hill. Unlike water-deposited debris, which is layered and sorted by size, this hill is made up of a jumbled mix of sand, gravel, and boulders. Geologists call this deposit a glacial moraine. Material eroded and transported by the Snow Creek Glacier was left here as the glacier receded. Imagine the power it took to move this much earth. 

Photo: A hill along a roadside is covered with many different-sized granite boulders. A red dotted line outlines the entire hill. Many trees grow out from the top of the hill. 

Caption: Where the road cuts through the moraine, you can see the debris left behind by the glacier. 

Illustration: An ice-covered mountainous terrain is shown in a square frame. A few of the peaks popping up over the icefield are Mount Conness in the upper left corner, Mount Dana in the upper right corner, Mount Hoffman, which is midway down and left of center, and Cathedral Peak, which is one-third of the way down and right of center. The majority of the terrain is white, representing the Tuolumne Ice Field, which travels downward and splits into the Tenaya Glacier on the right and the Snow Creek Glacier on the left. Just to the left of the Snow Creek Glacier, near the bottom of the illustration, a red dot indicates, 'you are under here,' and a dotted line represents Tioga Road. 

Caption: Twenty thousand years ago a vast ice sheet covered most of the Tuolumne Meadows area. This ice sheet fed glaciers that flowed east toward Mono Lake, west toward Hetch Hetchy, and southwest toward Yosemite Valley. One of these glaciers, the Snow Creek Glacier, left behind the moraine you see here.

data.title: Tioga Road - High Sierra Stories Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A meadow surrounds a small lake. A few mountain peaks rise up above the nearby treeline.

data.bodyText: How do plants and animals survive at the highest elevations in the park? And, how did people travel in this area from hundreds of years ago to today? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This paved parking area allows open views of the high country. A large, open meadow surrounds the parking area. A pond reflects the reddish-brown mountains that are Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, which rise up over the treeline to the left. To the right, grey granite peaks rise over the treeline in the distance. Large granite boulders are scattered here and there across the flat, open meadow. In the parking lot, a brown sign with a white outline and text reads, no camping or overnight parking. 

The meadow area is roped off from the parking area and two small signs are bolted to knee-height wooden posts. The first sign reads, give plants a chance! Please stay off. An illustration of a foot hovering over small plants is inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through its center. The second sign reads, area closed - restoration in progress, Yosemite National Park, and has a silhouette of Half Dome.

Three wayside exhibits line the curb of the parking lot. The first wayside exhibit, located to the far right of the parking area, is titled, Alpine Zone, and has a faint background photo of a large, smooth, granite peak. Text on the left side of the panel reads, you are now near the alpine zone, which includes the highest elevations in Yosemite. Look a few hundred feet higher, and you can see that trees cannot grow because the rugged terrain is windy, dry, and intensely sunlit. To survive such harsh conditions, plants here lie flat against the ground or crouch between stones. Special pigments in their leaves filter out harmful rays of sunlight. Some plants grow in little pincushion-like bunches. If they stand too tall the wind will dry them out or tear them apart. Their vibrant blossoms burst forth in an extra effort to attract insects. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the far right of the road is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Two photos show two different kinds of wild flowers. The first wildflower is called Davidson's penstemon and is light purple. They are growing in a bunch, out of a crack in a granite rock and are short in stature. Their small flowers are a bit long and flute-like, curving outward at the ends. The second photo shows a wildflower called Sky Pilot, which is purple, and has a spherical bulb of multiple flowers that shoot out of an erect stem. They are growing in a bunch in a rocky area. 

Text on the right side of the panel reads, pikas need to get out of the sun periodically to cool down or they risk lethal overheating. These small mammals live in rock piles at high elevations. They gather plants for winter food in nearby areas, frequently returning to the shade of the rocks. As Earth's temperature warms, they will have to spend more time in the rock piles cooling down. If they have to spend too much time cooling down, they won't be able to harvest enough food to survive the winter. 

Photo: In the bottom right corner, a small, greyish-brown, furry pika faces left and is leaning forward on a rock. It has black beady eyes, large round ears, and long whiskers. 

The second wayside exhibit, located near the middle of the parking area, is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick.

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads

data.title: Tioga Road - Meadow Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a roadside pullout.

data.bodyText: Learn more about the old Mono Trail, a part of a network for American Indian Trade, about the importance of Yosemite's and the Sierra Nevada snow pack, and the history of the Tioga Road, from these wayside exhibits.
data.audioDescription:
This arched driveway on the south side of Tioga Road has limited, undefined, parking. A green recycle dumpster and brown trash dumpster are located at the east end of the parking area. Trees surround the lot.

Two wayside exhibits stand side by side on the north side of the parking area. The right wayside exhibit is titled Mutual Survival, and has a background photo of a map of central California. Three recognizable areas are labeled, Lake Tahoe, at the top, middle of the panel, San Francisco Bay Area at the left, middle of the panel, and Mono Lake, toward the right middle of the panel. Two large, faint arrows are positioned in a circular way, signifying a counter-clockwise rotation, on the right side of the panel. In the midst of the circular arrows is a map of Yosemite National Park. Panel text reads, Mutual Survival - the Tioga Road follows roughly the same route as the old Mono Trail. This old trail formed the basis of a network for American Indian trade routes leading from the sea to the desert. People on either side of the mountains used this route to negotiate and trade for food items and other materials important to their daily lives. 
Photo Near the San Francisco Bay Area: A string of beads lay on a pink stone, in the sand, next to a seashell.

Caption: Trades from the west bartered with shells and jewelry. 

Photo in the middle of the Central California map: Many acorns are piled up in a basket, and a heap of long sedges is bundled together, laying on its side.

Caption: People in the mountain valleys traded acorns and basket-making materials.

Photo to the upper right of Yosemite National Park: A zoomed-in photo of white granules of salt, and little shrimp swimming bunched together in water. 

Caption: Salt and alkali fly pupa were trade items from the Mono Lake area. 

Illustration to the right of Yosemite National Park and Mono Lake: A black rock with shiny, white edges is shown. 

Caption: Obsidian to make spear and arrow points, knives, and scrapers came from the east. 

The left wayside exhibit is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick. 

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest. 

Caption: By the 1890s, horse-drawn wagons followed Indian migration routes. 

Photo: two women stand on a dirt road, next to a soft-top automobile that has two spare tires attached to the rear. 

Caption: Travelers needed spare tires and plenty of gas in the 1920s. 

Photo: Two vintage cars drive side-by-side, taking up the width of the narrow dirt road, while an oncoming car approaches. A large boulder and plenty of trees are right along the roadside. 

Caption: Motorists in the 1940s traveled slowly, navigating a narrow and treacherous dirt road. 

Photo: A bicyclist wearing a helmet rides on a paved road with snowcapped mountains in the background. 

Caption: In 2009, cyclists enjoy a high country biking experience. 

Photo: An older man with a white beard and mustache, a white long-sleeved shirt and black vest, long pants, and a hat, sits horseback, facing to the left. Caption: "...I have crossed the Range of Light, surely the brightest and best of all the Lord has build; and rejoicing in its glory. I gladly, gratefully, hopefully pray I may see it again." - John Muir

The third wayside exhibit is facing the small meadow on the south side of the parking area and is titled, Shrinking Reservoir. The exhibit panel's background photo shows a snow-covered mountain range in the background, and a few building and utility poles on flat terrain in the foreground. Panel text reads, Shrinking Reservoir - The Sierra Nevada is California's reservoir - nature's storage tank of water in the form of winter snow and ice. As the snow gradually melts, it releases the stored water into streams and rivers. The depth of the annual snow pack indicates how much water we will have each year for necessities like drinking water and crop irrigation. In a changing climate, more moisture may come as rain instead of snow. How will it

data.title: Tioga Road - Surviving the Crossing Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands near a roadside pullout.

data.bodyText: Who were the first non-Indians to pass through this area, and how did they survive? Learn more from this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
A small roadside turnout along the south side of Tioga Road allows for scenic views across the street. A clearing in the trees opens up to panoramic views of rolling hills, looking northward. A wayside exhibit titled, Surviving the Crossing, is on the north side of the parking lot.

The background illustration of the panel shows two men manuevering through a dense forest on horseback. Text reads, in 1833, in a trip that took more than two weeks, Joseph R. Walker led a party of mountain men along a ridge near here. They were the first non-Indians to pass through this area as they crossed the Sierra Nevada. Near starvation they finally found an Indian trail that eventually led them to safety, but not before 24 of their horses succumbed - most of which they had to eat for their own survival. 

Quote: We were then obliged to keep along the top of the dividing ridge between two of these chasms which seemed to lead pretty near in the direction we were going...

...A small deer was the first we had eat since our dried meat was exhausted, during which time we lived on stale and forbidden horse flesh...

-Zenas Leonard, Walker Party

data.title: Tunnel View
data.listingDescription: The iconic Tunnel View overlook has captured the awe of visitors for more than 75 years. Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing the immensity of the granite walls that surround Yosemite Valley and providing a classic view of El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm. Wawona Tunnel The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 19

images.altText: Large granite monoliths in the distance with a dense conifer forest below
images.title: Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View

data.bodyText:
Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm.

The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 1931, and opened to public travel on June 18, 1933. It took about 230 tons of dynamite to bore through solid granite to create this nearly mile-long tunnel. The construction of the Wawona Tunnel is considered significant in its design within the National Park System and the National Register of Historic Places.

Seasonal Information

Tunnel View is reachable by vehicle year-round.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The viewpoint can be seen from the parking area or via a short, paved walk to the pedestrian viewing area. There is a bronze tactile model of Yosemite Valley near the overlook.
data.audioDescription:
Tunnel View is located on Highway 41, a few miles from Bridalveil Fall. Tunnel View showcases the scenery of Yosemite Valley, with El Capitan to the left of the valley and Bridalveil Fall to the right.

Two wayside exhibits and a bronze relief textile model are located here.

Both wayside exhibits are located to the northeast side of the parking area

Wayside Exhibit Number one:
Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from Valley View. From left to right, the following natural features are labeled, El Capitan, Horsetail Fall, Clouds Rest, which is the furthest peak, in the middle of the photo, then Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, the Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: A Varied View
Text to the right of the header reads:
Whether spring or fall, morning or afternoon, one has the opportunity to experience an ever changing view. In summer, clouds glide amidst granite peaks. Fall splashes autumn hues upon maple and oak trees across the Valley floor. Winter brings snow, accenting the subtle details of granite walls, while spring breathes life back into ephemeral waterfalls and renews the echo of rushing water throughout the Valley.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: Ever-changing Scene
Text reads: In Yosemite, you may never witness the same scene twice.
A quote in italics text reads: This grand show is eternal. It is always sunrise somewhere; the dew is never all dried at once; a shower is forever falling; vapor ever rising. Eternal sunrise, eternal sunset, eternal dawn and gloaming, on seas and continents and islands, each in its turn, as the round earth rolls. - John Muir

Two small black and white photos are located side by side, at the bottom of the panel.

Left photo: A close-up photo of Horsetail Fall shows sparse water, glistening by the sun, falling off the rockface of El Capitan.

Left Photo Caption: Only in spring can you see Horsetail Fall leaping from the east end of El Capitan.

Right photo: A close-up photo of Silver Strand Fall shows sparse water, streaming down in a thin veil to its base.

Right Photo Caption: Also an ephemeral fall, Silver Strand can be found in spring to the southeast of this viewing area.

Wayside Exhibit Number 2:
Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from above Valley View, in the trees. Iconic natural features like El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, and the Cathedral Rocks are shown.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: A View Through Time
Text to the right of the header reads:
From this breathtaking viewpoint into Yosemite Valley, you can see three of its remarkable features: El Capitan, Half Dome, and Bridalveil Fall. In March 1851, a local militia (known as the Mariposa Battalion) was dispatched to the area in search of Miwok people suspected of attacking a trading post. The group stumbled upon this view and became the first Euro-Americans to enter Yosemite Valley.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: A Burning Tradition
Text reads: Miwok people, who called themselves Ahwahneechee, lived in Yosemite Valley for thousands of years. Their traditional practice of regularly burning the meadows and oak woodlands of the Valley contributed to the open landscape first seen by the Mariposa Battalion.

Quote, The whole valley had the appearance of park-like grounds, with trees, shrubbery, flowers and lawns, end-quote. - Lafayette Bunnell, 1880

Two black and white photos are located side by side, at the bottom of the panel.

Left photo: A black and white portrait photo shows an older caucasian man with a beard and long mustache. He is wearing a suit jacket over a white collared shirt with a black neck tab.

Left Photo Caption: Lafayette Bunnell, a member of the Mariposa Battalion, gave names to many of the Valley's prominent rock formations. He later wrote a book about his first impressions of Yosemite Valley.

Right illustration: A pencil drawing of Yosemite Valley shows El Capitan on the left and Bridalveil Fall on the right. In the foreground is a line of tree silhouettes that stretch from the left to the right of the picture.

Right Photo Caption: In this 1855 drawing, Valley from Artist's Point, Thomas Ayres captured the open, park-like nature of Yosemite Valley as it looked in the mid-19th century.

A bronze tactile relief model of Yosemite Valley is located nearby.

data.title: Tuolumne Grove
data.listingDescription: Marvel at nearly two dozen mature giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias.Begin at Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the Old Big Oak Flat Road-one of the first roads into Yosemite Valley-steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Within the Tuolumne Grove there is an easy, half-

images.altText: Two very large trees behind a wood fence surrounded by vegetation showing fall colors
images.title: Tuolumne Grove
images.caption: Giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove

data.bodyText:
The Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias is home to about two dozen mature giant sequoias. Begin at the Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the former Big Oak Flat Road (now closed to all vehicles) steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Once hikers reach the Tuolumne Grove, there is an easy, half-mile, self-guided nature trail. Parking at the trailhead is limited.

Distance: 2.5 miles (4 km) round trip
Elevation gain: 500-foot (152 m) elevation gain on return trip
Time estimate: 1-2 hours round trip

Tips

  • Bicycles are not allowed on this trail.
  • Pets are allowed on the paved trail through the grove, but not on the side trails in the grove.
  • Pit toilets are available at the trailhead parking area. There are no restrooms or water available in the grove.

Seasonal Information

The grove is open year round. Expect snowy and icy conditions in winter.

In winter, ski or snowshoe touring in Yosemite can be a magnificent experience! The Tuolumne Grove trail descends 500 feet from the trailhead to the giant sequoias. This is a popular trail both with snowshoers and hikers and is a strenuous uphill return ski.

Accessibility

This trail is not wheelchair accessible.
data.audioDescription:
A large, paved, parking area is next to a main road and is surrounded by forest. A green recycle dumpster, brown trash dumpster, and a brown facility, which holds four vault toilets, all line the parking lot. Picnic tables, large tree stump seating, and a wayside exhibit panel, framed in log posts, are at the grove trailhead on the north side of the lot, where the paved road trail then leads into the forest.

The green-toned exhibit panel is titled, Welcome to the Tuolumne Grove, and has an illustrated map, which takes up the left side of the panel. The map shows a red dot toward the middle of the map, which is labeled, you are here. A yellow squiggle line, representing the trail, makes its way through a faint canopy of trees upward from the red dot to the sequoia grove. A trail also travels downward from the red dot, leading nowhere specific, and eventually fades out. An aerial view of about 8 bold tree tops are shown at the end of the trail, as well as a tree trunk that has a tunnel through it.

Black and white photo: A sequoia tree trunk, with the upper half of the tree gone, has a tunnel carved out of it.

Caption: The temptation when visiting the Tuolumne Grove is to turn your eyes to the sky line, accessing the superlative qualities of these massive giants. Take a moment along your trip to reflect on the things that can go by unnoticed - the deep silence that accompanies each snow-muffled winter, the moment each spring when the tiny winter wren begins building her nest, the emergence of the white Pacific dogwood petals.

Think also of moments in this grove's recent human history, the jangle of bridles from the first pioneers, pilgrims and discoverers who passed this way, or the rumble of the first automobile engine after the new road was cut. The passage of time through the Tuolumne Grove is marked in small ways, with your experience here being just the most recent.

Map: A generalized map of the entire park, labeled Yosemite National Park, shows the three areas to find sequoia groves in the park. They are indicated by a sequoia tree icon. The Tuolumne Grove and Merced Grove are side by side and located on the left side of the map, about half-way down from the top. The Mariposa Grove is located at the bottom tip of the map.

Text on the right side of the panel reads, one of the three giant sequoia grove in Yosemite National Park, the Tuolumne Grove contains about 25 mature trees. While enjoying your walk through the grove, consider the rarity of this experience. These few maturing giant sequoias appear large and strong but are facing an unknown future. Climate change-and the resulting changes in hydrology and fire regime-may have an effect on the future of giant sequoias. Avoid walking in areas immediately surrounding the trees. Leave cones and other natural items in the grove.

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows
data.listingDescription: Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering quietly through its meadow channel against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes. Tuolumne Meadows embodies the high-country of the Sierra Nevada, with its broad sub-alpine meadows and granite domes and peaks.

images.altText: View of alpine meadow and river in Tuolumne Meadows
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows

data.bodyText:
Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes. The meadows are surrounded by stands of western white pine, mountain hemlock, and lodgepole pine. Belding's ground squirrels, mule deer, and yellow-bellied marmots are frequently seen in the meadows along with many other species of wildlife.

Experience views of Tuolumne Meadows with a short, easy walk toward Parsons Lodge. For a longer, more challenging hike through the meadow system, consider hiking toward Glen Aulin.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Tuolumne Meadows is only reachable by vehicle only while Tioga Road is open, typically from late May or early June to October or November.

Stay on official trails to protect fragile meadow ecosystems! Dogs, bicycles, and strollers are not allowed anywhere in the meadow or on hiking trails.

Accessibility

Trails toward Parsons Lodge and Soda Springs are mostly wide with gravel surfaces that may be accessible to some mobility aid users. From Parsons Lodge parking, the trail toward the lodge reaches a bridge over the Tuolumne River with several stone steps on either end of the bridge.
data.audioDescription: A large open meadow, Tuolumne Meadows, is surrounded by forest and granite peaks and domes. In the summer, the grasses are a vibrant green, speckled with multi-colored wildflowers. The sparkling waters of a narrow river, the Tuolumne River, snakes through the center of the meadow. Dirt trails are laid out throughout the area, leading to wilderness areas. A paved road, Tioga Road, lines the southern edge of the meadow. The summer months bring clear sunny days and overcast days with thick, dark, billowy, thunderhead clouds.

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located in a park lot just west of the Tuolumne Meadows Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

images.altText: Two electric vehicle charging stations on the edge of a paved parking lot
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows EV Charging Station
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located in a parking lot just west of the Tuolumne Meadows Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the back row of this small parking lot, there are four standard-sized parking stalls in front of two electric vehicle charging stations. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." The sign also displays the brand logos for Rivian, National Park Service, and Yosemite Conservancy. Directly behind the parking lot and the charging stations is a mixed conifer forest and boulders as well as three metal utility boxes a few feet behind the paved area.

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows Grill
data.listingDescription: After a day of hiking the miles of trails near Tuolumne Meadows, hungry adventurers enjoy hot meals at the Tuolumne Meadows Grill. Breakfast and lunch items are served with vegetarian options. Hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more, are offered daily. The grill is located along Tioga Road, approximately a half mile east of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

images.altText: Interior counters and ordering station of the Tuolumne Meadows Grill
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Grill
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Grill

data.bodyText:
Fast casual breakfast and lunch with vegetarian options available. Burritos, pancakes, hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more. Outdoor seating only.

Operating Hours & Seasons

See website or current issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours. Open seasonally from mid-June through late September. Dates vary depending on the opening of the Tioga Road.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated parking spaces are available nearby.
data.audioDescription: The Tuolumne Meadows Grill is on the right end of a long white building that consists of, from left to right, a store, post office, and grill. The building is a wooden frame structure with canvas roofing and siding. A roofed porch extends from the entrance of the grill, across the structure, to the entrance of the store. A sign in the small square window to the right of the double-door entrance reads, no smoking within 25 feet of building. Above the window is a large white sign with a green border and text. It reads, Tuolumne Meadows Grill - breakfast, hamburgers, and frosties. Above the entrance, a small white sign reads, welcome to Tuolumne Meadows Grill. A bench, brown trash bins, a blue mail box, and a corkboard attached to the side of the building, are all located under the porch. A parking lot lines the front side of the building. A few picnic tables are to the right of the building, and a small white structure, which holds the restrooms.

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
data.listingDescription: Situated next to the Tuolumne River, this is the perfect place to settle in after hiking in Yosemite-or before embarking on an extended backpacking trip.

images.altText: Entrance and sign for Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge

data.bodyText:
Situated next to the Tuolumne River at approximately 8,700 feet above sea level, the Tuolumne Meadows Lodge features canvas tent cabins that accommodate up to four guests. Accommodations are basic with no electricity, televisions, or WiFi.

See website for more information about the cabins and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Tuolumne Meadows Lodge is open seasonally, typically mid-June to mid-September, conditions permitting.

Amenities

Showers (for guests only) and restrooms can be found in the center of the camp.

Breakfast and dinner are served at the riverside dining tent. Box lunches are also available, and can be ordered for the next day. Dinner reservations are required, and can be made by calling 209/372-8413 or in person at the front desk.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for front desk and amenity hours.

Food Storage Requirements

Guests staying overnight at Tuolumne Meadows Lodge must follow these rules:

  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside your tent cabin or anywhere in the lodge area.
  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.
  • Keep your locker closed and latched at all times, just like you would a freezer.
  • Only have the food out that you are actually using; if you're not using it, put it back into the food locker.
  • Treat your trash and recycling like food: keep it in your food locker or dispose of it in a bear-proof dumpster; do not leave it sitting out.
  • During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed).
  • Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time. Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark.
  • When you check out, empty your food locker.
  • Failure to store your food properly may result in impoundment of your food or car and/or a fine of up to $5,000 and/or removal from your campsite or lodging facility.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
data.audioDescription: A large parking lot surrounded by tall trees has four long rows of parking. Multiple food storage lockers line the entire north side of the parking area. At the northeast end of the lot are luggage carts, that are like wheelbarrows, corralled and stacked side by side. Canvas-tent cabins that have metal-frames and cement platforms, are scattered throughout the trees, some with smoke stacks coming out the back side. At the southeast corner of the parking lot is a path that leads to the Tuolumne Meadows Lodge entrance.

data.audioDescription: The Tuolumne Meadows Post Office is situated in the middle of a long white building that consists of, from left to right, a store, the post office, and a grill. The building is a wooden frame structure with canvas roofing and siding. A roofed porch extends from the entrance of the grill, across the structure, to the entrance of the store. A sign above a service window, located between the store and grill entrances reads, post office. A wood carving of a bald eagle, clasping its talons to a tree branch, with its wings up as if its ready to take flight, is mounted to the building to the right of the service window. A bench, brown trash bins, a blue mail box, and a corkboard attached to the side of the building, are all located beneath the porch. A parking lot lines the front side of the building. A few picnic tables are to the right of the building, and a small white structure, which holds the restrooms.

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center
data.listingDescription: Visit the Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).

images.altText: A brown building with a covered entry and a sign that says "Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center"
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center

data.bodyText:
Visit the Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center is closed seasonally from approximately October 15 to late May, depending on conditions. This wilderness center is not open when Tioga Road is closed. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. There is also an accessible restroom. There are no designated accessible parking spaces.
data.audioDescription:
The Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center is located at the east end of a large parking lot. It is a small, brown, wooden building with a front porch and wood railing. Steps or a ramp access the front porch from the left. Two unisex restrooms are also located on the left side of the building. Along the outside wall, beneath the porch roof, is a trip planning flip book, a map of the Tuolumne vicinity, a few flyers, and a line of five exhibit signs. The panels are secured inside wood framing. At the top of the frame is a wooden sign that reads, you determine the quality of Yosemite Wilderness - Please leave no trace!

The first panel of the five is green and beige and is titled, campsite selection. Panel text reads, choose an existing campsite at least 100 feet (80 steps) from water and trail.
Use a large container to carry water to your campsite.
Arrange your camp so that trees, shrubs, and rocks hide it from view.
Please do not build additions such as fire rings, walls, and benches.
When you leave, make sure your campsite is clean.

Why? Using an existing and appropriately placed camp on durable ground improves wilderness quality. Camping away from lakes and streams is warmer, has fewer insects, and allows wildlife access to water. Using a water container will reduce the number of trips to lakes and streams. This prevents the formation or expansion of trails, protects plants near water sources, and preserves water quality. The spread of campsite impacts affects everyone's enjoyment of the wilderness.

Illustration: A plastic water jug with a spigot.

The second panel of the five is maroon and beige and is titled, water quality. Panel text reads, Use a trowel to help keep water clean! Bury all human waste in a 6 inch deep "cat hole" 80 steps (100 feet) from water or camps. Pack out all toilet paper. Do all washing at least 80 steps from water, too. Filter or treat all drinking water.

Why? Appropriate disposal of human waste and proper washing of your dishes or yourself are the keys to the quality of wilderness water. Unburied human waste and toilet paper around a campsite, and soapsuds and food scraps in our lakes and streams, are unhealthy and show little respect for other wilderness users. Remember; even biodegradable soap pollutes the water and can injure fish and other aquatic life. The disease giardiasis is usually traced to drinking water that contains impurities from human waste that is not properly buried.

Illustration: A water pump and a trowel are shown.

The third panel of the five is blue and beige and is titled, camp fires. Panel text reads, campfires are allowed below 9600 feet in elevation. Use only an established fire ring located at least 100 feet from water. Keep fires small. Use only dead and down wood that is on the ground and is smaller than your wrist. Never leave fires unattended. Make sure they are out before you leave. Pick up any litter in the area in or around the fire ring. The use of gas stoves is quick, clean, and encouraged to reduce the impacts of campfires.

Why? Fallen trees and branches provide habitat and shelter for other plants and wildlife and add essential nutrients to the soil. Vegetation grows very slowly at high elevations, so fires are allowed only below the alpine zone (9600 feet); Using existing fire rings prevents the spread of fire-blackened rocks and charcoal, which already scar many campsites. Never build a new fire ring or build a fire against a boulder.

Illustration: a small, red, gas canister is attached to a small metal cooking stobe by a thin tube.

The fourth panel of the five is maroon and beige and is titled, food storage. Panel text reads, don't let bears or other animals eat your food. Properly store all food, garbage, and anything with an odor in camp and at trailheads. Use bear-resistant food storage canisters and keep a clean camp.

Why? Some animals, particularly bears, become dependent on human food. When this happens, the animal is usually the loser - sometimes with its life. Unnatural food sources promote changes in foraging habits and population dynamics. Socialized animals can transmit diseases, upset normal ecological behavior, and become a danger to people. Do your part to keep the "wild" in wildlife by properly storing everything with an odor, not discarding food scraps, and packing out all garbage.

The fifth panel of the five is green and beige and is titled, trails. Panel text reads, stay on the trail. Don't cut switchbacks or take shortcuts! Leave dogs and bicycles at home - they are prohibited on trails and in wilderness areas. Give right-of-way to stock (horses, mules, or llamas). Stand quietly on the side of the trail while they pass.

Why? Help maintain the trail system! shortcutting and cutting switchbacks cause erosion, trail destruction, and falling rocks. Not only does it take more energy on your part, but the damage it can cause is costly and may be impossible to restore. Improper behavior around stock may hurt you, the rider, or the animal itself. Dogs are not allowed on trails because pets can transmit diseases and harass wildlife. Trails are designated for hikers and stock users only. Keep bicycles and baby strollers on roads or desginated bike paths.

Illustration: a map that is turned diagonally, creating a diamond shape.

A brown trash dumpster, a green recycle dumpster, and over eleven food storage lockers neatly line the west end of the parking lot.

data.title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
data.listingDescription: A steep climb is well rewarded with close-up views of Upper Yosemite Fall and distant views of Half Dome and other Sierra peaks. Along the hike, enjoy a bird's eye view of Yosemite Valley's meadows and the meandering Merced River. Enjoy the views from Columbia Rock, located one mile (and dozens of switchbacks) from the trailhead. The Yosemite Falls Trail is one of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877.

images.altText: Wooden sign at trailhead
images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead

data.bodyText:
One of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877, the Yosemite Falls Trail leads to the top of the waterfall, which cascades 2,425 feet (739 m) above the Valley floor. This trail starts near Camp 4, along the Valley Loop Trail, and immediately climbs a series of switchbacks through oak woodland. Do not stray off of the maintained path, as you will find steep drops adjacent to the trail.

Use extreme caution when near the creek and remember you are directly above a waterfall.

Columbia Rock

Columbia Rock features views of Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, and the valley floor. From there, consider hiking another 0.5 miles (0.8 km) beyond this point for a stunning view of Upper Yosemite Fall.

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) round-trip
Elevation: 1,000 ft (328 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 2-3 hours round trip

Top of Yosemite Falls

The upper switchbacks of the trail is steep and rocky but very scenic, including views of Upper Yosemite Fall with Half Dome in the background. The final portion of the hike leads to a small viewing platform where Yosemite Creek pours over the lip of the cliff.

Distance: 7.2 miles (11.6 km) round-trip
Elevation: 2,700 ft (820 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 6-8 hours round trip

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. Do not shortcut switchbacks, which causes rapid trail erosion and results in injuries.

The Yosemite Falls Trail can be hiked year-round, though conditions vary depending on the season. In spring, when the waterfall is at its peak, this hike is stunning, and you may even get wet from the spray of the waterfall during a section of the hike. In summer, conditions are hot and dry, and the loose decomposed granite along the trail can be slippery. Keep in mind that by August, the waterfall is typically low or totally dry. During winter, the lower portion of this trail gets direct sunlight, so hiking can be snow-free while other trails are icy.

Columbia Rock, located one mile up the trail, is a worthwhile trip at any time of year. Beyond this point, the upper portion of this trail receives little to no sunlight in winter and can be very icy and slippery, or buried beneath feet of snow, making traction difficult. In winter, hiking in the colder early morning or late afternoon hours can be even more dangerous if the trail is icy.
data.audioDescription:
The trailhead for the Yosemite Falls Trail is marked by a wooden sign that reads Yosemite Falls Trail, Top Yosemite Fall, 3.4 miles, Yosemite Point, 4.2 miles, Eagle Peak, 6 miles, North Dome, 7.9 miles. Dangerous to stray from trail. Horses not permitted off valley floor without guide.

The area is surrounded by forest and rugged terrain. The trail is a rocky path that starts immediately ascending. Fallen logs and boulders are strewn about.

data.title: Valley Shuttle Stop 10: Cathedral Beach
data.listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes (depending on conditions) during hours of operation. You can get off and on the shuttle wherever and whenever you wish.

images.altText: Shuttle bus at stop with El Capitan in the background
images.title: Valley Shuttle Stop #10
images.caption: Valley Shuttle Stop #10: Cathedral Beach Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
This shuttle stop is served by the Valleywide Shuttle route only. There is no covered shelter or benches at this bus stop.

Yosemite Valley shuttles are free and operate from 7 am to 10 pm daily. During hours of operation, the Valleywide Shuttle runs approximately every 22-32 minutes. No ticket is required. Passengers may board and disembark at any stop.

What's Nearby

  • Cathedral Beach picnic area
  • Valley Loop Trail

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.
data.audioDescription: The area is dense with trees, however, the tall, granite, Valley cliffsides are still visible through breaks in the trees and above the tree line. Across the street, a dirt road leads down a slight hill to the Cathedral Beach Picnic Area. Near the picnic area entrance, two brown signs read, No camping or overnight parking, and picnic area closes at dusk. A trail crosses the road near this area. The trail leads toward Yosemite Valley or in the opposite direction, toward El Capitan.

data.audioDescription:
Nearby, a brown sign reads, Four Mile Trail, and has an icon of a hiker inside a square outline and an arrow pointing to the right, next to the roadside parking area, that has limited parking. A noticeable dirt trail starts to retreat into the woods from here. Two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, and a way side exhibit are in this area. Before entering the forest and starting the ascent, a wooden sign is posted and reads, Glacier Point Four Mile Trail; Union Point - 3.0 miles, Glacier Point - 4.6 miles, Sentinel Dome - 5.2 miles. Dangerous to stray from trail. Horses not permitted off valley floor without guide.

The wayside exhibit near the road is titled, Paths Into Wilderness, and has a faint, sepia-toned photograph of fourteen or more men, sitting on both sides of a log that has been halved and is set for a meal. . The caption reads, trail crew stops for dinner. Panel text reads, James McCauley, an Irish immigrant and proprietor of the Glacier Point Hotel, hired John Conway to survey and construct a trail from Yosemite Valley to Glacier Point. Taking only seven months to build, it was completed in the early summer of 1872. The original trail was four miles long and travelers paid a $1 toll. In the 1920s, the National Park Service lengthened the trail to improve the steeper sections. Today it is 4.6 miles from the Valley to Glacier Point.

Black and white photo: One of Yosemite Valley's high, 2,000-foot plus rock walls has a noticeable trail zigzagging its way to the top.

Caption: "...it is the steepest trail out of the valley, zigzagging back and forth a sheer granite wall, one rides up it with little alarm or giddiness." - Helen Hunt Jackson, from Ah-Wah-Ne Days: A visit to Yosemite Valley in 1872. Under a heading that reads, Conway - A "Walkist", panel text quotes an 1869 article in the Mariposa Gazette, "John Conway of Sherlock Creek, last Saturday walked from the Sentinel Hotel, Yosemite Valley, to Mariposa in fourteen hours, including all stoppages. He left the hotel about seven o'clock in the morning and made the trip to town by nine o'clock the same evening. The walk did not seem to fatiguw him much, for he soon left town for his home on Sherlock Creek, six miles farther. Mr. Conway says it is no trip at all for him on foot." Black and white photo: Two older men stand side by side. The man to the right is wearing a hat, has a mustache and long white bear, and is wearing a black suit with a white collared button-down shirt. He is standing with his hands on his hips, looking off into the distance to the right. The other man is dressed similarly and has a mustache and long grey beard. He is standing with his hands down by his side, gazing to the right. Caption: John Conway, on right, shown here with Galen Clark, used only a simple ship's protractor to survey the Four Mile Trail's route.

data.title: Valley Shuttle Stop 12: Housekeeping Camp and Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center
data.listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free shuttle system. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes. The East Valley shuttle is limited to Yosemite Village, Curry Village, Pines Campgrounds, and trailheads in eastern Yosemite Valley. Buses arrive every 8 to 12 minutes. This stop is part of both routes.

data.audioDescription:
A green and white shuttle stop sign stands near the curb of a roadside turnout along the right side of the one-way road leading into Yosemite Valley. The sign reads, Valley Shuttle, Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center/Housekeeping Camp, and has the number 12 in white font, in a green circle. The area is dense with trees, however, the tall, granite, Valley cliffsides are still visible through and above the tree line. A covered shelter made with wooden beams and a shingled roof, both house two wooden benches.

Nearby, a stone building with a steep-pitched roof and a color, texture, and verticality that blends with the Yosemite Valley walls stands. The center section of the building rises up to a steep point, and two smaller wings are built slightly inward on each side. A stonewall extends off the ends of each wing, slanted inward as well, creating a hexagonal structural layout. Steps lead to the center of the hexagonal layout, a small porch area, then up to the front, wooden, pointed arched, door. Four windows line the front side of the building. At the end of the right stone porch wall, a bronze plaque is adhered to the granite, and it reads, LeConte Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987. National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior.

data.title: Valley Shuttle Stop 16: Happy Isles

images.caption: Valley Shuttle Stop #16: Happy Isles

data.bodyText:
This shuttle stop is served by both the Valleywide Shuttle and East Valley Shuttle routes. There is a covered shelter with benches available at this shuttle stop.

Yosemite Valley shuttles are free and operate from 7 am to 10 pm daily. During hours of operation, the Valleywide Shuttle runs approximately every 22-32 minutes. The East Valley Shuttle runs approximately every 18-22 minutes. No ticket is required. Passengers may board and disembark at any stop.

What's Nearby

  • Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
  • Mist Trail/John Muir Trail trailhead

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.

A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. Behind the shelter is a small wooden building, which is the restroom. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a drinking fountain are near the restroom facility. Up the road is a bridge, which leads to the Mist Trail and John Muir Trail.

data.audioDescription:
A green and white sign stands next to the roadside turnout where the shuttle bus stops. The sign is white with a green bar across the top. Within the green bar, text reads, Valley shuttle and has an icon of a bus. Below the green bar, text reads Mirror Lake Trailhead, and the number 17 is in white font within a green circle. Next to the sign is a wooden shelter that holds two benches. A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a sign that has three small panels across the top and a large map on the bottom, are near the shuttle stop shelter. A paved path/road retreats into the trees behind the shelter.

The first panel of the sign is yellow with a green bar across the top. Text in the green bar reads, shuttle bus schedule. The text in the yellow section reads, shuttle stop 17, Mirror Lake. From 7am to 10am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The second panel is white with a blue bar across the top. Text in the blue bar reads, Did You Know? Text in the white section reads, Mirror Lake is not really a lake at all. Until the middle of the 20th century, park personnel dredged sand to maintain a pond that reflected the cliffs above. Current park policy is to let the natural succession of pond to meadow occur. During high water, however, you can still see a stunning reflection of Half Dome.

Photo: One person stands in ankle-deep snow, with a backpack on the ground by his side, and his back turned from the camera. He is facing a small body of water and the large face of Half Dome which towers over this lake. Snow covers the landscape.

Caption: At Half Dome's base, Mirror Lake forms in winter and spring, but is more of a sandy beach during the dry season. NPS photo by Erik Skindrud.

The third panel is white with an orange bar across the top. Text in the orange bar reads, Be Bear Aware. Text in the white box reads, Keeping bears away from your food isn't just a way to avoid a fine-it could save a bear's life. Do not store food in vehicles after dark. When not stored in a locker or cabin, food must be within arm's length. Stay at least 50 yards from a bear. If a bear approaches, yell to scare it away.

Photo: A reddish-brown black bear with yellow plastic tags on both ears, is hanging halfway out of a parked car's side door window. The door frame is bent half way down, the side view mirror is dangling, and the glass has been busted out. It is dark out.

Caption: Bear break-ins can cost thousands of dollars and put visitors and bears at risk. NPS photo by Tammy Evans.

A large map showing three different shuttle routes in Yosemite Valley is below. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

data.audioDescription:
A green and white sign reads: Valley Shuttle, Lower Yosemite Fall. There is a bus stop shelter made with six large cobblestone posts, wooden beams, and it has a wooden roof. There is a bronze relief plaque of Yosemite Falls on the outer northeast corner post. Split logs serve as benches nearby. In front of the bus stop sign is a crosswalk that leads across the street into Cook's meadow. Also, the accessible trail to Lower Yosemite Fall begins north of the shuttle stop. Limited roadside parking is located east of shuttle stop six. Near the bus stop shelter is a large map of trails. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. The map header reads Welcome to Yosemite Falls. On the side of the large map is a smaller header that reads: About Yosemite Falls A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Heights of the Falls
The text reads: Upper Fall, 1,430 feet, 435 meters, Middle Cascades, 675 feet, 205 meters, 320 feet, 98 meters, 2,425 feet, 740 meters.

Photo, located to the left of the above text, shows an aerial sepia-toned photo of Yosemite Falls, and labels each part of the Falls, Upper Fall, Middle Cascades, and Lower Fall.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: World Ranking
The text reads: Yosemite Falls is the tallest waterfall in the United States, and the 5th tallest waterfall in the world. The tallest is Salto Angel in Venezuela at 3,212 feet, 979 meters.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Source of the Falls
The text reads: Yosemite Creek, which flows over this waterfall, is entirely fed by melting snow. It drains an area of nearly 50 square miles. At its peak volume in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second, or 9,000 liters, flow over the lip of the Upper Fall. Every summer, when the snow from this drainage is entirely melted, Yosemite Falls usually run dry.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Ice Cone
The text reads: In winter, a dramatic cone of ice accumulates at the base of the Upper Fall. The maximum height of the cone is documented at 322 feet, about as tall as a 25 story building. When temperatures warm up in early spring, the water from the fall begins to drill a hole at the top of the cone, creating a volcano-like structure, and by mid-April, most of the cone has melted.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Moonbow
The text reads: The full moon in April and May offers a special treat at the base of Lower Yosemite Fall. As the moon rises, the light is captured and refracted in the massive spray of the fall, creating a phenomenon called a moonbow.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Frazil Ice
The text reads: In early spring, frazil ice sometimes forms in waterfalls and creeks when water becomes super cooled by turbulence. Ice crystals form and group into spongy masses which sometimes overflow the creek bed. In 1997 frazil ice was above the railings of the Lower Yosemite Fall bridge, almost completely burying it!

Quote: When the afternoon sunshine is streaming through the throng of comets, ever wasting, ever renewed, the marvelous fineness, firmness and variety of their forms are beautifully revealed. - John Muir
