data.audioDescription: Vallewide shuttle stop #9 is located on a side road that makes a half circle through the El Capitan Picnic Area, just off Northside Drive, near El Capitan. There is a designated entrance to the road that then travels clockwise to the parking area and then to the designated exit. Shuttle stop #9 is located in the picnic area parking lot, on the right side of the road. Picnic tables and accompanying grills are randomly scattered through this forested area. To the left of the road, there is a vault toilet, trash and recycle receptacles, and food lockers. El Capitan and other nearby rocks tower over the treeline. Climbers are sometime seen on these portions of exposed rocks.

data.title: Valley Shuttle Stop 9: El Capitan Meadow
data.listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes (depending on conditions) during hours of operation. You can get off and on the shuttle wherever and whenever you wish.

images.altText: Bus pulled over at stop along road
images.title: Valley Shuttle Stop #9
images.caption: Valley Shuttle Stop #9: El Capitan Meadow

data.bodyText:
This shuttle stop is served by the Valleywide Shuttle route only. There is no covered shelter or seating at this shuttle stop.

Yosemite Valley shuttles are free and operate from 7 am to 10 pm daily. During hours of operation, the Valleywide Shuttle runs approximately every 22-32 minutes. No ticket is required. Passengers may board and disembark at any stop.

What's Nearby

  • El Capitan Meadow
  • Valley Loop Trail

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.
data.audioDescription: Two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, and a few food lockers are in the area. The Merced River flows beneath a nearby bridge. Beyond the bridge, a large, vertical rock face rises above a forest of oaks, pines, and cedars, which offer a pleasant combination of sun and shade.

data.title: Valley View
data.listingDescription: Catch a glimpse of past glaciers' exposed handiwork from Valley View, a view that highlights El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. Valley View is a remarkable spot to soak in some of Yosemite Valley's unbelievably scenic charm. Although glaciers ended their work carving out Yosemite Valley over 14,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley, making Yosemite a very dynamic place.

images.altText: View of El Capitan on the left, the river in the foreground, and Bridalveil Fall on the right
images.title: Valley View
images.caption: Valley View showing El Capitan, the Merced River, and Bridalveil Fall.

data.bodyText:
Take in an iconic view of El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. Although the glaciers that carved Yosemite Valley melted about 10,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley. In January 1997, floodwaters spilled over into the parking lot here, up to a depth of 6 feet!

Parking is extremely limited at Valley View. A vault toilet is available by crossing Northside Drive.

Seasonal Information

Located on the west end of Yosemite Valley, Valley View can be reached by vehicle year-round.

Caution: swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river is flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces available. This viewpoint is visible from the parking area.
data.audioDescription:
Valley View is located along the left side of Northside drive, as you're about to exit Yosemite Valley. Valley View is next to the river, and showcases the scenery of Yosemite Valley, with El Capitan to the left of the valley and Bridalveil Fall to the right.

A wayside exhibit is located next to the Valley View parking area.

Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from Valley View. El Capitan is on the left, while Sentinel Rock, the Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall are on the left side of the panel.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: The Power of Glaciers.
Text to the right of the header reads:
Following the ancient river channel, a series of glaciers shaped this canyon. When the glaciers melted, they left behind piles of rocks that had been plucked from the cliff walls and carried along in the river of ice. These piles are called moraines. The moraine left behind following the most recent glacial activity dammed the Merced River near Bridalveil Fall. As the glacier melted, a shallow lake formed which eventually filled in with small rocks and sediment. This accounts for the flat valley floor we see today.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: An Everchanging Landscape
Text reads: Although glaciers ended their work here over 14,000 years ago, Yosemite remains a dynamic place. The Merced River continues to shape this valley. On January 2, 1997, floodwaters covered the parking lot here to a depth of 6 feet.

Two small, square, black and white illustrations are located beneath the text.

Photo 1: An aerial view looking into Yosemite Valley shows a glacier that starts in Yosemite's backcountry, moving forward past Half Dome, and ending just after El Capitan and Bridalveil Fall. The glacial ice rise about halfway up the Valley walls.

Photo 1 Caption Header: 30,000 years ago
Photo 1 Caption Text: The last glacier to flow through Yosemite Valley was at its peak. As you can see at the bottom of this illustration, the moraine forms a low ridge at Bridalveil Fall.

Photo 2: An aerial view looking into Yosemite Valley shows the steep walls of Yosemite Valley, with a lake that ends near El Capitan and Bridalveil Fall.

Photo 2 Caption Header: 10,000 years ago
Photo 2 Caption Text: A shallow lake was created by the moraine left behind when the glacier receded.

To the west of the parking lot is a sign that stands over six feet high. The sign reads: Flood Water Level, 11:00pm., January 2, 1997, and has a double sided arrow extending from left to right.

data.title: View of Mirror Lake
data.listingDescription: Mirror Lake is famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins and is one of the few lakes that are easily accessible in Yosemite National Park. Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, in the shadow of Half Dome. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area. Mirror Lake is in a state of transition. Sand carried by Tenaya Creek collects here, and will eventually form a meadow.

images.altText: Low water levels in Mirror Lake with people wading into water
images.title: Mirror Lake
images.caption: Mirror Lake during a warmer time of year when water levels are low.

data.bodyText:
Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area. When there is adequate water, the mirror effect for which the lake is named is best viewed early in the morning, when the water is still.

Tips & Seasonal Information

While you may visit this area any time of year, the lake is typically only present in spring and early summer. As summer wears on, the shallow lake gradually disappears into the sand in late summer, transforming into "Mirror Meadow." All times of year, the views of Half Dome and other nearby cliffs are remarkable.

Leashed pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed on the paved pathways leading toward this viewpoint. Beyond that, on unpaved areas, they are prohibited. A pit toilet is available where the paved road ends, near the views of Mirror Lake.

Caution: During spring and early summer, when water levels are highest, entering the water can be dangerous. Always remember when approaching moving water to look at the conditions downstream. Waters in this area may appear ankle deep at first, but can quickly become thigh deep, and, all too often, hikers are swept into dangerous whitewater and pinned against rocks. Learn more about past experiences visitors had with swift water in this area of the park.

Accessibility 

A one-mile road, from the Mirror Lake shuttle stop, leads to this view of the lake and is easy to walk due to its paved surface. The last 1,000 feet of the trail up to the lake is on a slope from 6.6 percent to 10.6 percent.

Vehicles with a disability placard are permitted to drive up to 15 mph, with hazard lights on, to Mirror Lake. Be cautious as the road is shared with bicyclists and hikers. There are two designated accessible parking spaces available.
data.audioDescription: Depending on time of year, Mirror Lake is either a full body of water or an open meadow. The water reflects the surrounding granite cliffs that rise up above the treeline, including the iconic Half Dome. The lake is surrounded by a forest of oaks, pines, and firs.

data.title: Village Grill
data.listingDescription: Dine al fresco at the Village Grill, which features outside seating on an expansive deck. Grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options are available daily. Open March - October, see website for hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Village Grill Deck is also located at shuttle stops #2 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

images.altText: People eating at outdoor seating with umbrellas on the deck of the grill
images.title: Village Grill
images.caption: Village Grill

data.bodyText:
Counter service eatery serving grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options. Outdoor seating only with shade umbrellas on the adjacent deck.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open seasonally, typically March - October. See website for hours.

Accessibility

This outdoor deck and facility are wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the Village Store 30-minute Parking Area.
data.audioDescription: The Village Grill is located on the side of a brown wooden building that also houses the Village Store. An open doorway with a sign that reads Enter is on the right, while another open doorway, with a sign that reads exit, is on the left. All the seating is outside. Circular and rectangular picnic tables with green umbrellas are randomly placed on the paved deck. A few sets of trash and recycle bins are against the fence that lines the deck.

data.title: Village Store
data.listingDescription: If you left something behind, or just need to stock up, we have everything you need at the Village Store.The Village Store has all the essentials you need - including groceries, meat and produce, baked goods, camping supplies, books, magazines, postcards, ice and firewood. There's also an ATM in the store. Additionally, you'll find all the souvenirs, T-shirts, sweatshirts and hats you could ever want-perfect for gifts or commemorating your Yosemite experience. Hours :Year-rou

images.altText: A pedestrian walkway leads to a covered entry of a building, a sign reads "Village Store"
images.title: Village Store
images.caption: Village Store

data.bodyText:
The Village Store offers a large selection of groceries, grab-and-go food, camping supplies, apparel, and many other gifts and supplies.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round. See website for hours.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot outside the store's east entrance.
data.audioDescription: The Village Store is located in a brown wooden single-story building that also houses the Village Grill. The front and rear entrances of the Village Store have high pitched roofs held up by tall wooden posts. A large sign reads Village Store in the center of the porch. Three vending machines, a penny press machine, and a large touch screen information kiosk line the front of the building, to the right of the entrance. There are two rows of windows above the entrance and vending machines. The lower row of windows have pictures that correspond to the text, from left to right, the text reads Trail Rides, Biking, Tours, Bracebridge Dinner, Rafting, and Hiking. The back entrance has a large touch screen information kiosk, a penny press machine, one vending machine, three pay phones, six newspaper vending machines, two trash bins, a drinking fountain, and two rows of grocery carts nearby.

data.title: Village Store 30-Minute Parking
data.listingDescription: Park in this 30-minute parking area to grab something you may have left behind, or just need to stock up on, at the Village Store. Open year-round, during store hours. See website for store hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking.

images.altText: Cars in a full parking lot, with Yosemite Falls in background
images.title: 30-minute Village Store Parking
images.caption: 30-minute Village Store Parking

data.bodyText:
This small parking area is for short visits to the Village Store and Welcome Center. Parking is limited to 30 minutes.

All day parking is available in Yosemite Village Parking, located just to the south of this lot.

Tips & Seasonal Information

During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed). Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark: use the food lockers available near the entrance to this parking area.

Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time.

See website for Village Store hours.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces near the entrance to the Village Store and near the path to the Village Grill Deck.
data.audioDescription: The Village Store Parking lot is a paved lot located directly behind the Village Store's brown wooden building. A white sign at the entrance of the lot reads 30 minute parking, 8am to 8pm. The lot overflows into a second lot, that is separated by a stand of trees. Tall trees encase the lot and Yosemite Valley's granite walls rise above the treeline.

data.title: Village Store Bike Stand
data.listingDescription: Biking is one of the best ways to see Yosemite Valley. Yosemite Valley is flat, which makes for easy riding along our 12 miles of designated paths. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. We also offer a select number of tandem bikes and hand-crank bikes for guests with physical limitations. Wheelchairs, electric scooters, and strollers may also be available for rent.

images.altText: Yellow metal fencing surrounds a fleet of bicycles and a small brown structure
images.title: Village Store bike stand
images.caption: Village Store bike stand

data.bodyText:
With miles of designated bike paths, Yosemite Valley offers ample opportunity for easy riding. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, child trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. All rental bikes are first-come, first-served. Reservations are only available for bicycles intended for people with disabilities. The Village Store bike stand has a smaller fleet of bicycles. When sold out, a larger fleet of bicycles may be found at the Curry Village bike stand or Yosemite Valley Lodge bike stand.

See website for rates.

Bicycles are not permitted on hiking trails. Ride on paved bicycle paths only. Cyclists that choose to ride on roads must ride with traffic and obey all traffic laws and signs.

Operating Hours & Seasons

See website for hours, or call 209/372-1208. Bicycle rentals are available daily spring through fall, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

A limited number of tandem and hand-crank bicycles are available for rent and may be reserved in advance by calling 209/372-1208.

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
data.audioDescription: The Village Store Bike Stand operates out of a small, brown, wood-paneled kiosk. It is located in front of the Village Store (the western side) and is between the store entrance and the Welcome Center. Rows of bikes are parked side by side within an area enclosed by yellow metal temporary fencing. The bikes are a variety of colors and range in size from larger adult-sized bikes, to smaller child-sized bikes, to tandem bikes, and bikes with trailers for children.

data.title: Wagon Shed
data.listingDescription: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.

images.altText: Historic red stage wagons in a row under an open barn roof
images.title: Wagon Shed
images.caption: Wagon Shed

data.bodyText: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.
data.audioDescription: A dirt path leads by this open wooden structure that has exposed timber frame trusses, log posts, and log barriers, and holds about 10 historic horse-drawn wagons and carriages inside. One of the wagons is green and has four large wheels, a basic body large enough to hold a metal barrel with a spigot, and only one seat in front. Another carriage is a bit fancier, with a yellow undercarriage and a red body that holds four rows of people, including the driver, and has a canopy over the top. Down the dirt path is a grey barn and corral. Tall trees surround the area.

data.title: Wapama and Rancheria Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, and in spring and early summer, home to brightly colored wildflowers. Enjoy a day hike or overnight backpacking trip (wilderness permit required) in this area at any time throughout the year.Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone. Wapama Fall five-mile, round-trip hike follows the shoreline of the rese

images.altText: A vast blue reservoir surrounded by granite peaks
images.title: Trailhead at Hetch Hetchy Reservoir
images.caption: The trail to Wapama and Rancheria Falls begins at O'Shaughnessy Dam

data.bodyText:
Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals all times of year and is a great area for wildflowers in spring and early summer. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite.

The trail begins at the O'Shaughnessy Dam as hikers travel through a short tunnel blasted out of the granite. Beyond that, the trail skirts the shorelines of the reservoir with moderate up and downhill sections. The trail includes spectacular views of Tueeulala and Wapama Falls.

The trail to Rancheria Falls continues past Wapama Falls and may be done as either a long day hike (13 miles round trip) or a backpacking trip. Permits are required for all overnight hikes. Visit a wilderness center for more information.

Wapama Falls

Distance: 5 miles (8 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 507 ft (155 m)
Time estimate: 2 hours

Rancheria Falls

Distance: 13.4 miles (21.4 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1909 ft (581 m)
Time estimate: 6 to 8 hours

Tips & Hours

Expect substantial mist from Wapama Falls in spring and early summer. By late summer, waterfalls in this area have typically slowed or dried out. Watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak in this area.

Pets are prohibited on all hiking trails. Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open from sunrise to sunset only. Hetch Hetchy trailheads are not reachable by vehicle when the road is closed.

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.
data.audioDescription: The official trailhead for this walk begins after walking across the O'Shaughnessy Dam and through a dark tunnel. At the other side of the tunnel, a dirt trail continues around the perimeter of the reservoir. A large body of water is on the right side of the trail. The water is in a granite basin, with high granite cliff walls rising up around the reservoir. Four wayside exhibits line the dirt path near the trailhead. The first sign has two panels stacked on top of each other. The upper panel has a faint, sepia-toned photo of an elderly Native American woman holding a baby in a cradle basket. The text reads, for generations Central Me-Wuk, Southern Sierra Miwuk, and Mono Lake Paiute people made mountain places like this their homes, using the higher mountains for trade routes and summer encampment. We have lived on the land as hunters and gatherers, and traditional skills and beliefs were passed on. We still live here and continue to teach our children the ways of our ancestors. The lower panel is titled, Archeological Site Protection, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photo of three Native American children grouped together. A young girl in a plaid dress and hat is on the left. A young boy with a white, long-sleeved shirt, hat, and long bangs, is to the right of the young girl, and is slightly taller than she is. An older girl, in a white, long-sleeved blouse and long skirt, sits on the ground to the right of the two others, and smiles at the camera. Panel text reads, disturbing these resources is disrespectful to American Indian cultures and is a violation of law. Please participate as a guardian of these important resources. The second sign has four, small, square panels, all located below a large map. Map: The large, detailed map shows the northern portion of the park. Roads, trails, peaks, and lakes are labeled. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.The top left panel is orange with white text and reads, Hetch Hetchy trailhead. You are at the gateway to the northern canyons of Yosemite's wilderness. Wapama Falls - 2.7 milesRancheria Falls - 6.1 milesLaurel Lake - 6.8 milesLake Vernon - 8.0 milesTo protect water quality, swimming and boating is not allowed in the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and in the stream within one mile of the Reservoir. Closure includes Wapama Falls and Rancheria Cascade. The top right panel is blue with white text and reads, wilderness regulations, the natural integrity of Yosemite's high country depends on you. Help protect the wilderness, and avoid a citation, by following these regulations.Camp at least four trail miles from all developed areas. Pets, firearms, and bicycles are prohibited in wilderness. Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks kills vegetation and causes erosion. Maximum group size for cross-country travel is eight people.Avoid disturbing wildlife and other visitors by keeping quiet on the trail and in camp. Use a gas stove for cooking; wood fires are allowed only below 9,600 feet in existing fire rings using dead and downed wood. Leave campsites as you find them; do not build windbreaks, fire rings, hitch racks, chairs, drainage trenches, or other "improvements."Pack out everything you carry in; do not burn trash. Wilderness permit required for all overnight use. A series of three white circles containing three different icons are outlined in red and have a red diagonal line slashing through the middle. The three icons are of a gun, a dog, and a person on a bicycle.The bottom left panel is yellow with black text and reads, Black Bears - the health and well-being of Yosemite's bears depends on you. Bears are intelligent, curious, adaptable, and hungry. Human food, however, is harmful to bears and other animals here. Keep wildlife wild by using these food storage methods.At the trailhead: Remove all food, ice chests, and scented items from you car. Store them in food storage lockers where available. Never feed bears or other wildlife. In the backcountry: Store food, garbage, and scented items in bearproof canisters, available at front country locations. Keep items stored whenever you are not eating. Remember, bears are active day and night. Scare away any bears you see by making loud noises and acting aggressively. Report all bear incidents.The bottom right panel is blue with white text and reads, water quality - clean, sparkling water is one of the joys of the high country. Wildlife, wilderness visitors, and people downstream all need clean water to stay healthy. Protect your water suppy by following these regulations and suggestions:Camp at least 100 feet (40 steps) from water.Deposit human waste in a six-inch-deep hole at least 100 feet from water; carry out toilet paper.Wash dishes and yourself at least 100 feet from water; even biodegradeable soap pollutes.Carry a large water container and limit your trips to collect water; eroded stream banks and lakeshores contribute to poor water quality. Sta

data.title: Washburn Point
data.listingDescription: Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada. From this vantage point, visitors will see Nevada and Vernal Falls as well as Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who built the first road from Wawona to Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Visitor enjoying the view with Half Dome in the background
images.title: Washburn Point
images.caption: Washburn Point

data.bodyText:
Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada.

From this vantage point, visitors will see Nevada and Vernal Falls as well as Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who were early Yosemite concessioners in the hotel and transportation businesses in the late 19th century and early 20th century. The Washburn interests funded the construction of the original Glacier Point Road in 1882.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, typically from approximately late May through October or November.

Vehicles longer than 30 feet and vehicles pulling trailers are not allowed past Sentinel Dome parking lot and therefore cannot reach Washburn Point.

Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

From mid-December through March, cross-country skiers can experience this view after skiing 10.5 miles, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

There is one designated accessible parking spot at the north end of the lot.
data.audioDescription: Washburn Point is an overlook that gives a panoramic view of Half Dome, Nevada Fall, and Vernal Fall, and other domes, peaks, and natural features found in Yosemite's high country. A ramp or steps descend from the parking lot. A three foot stone wall barrier lines the walkway and viewing area. A wayside exhibit stands on the south side of the overlook.

data.title: Wawona Covered Bridge
data.listingDescription: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Pioneer Yosemite History Center.As you cross the bridge, listen for t

images.altText: A bright red horse-drawn stage exits an old covered wooden bridge.

data.bodyText: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Yosemite History Center. As you cross the bridge, listen for the low rumble of an oncoming stage and allow your imagination to return to the days of Yosemite's pioneers.
data.audioDescription: A dirt road leads into this covered bridge. Vertical wooden planks make up the height of this bridge, which extend up to an A-frame roof. There is a wooden divider stretching across the inside of the bridge, making a path for people to walk on, and a road for the stagecoach to use. An exhibit sign reads: The Covered Bridge. The deck and truss portion of this bridge across the South Fork of the Merced River was built around 1857 by settler Galen Clark, who established a tourist facility there. The area was then called Clark's Station. The road from Wawona to the Yosemite Valley opened in 1875 just after the Washburn brothers purchased Clark's holdings. The brothers, who were from Vermont, covered the bridge soon thereafter. Bridges were covered primarily to protect the large wood truss beams and flooring from the weather. It is much easier to re-shingle a roof than to replace the major supporting structures. Although the large beams were hand-hewn with ax and adze, the lumber to cover the bridge was cut locally at the Washburn's sawmill. Did the Washburn brothers cover the bridge exclusively for practical reasons? Maybe so. But a granddaughter claims the reason was nostalgia - they were homesick for a bit of New England.

data.title: Wawona EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located in the parking lot adjacent to the Wawona Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 24 level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector with a power output of 11 kW.

images.altText: A parking lot lined with electric vehicle charging ports
images.title: Wawona Store EV Charging Station
images.caption: Wawona Store EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located in the parking lot adjacent to the Wawona Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 24 level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector with a power output of 11 kW.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the southernmost row of a large parking area, there are 24 standard-sized parking stalls in front of twelve electric vehicle charging stations all in a row. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. The stations are located behind the curb that borders the parking area on small concrete footers. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." Behind some of the charging stations is a sidewalk, while behind others there is in an unpaved area with grasses and rocks.

data.title: Wawona Gas Station
data.listingDescription:
The Wawona Gas Station conveniently serves the southern end of the park for your refueling needs.

Diesel and Propane available.

Hours :
8am to 5pm, Pay at the pump 24 hours with credit or debit card.

Getting Here :
The Wawona Station is located on Wawona Road (Highway 41), at Forest Drive.

Accessibility :
Attendants can assist with fuel service during business hours.

images.altText: An American flag waves on a flag pole in front of a white building and two gas pumping islands.

8 am to 5 pm, Pay at the pump 24 hours with credit or debit card.

Accessibility:
Attendants can assist with fuel service during business hours.
data.audioDescription: As you approach the gas station, there are two horizontal islands that each contain two fueling stations. The building is white and very basic. An American flag waves on a tall flagpole in front of the store.

images.altText: A sign that reads, 'Golf Shop,' hangs from the ceiling at the corner of a two story building. Circular picnic tables are beneath a porch and lawn chairs sit on the green grass that surrounds the building.

data.bodyText:
The beginning of your grand golfing adventure in Yosemite starts at the Wawona Hotel Golf Shop.

Pay greens fees and rent golf clubs, pull carts, or electric carts here. The shop also provides, apparel, souvenirs, snacks, beverages, and more.

Hours:
Mid-May to late October, conditions permitting.
See website for hours.

Getting Here:
Located in the Wawona Hotel complex, on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Accessibility:
This facility is accessible. A paved path leads to this first floor shop, from the parking lot and the main building of the Wawona Hotel.
data.audioDescription: The Golf shop is on the first floor of a white, three-story building. Each floor has a covered porch with green awnings that wrap around the entire building. As you approach the Golf shop, there are circular picnic tables on the porch. There is a sign that says Golf Shop.

data.title: Wawona Grey Barn (Washburn Barn)
data.listingDescription: In the late 1800s, Wawona was the largest stage stop in Yosemite. After hours of bouncing and bumping along uneven dirt roads, inbound stages stopped for the night at the Wawona Hotel before making the eight-hour trip to Yosemite Valley. If a stage needed a repair before the sixteen-hour round-trip journey, the grey barn was the place to visit. The Washburns, proprietors of the Wawona Hotel, used this barn for repairing stages.

images.altText: A simple grey barn in a dirt area surrounded by trees
images.title: Wawona Grey Barn (Washburn Barn)
images.caption: Wawona Grey Barn (Washburn Barn)

data.bodyText: In the late 1800s, Wawona was the largest stage stop in Yosemite. After hours of bouncing and bumping along uneven dirt roads, inbound stages stopped for the night at the Wawona Hotel before making the eight-hour trip to Yosemite Valley. If a stage needed a repair before the sixteen-hour round-trip journey, the grey barn was the place to visit. The Washburns, proprietors of the Wawona Hotel, used this barn for repairing stages.
data.audioDescription: The wooden barn is grey and has a gable style triangular roof. Double doors are open in the front and in the back. A red, white, and blue bunting is placed on the inside of each door. A fenced corral is located to the left and a fire ring is near the front.

data.title: Wawona Hotel
data.listingDescription: Immersed in nature, Wawona Hotel is the perfect place to settle in during your Yosemite National Park visit.

images.altText: Image of fountain in foreground and hotel in background
images.title: Wawona Hotel
images.caption: Wawona Hotel and Fountain

data.bodyText:
As of December 2, 2024, the Wawona Hotel is closed for a comprehensive condition assessment. The closure follows a recent roof replacement project that uncovered the need for further investigation. Check the website for updates on the reopening date.

One of California's original mountain resort hotels, the Victorian-era Wawona Hotel was originally established in 1856. Accommodations consist of 50 standard hotel rooms with private bath and 54 standard hotel rooms with shared restrooms as well as an on-site dining room serving breakfast, lunch and dinner. 

Galen Clark, a former gold prospector, built the first structure on this site. He built the simple log cabin along the original trail into Yosemite Valley. Visitors would stop along the way to restock their provisions and rest before continuing their travels. From these humble beginnings, the Wawona Hotel eventually attracted many famous travelers of the day, including President Theodore Roosevelt.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Both lodging and dining room are currently closed during the comprehensive condition assessment.

Typically open March to November and several weeks in December. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

The hotel dining room serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. Special holiday meals and barbecues on select weekends may be available. Seasonal amenities include a nine-hole golf course, an outdoor swimming pool, and a riding stable.

For seasonal opening dates and hours see website.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are located on the north side of the hotel behind Hill's Studio. The hotel dining room, lobby, and restrooms are wheelchair accessible. Additionally, there are two accessible guest rooms available.
data.audioDescription: Upon entering the Wawona Hotel area, there is a circular driveway lined with several white buildings. At the far end of the circular driveway, there is a long, white, two-story building that has a sign reading Wawona Hotel. The property is surrounded by tall pine and cedar trees, and has groomed lawns with a few white, wooden chairs scattered about. In the middle of the circular driveway is a grassy area with a fountain that has a paved path surrounding it.

data.title: Wawona Meadow Loop Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Take a relaxing and scenic stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin and gives the opportunity to see wildlife and wildflowers. Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road. You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, s

images.altText: A wooden sign at the intersection of a trail and road reads, "Meadow Loop Trail," and has an arrow pointing to the left.

data.bodyText:
Take a relaxing stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin.

Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road.

You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, so please be courteous of others.

3.5 miles (5.6 km) round trip
1.5 to 2 hours

Hours:
Trail is open year-round

Getting Here:
Begin at the Wawona Hotel, located on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations:
Horses, bikes, and leashed pets are permitted on the trail.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
data.audioDescription: A path from the Wawona Hotel leads across the Wawona Road, past the golf course, to the Meadow Loop trailhead. This mostly flat dirt trail is partially in a forest and partially in open meadow. It is a 3.5 mile loop that goes around the Wawona Meadow, which also contains the golf course.

data.listingDescription: Be enticed by the refreshing aroma of the forest and the sounds of the burbling river while sitting down to a picnic in Wawona. Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not a

images.altText: Picnic tables are located in the shade on the banks of a river.

data.bodyText:
Be enticed by the refreshing aroma of the forest and the sounds of the burbling river while sitting down to a picnic in Wawona.

Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:

Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility:
The Wawona Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible.
data.audioDescription: The Wawona Picnic area is located immediately off the Wawona road, near the Wawona Campground. As you enter the small parking lot, there is a restroom located on the left, along with trash cans. Picnic tables are lined up from left to right, an approximate ten feet from the parking lot. Trees surround the area and a river flows nearby.

data.title: Wawona Stable
data.listingDescription: Beyond hiking, the best way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule ride or horseback riding adventure. Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle.

images.altText: Riders on horses leaving the stable
images.title: Wawona Stable
images.caption: Wawona Stable

data.bodyText:
The Wawona Stable is closed.

Beyond hiking, a fun way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule or horseback riding adventure.

Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle as the ride meanders around the Wawona Meadow.

See website for times, prices, and other requirements.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Approximately May to September, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

Consult with the Wawona Stable staff to discuss potential arrangements for a gentle horse ride around the corral for someone with special needs.
data.audioDescription: As you approach the stable from the parking lot, you pass under a black and white sign that reads, Wawona Hotel Stable. There is a dirt path that leads to the stable office. to the left of the dirt path, there is a corral full of mules and horses before reaching a large, wooden, barn like building that faces to the right and has an American Flag and a sign that reads Big Trees Stable, Riding horses, pack trips.

data.title: Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio
data.listingDescription: Visit the Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).

images.altText: A building with a covered porch, a sign over the door reads "Hill's Studio"
images.title: Hill's Studio
images.caption: Hill's Studio

data.bodyText:
Visit the Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio is closed seasonally from approximately mid October through late May. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

Two designated accessible parking spaces and a mechanical lift are available at the rear of the studio. Use the intercom located next to the lift to request assistance from staff for operation of the lift.
data.audioDescription: The Hill's Studio is a boxy brown building with a long porch along the front. There are five steps that lead up to the entrance. A sign above the porch reads Hill's Studio. There are remnants of an old round fountain, no longer in use, in the front of the studio. Smooth, round, palmsized rocks fill the center of the fountain a quarter way up.

data.title: White Wolf Lodge
data.listingDescription: Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, you'll find tranquility here at the remote and peaceful White Wolf Lodge.

images.altText: Wooden cabin painted white with a covered porch
images.title: White Wolf Lodge
images.caption: White Wolf Lodge

data.bodyText:
White Wolf Lodge will not be operating for the 2025 season.

Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, White Wolf Lodge features 24 canvas-tent cabins and four traditional wood cabins with private baths.

Guests gather morning and evening in the central dining room-a rustic wooden building with a porch that's perfect for relaxing and taking in the views. There is also a small store on site.

See website for more information about the cabins and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

White Wolf Lodge is open seasonally, typically mid-July to early September, conditions permitting.

The dining area, shop, and shower house are currently closed.

See website or the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for amenity hours.

Food Storage Requirements

Guests staying overnight at White Wolf Lodge tent cabins must follow these rules:

  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside your tent cabin or anywhere in the lodge area.
  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash. Guests staying in wood cabins may store their food inside their cabin.
  • Keep your locker closed and latched at all times, just like you would a freezer.
  • Only have the food out that you are actually using; if you're not using it, put it back into the food locker.
  • Treat your trash and recycling like food: keep it in your food locker or dispose of it in a bear-proof dumpster; do not leave it sitting out.
  • During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed).
  • Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time. Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark.
  • When you check out, empty your food locker.
  • Failure to store your food properly may result in impoundment of your food or car and/or a fine of up to $5,000 and/or removal from your campsite or lodging facility.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available. Wheelchair access to the front desk and dining area are via ramp located behind the main building.
data.audioDescription: A white building with a roofed porch and white railings has steps that lead up its center to the front entrance. One large window is on either side of the door. To the far right of the building is a smaller service window. Two large split logs serve as benches at the bottom of the porch, on both sides of the steps. A road is located directly in front of the building and leads to a parking area located to the right side of the building. The road then leads on to the White Wolf Campground. Behind the main building, canvas tents with green wooden doors are randomly spaced out. Each tent has a green food locker to the side of the door. Tall trees surround the area.

data.listingDescription: Visit the Wilderness Center at Big Oak Flat Information Station to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).

images.altText: A low brown building with a wood porch, a sign reads "Big Oak Flat Information Station"
images.title: Big Oak Flat Information Station
images.caption: Big Oak Flat Information Station

data.bodyText:
Visit the Wilderness Center at Big Oak Flat Information Station to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Wilderness Center at Big Oak Flat Information Center is closed seasonally from approximately mid October through late May. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available in front of the facility. The Information Station has an accessible information desk, campground reservation desk, wilderness center, and restrooms. New accessible exhibits are located inside the facility and on the deck.
data.audioDescription: The Big Oak Flat Information Station building is a one-story, long, modular trailer. A fenced accessible ramp ascends across the length of the front of the building onto a deck. A brown metal sign at the top of the ramp reads Big Oak Flat Information Station and has a National Park Service logo. It goes on to read: visitor information, with an icon of a question mark, wilderness permits, with an icon of a person hiking, and bookstore, with an icon of an open book. On the deck, near the side entrance to the information station are two large, grey, metal bins that look like trash bins. Similar signs on both bins read: No trash, bear canister rental return, with an illustration of a bears' head. Next to the information station are restrooms and vending machines, with similar architectual features.

data.listingDescription: Enjoy Yosemite stress free without a car. Save gas, save time, save money, by taking YARTS!The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system that operates year-round in the Yosemite region.YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses. Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road. This particular route

images.altText: A sign with a banner reading "YARTS" in front of a parking area
images.title: Big Oak Flat YARTS stop
images.caption: YARTS stop at Big Oak Flat Information Station

data.bodyText:
This bus stop is served by the Highway 120 West route, connecting Sonora, Jamestown, Groveland, Buck Meadows, and Yosemite Valley. This route operates May-September, seven days a week. See website for schedule.

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system in the Yosemite region. YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses.

Walk-on service is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Walk-on passengers can purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only) or card. Advance reservations can be purchased online. Passengers entering the park on a YARTS bus do not need to pay the park entrance fee; it is included in the bus fare.

Bus Tips & Accessibility

  • Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
  • Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bicycle rentals may be available seasonally in Yosemite Valley.
  • YARTS does not pick up anywhere other than designated stops.
  • No pets are allowed to ride except for service animals.

All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Passengers needing assistance while boarding may request this in advance. Passengers with disabilities as well as their companions or attendants who provide care may purchase tickets at a discounted rate.

Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding to ensure your ride is accessible: 877/989-2787
data.audioDescription: A YARTS sign stands near a roadside pullout along the Big Oak Flat Road, right in front of the Big Oak Flat Information Station parking area and just down the road from the Big Oak Flat Entrance kiosks. The sign reads YARTS, Public Transit to Yosemite. Beneath the icon of a front facing bus, text reads 877-989-2787, www.yarts.com, Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System. On the poll below the sign, at eye height, is a four-sided plastic box that holds the latest route and schedule on each side. Tall trees and shrubs line the roadway.

This bus stop is served by the Highway 120 East/395 route, connecting Mammoth Lakes, Lee Vining, Tuolumne Meadows, and Yosemite Valley. The 120E/395 route operates July-September, seven days a week. See website for schedule.

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system in the Yosemite region. YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses.

Walk-on service is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Walk-on passengers can purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only) or card. Advance reservations can be purchased online. Passengers entering the park on a YARTS bus do not need to pay the park entrance fee; it is included in the bus fare.

Bus Tips & Accessibility

  • Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
  • Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bicycle rentals may be available seasonally in Yosemite Valley.
  • YARTS does not pick up anywhere other than designated stops.
  • No pets are allowed to ride except for service animals.

All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Passengers needing assistance while boarding may request this in advance. Passengers with disabilities as well as their companions or attendants who provide care may purchase tickets at a discounted rate.

Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding to ensure your ride is accessible: 877/989-2787

A brown bench is situated near the YARTS sign, and tall trees give shade to the area.
