data.audioDescription:
A blue and white sign reads YARTS, public transit to yosemite. Below a bus icon it reads (888) 989-2787, www.yarts.com, Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System. Below the YARTS sign is an area to insert current bus schedules. A separate green and white sign reads: Valley Shuttle, Valley Visitor Center, and has the number five, in white font, in a green circle.

Two covered shelters made with wooden beams and a shingled roof, both house two wooden benches. An informational display containing a map is located between the two shelters.

The display is made up of three small text panels that are lined up on top of a large map. The left panel is yellow with a green bar across the top. The text within the green bar reads Shuttle Bus Schedule, Shuttle Stop number five, Visitors Center. The text in the yellow box reads From 7am to 10 am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The middle panel is white with a purple bar across the top. The text within the blue bar reads Shuttle to El Capitan. The text in the white box reads The El Capitan shuttle serves the west end of Yosemite Valley from May through October. Visitors can discover four uncrowded picnic areas, sandy beaches, and great views of climbers on "El Cap." You can hike back to Yosemite Village and Half Dome Village on the Valley Loop Trail, or climb above the Valley on the Four Mile Trail.

Photo: A white shuttle bus with the words Yosemite Shuttle across the side, is on the road in front of El Capitan

Caption: Valley shuttle drivers will be happy to help you with trip and bus transfer information. Photo, Al Golub.

The right panel is white with a blue bar across the top. The text within the blue bar reads Did You Know? The text in the white box reads what is now the Ansel Adams Gallery was first known as Best's Studio. It was owned by the Best family, who let a young Ansel Adams practice on the piano in their home. In 1928, Ansel Adams married Virginia Best here. Today, the gallery offers photography workshops and features Ansel Adams' work, along with other artisans.

Photo: A black and white photo shows a building with a wooden, high-pitched porch roof with stone pillars, and a sign and that reads Bests Studio.

Caption: The building has undergone renovation, but the Ansel Adams Gallery is still located in this 1920s structure. Photo, Yosemite Research Library.

The map shows three different Yosemite Valley shuttle routes. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

A fence runs along the backside of the shelters, separating the paved bus boarding area with a patch of grass. In front of the bus stop sign is a crosswalk that leads across the street to shuttle stop 9. The area is surrounded by black oak trees.

data.title: Yosemite Administration Building Architecture

images.altText: A covered entrance to a two-story building with a stonework first level and shingled second level
images.title: Administration Building
images.caption: Administration Building

data.bodyText:
One of the first buildings constructed in the new village envisioned by Herbert Maier, Myron Hunt, and Thomas Vint, the Park Administration Building was constructed in 1924. Hunt is credited with the design of this particular building, which set the precedent for the similarly designed Post Office and Museum buildings.

Its stone first story and overhanging rustic frame second story reflect the granite canyon walls of the valley surmounted by the conifer forests above the rim.

The Administration Building is not open to public access. One of the first buildings constructed in the new village envisioned by Herbert Maier, Myron Hunt, and Thomas Vint, the Park Administration Building was constructed in 1924. Hunt is credited with the design of this particular building, which set the precedent for the similarly designed Post Office and Museum buildings.

Its stone first story and overhanging rustic frame second story reflect the granite canyon walls of the valley surmounted by the conifer forests above the rim.

The Administration Building is not open to public access.
data.audioDescription: The administration building is a two-story facility, in a wide rectangular shape. The first story is made of granite boulder stonework, while the second story is wood shingle siding that is painted dark brown. Multiple orange framed windows line both the first and second stories. The eastern aspect, facing the pedestrian plaza of Yosemite Village, has an overhanging entryway. The overhanging entry has two stone pillars at either corner, wood paneling under a pitched roof, and a small wooden sign that reads “administration building.” Under the overhang, there is a series of door panels painted the same as the windows. The building is surrounded by mature trees such as black oaks as well as various shrubs.

data.title: Yosemite Bike Share Program
data.listingDescription: The free Yosemite Bike Share opens for the season in late spring, depending on weather and road safety. When it opens, you can use the bike share for short trips (up to two hours) in Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: A row of cruiser-style bikes on a bike rack
images.title: Yosemite Bike Share
images.caption: Yosemite Bike Share hub at Yosemite Village

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite Bike Share is available seasonally, typically from approximately June through October, conditions permitting. When available, you can use the bike share for short trips (up to two hours) in Yosemite Valley. The bicycle sharing program is offered free of charge courtesy of Yosemite Conservancy.

Bike share hubs are available at Yosemite Village (between the Welcome Center and Village Parking) and Camp 4. Bicycles must be picked up and returned at either of these two locations.

Get a Bike

  1. Download the LINKA GO app. (Apple iOS or Google Play) Create an account.
  2. Get a bike: open the app, scan the bike’s QR code found on front of bike basket to unlock bike.
  3. Ride safely! Use the helmet provided with the bike (or wear your own) and stay on roads and paved bike paths. If you ride in the road, you must ride in the same direction as traffic and follow all traffic laws and signs.
  4. Bike shares are limited to two hours. For longer bicycle rentals, visit a Yosemite Hospitality bike stand.

When You Are Done

  1. Return the bike to the station where you picked it up. Be sure to leave the bike in the “Used Bike Corral” area. You must return the bike to a designated bike share hub.
  2. Remember to lock up helmets using the lock inside the basket.
  3. To end your ride and lock the bike, manually close the lock on the rear wheel and press STOP on the app. Double-check that the app has registered the end of the ride before you leave!

Learn more about the bike share program, see a map of bike paths, and plan your routes.

data.title: Yosemite Cemetery
data.listingDescription: Take a few minutes to gaze back into Yosemite's interesting past by wandering through the Yosemite Cemetery.People buried at the Yosemite Cemetery include American Indians, casual park visitors, and people who played important roles in the development of what is now Yosemite National Park. A guide to the Yosemite Cemetery is available to borrow or purchase at the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :located in Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, a

images.altText: Grave markers in a shady, wooded area with walking paths
images.title: Yosemite Cemetery
images.caption: Yosemite Cemetery

data.bodyText:
People buried at the Yosemite Cemetery include American Indians, casual park visitors, and people who played important roles in the development of what is now Yosemite National Park. The last people to be buried in this cemetery were interred in 1956. This cemetery is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

A guide to the Yosemite Cemetery, including information on those buried here, is available to borrow or purchase at the Yosemite Valley Welcome Center.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Respect this historic cemetery by staying on designated paths.

The Yosemite Cemetery is open year-round, 24 hours a day.

Accessibility

The cemetery is not wheelchair accessible. Surfaces are flat, unpaved, and irregular, and may be accessible to those using other mobility aids.
data.audioDescription: The entrance to Yosemite Cemetery is marked by a wooden sign held up with two posts, and reads Yosemite Cemetery . A dirt path leads into the cemetery, with a zig-zagged wooden fence on both sides of the path. The cemetery is full of Cedar trees, a few black oak trees and ponderosa pines, and a couple of giant sequoia trees. The scenery opens up to allow views of Upper Yosemite Fall. About 20 to 30 headstones and wooden memorial markers are scattered throughout the cemetery. Some granite headstones are in the form of obelisks, crosses, and the common rounded top tablet.

data.title: Yosemite Chapel
data.listingDescription: The Yosemite Chapel, the oldest structure in Yosemite Valley, has been a place of worship, teaching, fellowship, and weddings for residents and visitors alike for over 140 years. The chapel was listed on the prestigious National Register of Historic Places in 1973.The Yosemite Chapel was originally erected near where the present Four Mile trailhead is located today.

images.altText: A simple, red-brown building with a steeply pitched roof and a steeple
images.title: Yosemite Chapel
images.caption: Yosemite Chapel

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite Chapel, the oldest building in Yosemite Valley, was built with funds from the California State Sunday School Association in the summer of 1879. The National Park Service acquired the building in 1927.

The Yosemite Chapel was originally built near the present-day Four Mile Trailhead. In 1901, the chapel was relocated to its present location. In 1965 some interior restoration was completed, and the foundation was raised 3 feet to help protect the structure from periodic flooding. In spite of these efforts, the chapel sustained damage during the historic 1997 flood and required further restoration.

With a few minor exceptions, the Yosemite Chapel has been the park's sole church facility since its construction over 140 years ago. Purportedly, Yosemite Chapel services began June 7, 1879. In 1973, the chapel was listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Operating Hours & Seasons

The Yosemite Chapel operates year-round. Spiritual services are held every Sunday morning as well as special services on some holidays. Alcoholics Anonymous meetings are also held regularly at the chapel.

For service times, see the website the current issue of the Yosemite Guide.

Information on weddings at the Yosemite Chapel is available online.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The chapel is wheelchair accessible by way of a wheelchair lift (elevator) on the east side of the building near the parking area.
data.audioDescription: The Chapel is a wooden structure with a steeply pitched roof, and is painted red with orange doors and trim. There is a small set of 8 steps that lead up to the front doors. One vertical, rectangular, 8-paned window is on both sides of the doorway. A tall steeple rises up off the steep roof. A cement pathway starting from the steps in front of the chapel, splits and leads to the parking lot on the side of the chapel, and also to a crosswalk in front of the church. Trees surround the backside of the chapel, and a large rock face rises up behind.

data.title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center
data.listingDescription: Peruse through the library or attend an evening program at the Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, Yosemite's first public visitor center and a National Historic Landmark. The Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, was built by the Sierra Club starting in 1903. For over 110 years, a curator and Sierra Club volunteers have provided information to park visitors about Yosemite, the Sierra Nevada, and the national parks.

images.altText: A rustic stone building with a central peak and gabled roofs on either side
images.title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center
images.caption: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center

data.bodyText:
Peruse through the library or attend an evening program at the Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, Yosemite's first public visitor center and a National Historic Landmark.

The Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, formerly known as LeConte Memorial Lodge, was built by the Sierra Club starting in 1903. The Sierra Club still operates the iconic structure as a public education and visitor center. Explore history exhibits, browse the reference library, enjoy the kids' corner, or attend an evening program.

The collection includes books on the natural and human history of Yosemite and the Sierra Nevada; books by and about Yosemite luminaries like John Muir, Ansel Adams, and David Brower; children's nature literature, and Sierra Club books, magazine, and pamphlets.

Free evening programs on natural history, outdoor adventure, and conservation issues are offered regularly in summer. See current Yosemite Guide or the Sierra Club website for program schedule.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open Wednesday - Sunday, 10 am - 4 pm. Open seasonally from May to September. See current Yosemite Guide for hours.

Accessibility

This building is not wheelchair accessible. There are eight stone steps leading to the building entrance; there are no handrails. Inside, there are two steps down to access the lower area of the library.
data.audioDescription: The granite stone masonry and steep-pitched roof are unlike any other building in the park. The building captures the color, texture, and verticality of the Yosemite Valley walls. As you approach the facility, the center section of the building rises up to a steep point, and two smaller wings are built slightly inward on each side. A stonewall extends off the ends of each wing, slanted inward as well, creating a hexagonal structural layout. Steps lead to the center of the hexagonal layout, a small porch area, up to the front, wooden, pointed arched, door. Four windows line the front side of the building. At the end of the right stone porch wall, a bronze plaque is adhered to the granite, and it reads, LeConte Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987. National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior.

data.title: Yosemite Creek Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Let the cool breeze of the high-country and the soothing sounds of nature make for an enjoyable time at this shady picnic spot along Yosemite Creek.Five picnic tables line the perimeter of the driveway, beneath a canopy of pine trees and near the Yosemite Creek. Hours :Approximately late May or early June to sometime in November. Getting Here :Located along Tioga Road, a few miles east of White Wolf Road. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas are available on a first-come, fir

images.altText: Picnic tables underneath the shade of tall pine trees
images.title: Yosemite Creek picnic area
images.caption: Yosemite Creek picnic area

data.bodyText:
This small, quiet picnic area sits alongside Yosemite Creek under the shade of pine trees. Parking is very limited.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

Yosemite Creek Picnic Area features one accessible picnic table with an extended top, and an accessible vault toilet. Surfaces in the area around the picnic tables may be unpaved and uneven. There are no designated accessible parking spaces.
data.audioDescription: Five picnic tables line the permiter of this paved, loop driveway. The picnic tables are nestled beneath a canopy of tall pine trees, next to the Yosemite Creek. Granite boulders ranging from basketball-size to snowmobile-size and larger, are strewn about the area. Two green recycle bins and two brown trash bins sit at the far end of the loop driveway from the entrance. A small brown structure houses a vault toilet near the entrance. There is no designated parking lot.

data.title: Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley. John Muir once described Ten Lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest."

images.altText: Snowy peaks above conifer forest and dark blue lakes
images.title: Ten Lakes Pass
images.caption: Ten Lakes Basin viewed from Ten Lakes Pass

data.bodyText:
On the north side of Tioga Road, an unpaved parking lot sits next to the Ten Lakes trailhead. Directly across the street, on the south side of Tioga Road, there is a paved parking area as well as the Yosemite Creek trailhead.

Ten Lakes

To reach the lakes, follow this trail through conifers and across granite to cross a tributary of Yosemite Creek. Continue on the trail to Ten Lakes Pass, the headwaters of Yosemite Creek, overlooking the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne and the Sierra Crest. Descend 693 feet (211 m) into the Ten Lakes Basin, returning the way you came.

Distance: 12.6 mi (20.3 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 2,200 ft (671 m)
Time estimate: 7-9 hours

Route variations: For a shorter hike with slightly less elevation change, turn around at the view at Ten Lakes Pass instead. To see even more lakes, take a side trip to Grant Lakes via a 1-mile spur (each way) below Ten Lakes Pass.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Both trails include unbridged stream crossings. Early in the season, when water can be very high, cold, and swift, use caution when crossing streams or turn back when crossing is not safe.

Bicycles and pets are not permitted on hiking trails. Vault toilets are available at the Yosemite Creek trailhead parking area.

Both trailheads are only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).
data.audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, four brown food lockers, a facility holding two vault toilets, one wayside exhibit and one map. Trees and granite bedrock surround the area. A dirt lot is located across the street, which is also where the trailhead for Ten Lakes is located. The trailhead for Yosemite Creek is at the north end of the parking area, marked by a metal sign that reads Yosemite Creek Trail and has an arrow pointing forward.

The wayside exhibit shows a faded, black and white, close-up, background photo of a full waterfall. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, rocks, ice, and water - standing here near Yosemite Creek, one feels only a hint of the power that this busy but unassuming waterway will possess by the time it reaches the floor of Yosemite Valley.

The rocky Yosemite Creek watershed, which slopes downhill to the rim of Yosemite Valley about eight miles away, encompasses some fifty square miles of Yosemite's high country. Carved by tributary glaciers about 20,000 years ago, the V-shaped Yosemite Creek drainage was enlarged by the heavy volume of water and `ice which rushed through as the glacier retreated. Today, as spring snow melts, an average of 2,400 gallons per second of icy runoff is funneled through this hanging valley before plunging over the vertical cliff 2,425 feet to Yosemite Valley below.

Photo: A river with white water flows toward a precipice. Granite bedrock and trees are along the banks. A rock formation blanketed in snow is at the far end of the river.

Caption: Yosemite Creek plunging over the top of Yosemite Falls.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, Yosemite Creek Trail, for hiking and trail information, please visit a Visitor Center or Information Station. This strenuous 16-mile out-and-back trail drops about 2.6 miles through lodgepole pine stands before joining the trail from the Yosemite Creek Campground. The trial continues to parallel Yosemite Creek for another 3.3 miles below. Follow the signs to the overlook at Yosemite Point, a short distance to the east, for a glimpse of the breathtaking drop into Yosemite Valley and across the High Sierra. Use caution, wet rocks can be slippery.

Map: A tall, rectangular map of the surrounding area, shows a horizontal, squiggly, grey line near the top of the map, crossing from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." A dotted diagonal line extends downard and slightly to the left from the red dot, representing the Yosemite Creek Trail. Along the trail, Yosemite Creek Campground and the top of Yosemite Falls are labeled. At the bottom of the dotted line is Yosemite Valley. Upper Yosemite Fall and Lower Yosemite Fall are represented by a series of three blue lines stacked on top of one another, each line shorter than the one above it. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

Photo: A black and white aerial photo shows a three tier waterfall coming over a large rock wall. The upper fall is the longest of the three, the middle cascade the shortest. The lower fall is half the height of the upper fall.

Caption: V-shaped Yosemite Creek watershed and Yosemite Falls.

A map labeled, The Tioga Road, is on a sign board inside a wooden frame. The map shows the entire park with emphasis only on the Tioga Road, which is a red, solid, squiggly line that crosses the map from left to right, midway down the map. Major areas, beginning from the left include Crane Flat, which has icons indicating restrooms, groceries, gas, campground, and two sequioa groves that are in the area. A bit to the right is Tamarack Flat Campground. A quarter of the way across the map is White Wolf, which has icons indicating a campground, dining, and hiking are in that area. About one-third of the way across the map is Yosemite Creek, which has a red dot and text that reads, "you are here." This area is labeled with Hiking, restrooms, and picnic icons. Halfway across the map are Olmsted Point, which has no services, and Tenaya Lake, which has multiple hiking, picnic, and restroom icons in the area. About two-thirds of the way across the map is Tuolumne Meadows, which has icons indicating camping, dining, restrooms, groceries, a wilderness center, and hiking, which includes Cathedral Lakes and Lembert Dome. Near the right side of the map, past Tuolumne Meadows, Mono Pass, a hiking destination, and Tioga Pass, the east entrance and exit to the park, are found along Tioga Road. The road then continues down to the first town outside the park, Lee Vining. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

data.title: Yosemite Exploration Center
data.listingDescription: Formerly the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, the newly designed Yosemite Exploration Center hosts numerous exhibits, some interactive, for a fun learning experience for the entire family.

images.altText: A single story building with glass doors framed by large rock walls on both sides
images.title: Yosemite Exploration Center
images.caption: Learn more about Yosemite's many treasures!

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite Exploration Center (formerly the Valley Visitor Center) is a family-friendly space that includes interactive displays and exhibits highlighting Yosemite's many stories and resources. Learn more about Yosemite's history, the people who originally called this place home, as well as more about meadows, animals, and sequoias! The Yosemite Conservancy bookstore located inside offers books, apparel, and gifts.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round, 9 am to 5 pm daily.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. A small number of designated accessible parking spaces are available just west of the Yosemite Museum. Numerous exhibit panels feature tactile relief elements along with several tactile exhibits. Parts of the exhibit hall feature audio elements.
data.audioDescription: The former visitor center building is comprised of stone and wood. There are multiple doors to enter the building, with concrete and asphalt leading to the building itself. Once inside, the floors are concrete, there is a welcome desk immediately in the center, with exhibits surrounding it.

data.title: Yosemite Exploration Center (formerly, Valley Visitor Center) Architecture

images.altText: A single story building with glass doors framed by large rock walls on both sides
images.title: Yosemite Exploration Center
images.caption: Yosemite Exploration Center

data.bodyText:
Originally serving as the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, this building was completed in 1967. For many decades, it included an information desk, exhibits, and retail space in its primary building. Attached buildings include two multi-purpose auditoriums, still in use, surrounding a small plaza.

The low, wide front elevation of the visitor center, as well as several accent walls on the interior and exterior, feature stones from the Merced River embedded into concrete slabs. These natural, local design details harmonize both visually and ideologically with nearby rustic buildings. The auditoriums behind the main visitor center are larger, plain structures not easily visible from the main visitor plaza spaces.

This building now houses exhibits and retail space managed by Yosemite Conservancy. Visitor information services moved to the Welcome Center in 2023.
data.audioDescription: Yosemite Valley Visitor Center is a single story building, made of granite stones and wooden planks. The front side of the building has two sets of double-doors with a bench sitting between both entrances. A wooden awning extends out over the entrances. Above the awning is a sign that reads Yosemite Visitor Center and Theater. To the left of the door, on the stone siding, is the National Park Service Logo, which is a brown, downward facing arrowhead, with a green sequoia tree, a white bison at the bottom, a white lake to the right middle, and a white mountain peak across the mid-section. Above the white peak, it reads National Park Service.

data.title: Yosemite Exploration Center Theater
data.listingDescription: Take in a film about Yosemite during your trip at the Yosemite Theater, located behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. The Spirit of Yosemite, is shown daily on the hour and the half hour in the theater behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. The first showing is at 9:30am, and the last showing is at 4pm, except on Sundays, when the first showing is at noon.

images.altText: A concrete building with steel beams that create a covered entry over glass double doors
images.title: Yosemite Exploration Center Theater
images.caption: Yosemite Exploration Center Theater

data.bodyText:
The theater shows Yosemite's park film, The Spirit of Yosemite, daily on the hour and the half hour in the theater behind the Yosemite Exploration Center. Audio description and foreign language headsets are available from the exploration center information desk.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round, 9:00 am to 4:30 pm daily. The first film showing begins at 9:30 am and the last begins at 4:00 pm. Showings begin on the hour and half hour during open hours.

Accessibility

  • There is a wheelchair accessible path to the theater through the exploration center, or via a sidewalk to the left of the exploration center.
  • The Spirit of Yosemite is both captioned and audio described. Ask at the information desk for an assistive listening device.
  • Wheelchair accessible restrooms are located in the building to the west of the exploration center.
  • A few designated accessible parking spaces are available just west of the nearby Yosemite Museum.
data.audioDescription: The building that houses the Yosemite Exploration Center and Theater, arcs halfway around a courtyard in the back of the facility. The tail end of the building is where the theater is located. It is a simple cement building with a covered walkway lining the front of the theater and extending to the exhibit hall of the exploration center. There are double glass doors that lead visitors into the theater.

data.title: Yosemite Falls Parking
data.listingDescription: Park your car and hit the trails or hop on the free Yosemite Valley Shuttle to see the sites in Yosemite Valley. Open year-round from dawn to dusk. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, near shuttle bus stops 7 and E2. Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.

images.altText: Cars parked in a large lot at dusk
images.title: Yosemite Falls Parking
images.caption: Yosemite Falls Parking

data.bodyText:
This parking area along Northside Drive provides access to trailheads and the Valleywide shuttle. Electric vehicle charging is also available in this parking area.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Sleeping in vehicles or campers of any kind is not allowed in this parking area. Park in designated spaces only. Driving or parking on vegetation is prohibited.

During the busy summer season, especially on weekends, parking fills early and heavy traffic is common in Yosemite Valley. Arrive early to increase your chances of finding parking and avoiding traffic delays, then use the free shuttle system to get around Yosemite Valley.

During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed). Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark: use the food lockers available near the entrance to this parking area.

Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time.

Accessibility

Designated accessible spaces are available on the north side of the parking area near the entrance.
data.audioDescription: The Yosemite Falls Parking lot is a dirt lot located at the west end of Yosemite Valley Lodge and across the street from Camp 4. There are two rows of parking that run parallel to the main road, Northside Drive. A third row of parking, furthest from the main road, is reserved for oversided vehicles and buses. All parking spaces are unmarked. Trees surround the area. Views of Upper Yosemite Falls can be seen through the trees.

data.title: Yosemite Falls Parking EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located at the northeast corner of the Yosemite Falls Day Use Parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 10 level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

images.altText: A row of EV charging stations along the edge of a parking lot next to a dirt area
images.title: Yosemite Falls EV Charging Station
images.caption: Yosemite Falls EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located at the northeast corner of the Yosemite Falls Day Use Parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 10 level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the northeastern corner of a large parking lot, there is a row of 20 standard-sized parking stalls in front of 10 electric vehicle charging stations. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. The stations are located just behind the parking stalls. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." Behind the charging stations is an unpaved dirt area.

data.title: Yosemite History Center
data.listingDescription: Go back to a time of horse-drawn wagons, a covered bridge, and log cabins. A visit to the Yosemite History Center explores Yosemite's history and explains how Yosemite was the inspiration for national parks across America and around the world. The Yosemite History Center consists of historic structures from different eras of Yosemite history.

images.altText: Horse drawn stage coming through covered bridge with passengers
images.title: Yosemite History Center
images.caption: Horse drawn stage coming through the Wawona Covered Bridge with passengers

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite History Center is a collection of historic buildings where outdoor interpretive signs tell the stories of people who moved here from around the world and shaped the park’s development. During the summer, visit exhibits inside the Chinese Laundry and the Acting Superintendent's Office, take a ride on our horse-drawn wagon, or watch blacksmiths forge iron tools on a coal forge! Check the Yosemite Guide for details.

Many of the buildings that make up the Yosemite History Center were moved to Wawona in the 1950s and '60s from various locations throughout the park. These buildings were moved to make way for more modern park facilities and to create an area to interpret Yosemite's history. The History Center commemorates the efforts of people, the events they experienced, and the issues they faced during the establishment of Yosemite as a national park.

Seasonal Information

Open year-round. Informational signs are found in front of each building.

Accessibility

Paths within the complex have a dirt surface. An accessible restroom is located near the parking lot. There is no designated accessible parking. Parking near the Wawona Store and Pioneer Gift Shop provides the best access; the paved route includes a portion with an 8.1% slope.
data.audioDescription: From the paved parking area near the Wawona Store and Pioneer Gift Shop, there is a path that leads across a street and beneath a sign that reads Yosemite History Center...a place of pioneers who so profoundly influenced the birth and growth of the National Park Idea. A flat, dirt path passes by a shed filled with 8 plus old stagecoaches. At the end of the shed is the intersection of an old stagecoach road. Taking the road to the right will lead you to the Gray Barn, and taking the road to the left will lead you through a covered bridge that sits over a stream. At the other side of the bridge is a small loop trail, lined with wooden pioneer-era buildings. There is a sign that instructs you to take the trail to the left, leading you to a clock-wise tour of the trail. In order of appearance, the trail takes you by Artist Cabin, Anderson Cabin, Homestead Cabin, Blacksmith Shop, Cavalry Office, Ranger Patrol Cabin, Degnan's Bakery, Wells Fargo Office, and the Powderhouse and Jail, before it loops back to the covered bridge.

data.title: Yosemite Medical Clinic
data.listingDescription: Protecting, Promoting, and Fostering Health and Wellness in Yosemite National Park, welcome to the Yosemite Medical Clinic. In the case of an emergency, dial 911. See website for the Yosemite Medical Clinic Notice of Privacy Practice and for information regarding methods of payment and insurance. Open year-round, closed on federal holidays. Located in Yosemite Valley, between Yosemite Village and The Ahwahnee.

images.altText: A wood multi-story building with a chimney and covered walkway in front of a waterfall
images.title: Yosemite Medical Clinic
images.caption: Yosemite Medical Clinic

data.bodyText:
Managed and operated by the National Park Service (NPS), the clinic is staffed by U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps (USPHS) and NPS healthcare providers. We offer basic medical care including primary care and urgent care for both residents and visitors.

The clinic is not an emergency room. If you have a medical emergency, text or call 911.

Services include, but are not limited to, primary care such as physical exams and immunizations, urgent care for evaluation and treatment of illness, injury care such as fractures and cuts, limited in-house laboratory services, and diagnostic services such as X-ray and spirometry. See website for a more detailed list of services available.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round, hours may vary seasonally. Services are available both by appointment and on a walk-in basis for urgent care. See website for appointment and urgent care hours.

To make an appointment, call 209/372-4637. For medical emergencies, text or call 911.

Limited insurance accepted. Please plan to pay out of pocket if you have out-of-state insurance. See website for payment information and insurance accepted.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces and accessible entrance are located behind the building.
data.audioDescription: This wood and stone building is set back away from the main road, Ahwahnee Drive, up a gravel driveway. Trees surround the property and The Upper Yosemite Fall is its backdrop. Three signs line the drive way and parking area. One sign reads Medical Clinic and has a square icon with a red cross in the center. The second sign reads Patient Parking Only. The third sign reads Patient Entrance and has an arrow pointing to the right. Monday through friday, 9am to 5pm. After Hour Emergencies dial 9 1 1. Emergency phone located at rear entrance. A square icon with a phone in its center is located to the left of Dial 9 1 1. A handicap symbol is followed by text that reads access in rear. A square icon with a bus in its center and a red slash across the icon is followed by text that reads No oversize vehicles beyond this point.

data.title: Yosemite Museum
data.listingDescription: Explore the cultural history of Yosemite Indians and watch daily traditional demonstrations, tour the art gallery, or take a self-guiding tour through an outdoor Indian Village, at the Yosemite Museum. The Yosemite Museum has displays that interpret the cultural history of Yosemite's native Miwok and Paiute people from 1850 to the present, demonstrations of stone tool making, basket-weaving, beadwork, and traditional games.

images.altText: Yosemite Museum building with wood bark house to the left of the main door
images.title: Yosemite Museum
images.caption: Yosemite Museum entrance

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite Museum exhibits interpret the cultural history of Yosemite's native Miwok and Paiute people from 1850 to the present, demonstrations of stone tool making, basket-weaving, beadwork, and traditional games.

In front of the museum is a cross-section of a giant sequoia tree that visitors can touch and a re-creation of an umacha, a Miwok and Paiute cedar bark house. Behind the Yosemite Museum, follow a self-guiding, wheelchair-accessible trail through the re-constructed Indian Village of Ahwahnee, and learn about the significant plants and structures. Interpretive rangers are available to provide additional information.

The adjoining gallery is open periodically and often exhibits art pieces from the Yosemite Museum collection and other artists. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for current exhibits. A small gift shop is located inside featuring books, handcrafts, and jewelry.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round, 10 am to 5 pm daily in summer and 10 am to 4 pm in winter. May close for lunch. See the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Building entrances do not have automated entrances. Some benches are located in the lobby and just outside the north entrance. A few designated accessible parking spaces are available just west of the museum.
data.audioDescription: The building that houses the Yosemite Museum is a two story facility. The first story is made of granite boulder stonework, while the second story is wood shingle siding that is painted dark brown. Multiple orange framed windows line the second story. Above the arched entranceway is a wooden sign that reads museum. The entrance has double wooden doors with glass panes containing a few flyers. To the right of the entrance is a large slab of a giant sequoia trunk, about 9 feet in diameter. A sign reads Big Tree, sequoiadendron giganteum. This nine foot section of a giant sequoia was cut 30 feet from the base of a tree that fell in the Mariposa Grove in 1919. Annual rings show the tree's to be 996 years old, but at the base of the tree, where the diameter was 14 feet, the age was found to be 1,100 years. One of the largest trees in the Mariposa Grove, the Grizzly Giant, has been estimated to be 1790 years old. These big trees should not be confused with the coast redwood, Sequoia sempervirens, which is utilized commercially. Both are sequoias, part of the redwood family of trees, but the giant sequoia Sequoia giganteum, is native only to the western slope of the Sierra Nevada. The coast redwood grows along the Pacific coast from the Monterey Peninsula to southwestern Oregon. The fossil record indicates that over forty species of the redwood family once existed in the Northern Hemisphere. Eighteen species survive to the present, three of which have the name sequoia. There are nine small green arrows tags pointing at rings in the tree, progressing from the oldest, inner ring to the outer, most recent ring. The first tag near the center of the sequoia trunk slab reads A.D. 323, the next tag to the right reads 1066 Battle of Hastings, the next tag reads 1215 Magna Carta, the next tag, which is about two-thirds of the way from the center, reads 1492 Landing of Columbus, the next tag reads 1620 Landing of Pilgrims, and the next tag reads 1776 Declaration of Independence. The next three tags skirt around the outter edge of the slab and they read 1860 Civil War, 1864 Lincoln signed Yosemite Grant, and 1890 Yosemite National Park. To the left of the entrance is an Ahwahneechee Umacha, a traditional dwelling for Yosemite Indians, made up of long cedar planks stacked in a conical shape.

data.title: Yosemite National Park

images.altText: Black and white of rocky mountain top covered with snow and trees spread out on top
images.title: Yosemite National Park
images.caption: Yosemite National Park, Job #08204, CA

relatedParks.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

tags: frederick law olmsted national historic site
data.bodyText:
Frederick Law Olmsted didn’t arrive at Yosemite for a vacation but was here to work; he took over as the general manager for the Mariposa gold-mining estate. Many thought he was crazy to leave behind his landscape architecture work, and his father made sure Frederick knew his displeasure over the move. However, at the time no one could have known that this move would set the stage for the creation of parks from the natural domain.

A year after his move to California, the state had secured a grant deeming Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Big Tree Grove inalienable parkland. A commission was formed to oversee the creation of the public preserve, with Olmsted serving as Superintendent and Chairman.

Another year would pass before Olmsted wrote his report on Yosemite Valley and Mariposa, stressing the uniqueness of the valley, not because of the towering cliffs, but because of the union of the entire landscape, and the experience of taking it all in, uninterrupted.

Olmsted wrote his report for Yosemite and Mariposa with a distinct eye for the times; the Civil War was over and he was expanding upon Lincoln’s vision for a broader, more inclusive interpretation of democracy as he wrote the foundation for our national park system.

Like father, like son, Olmsted Jr. would join in on his father’s fight 50 years later when asked to refine his father’s work and address the need for a new bureau to manage scattered parks and monuments. This would start a 6-year correspondence, culminating in Jr.’s writing of the Organic Act, which would help solidify the creation of the NPS, keeping great natural wonders in the hands of the people.

Source: "Yosemite National Park," The Cultural Landscape Foundation

For more information and primary resources, please visit:
Olmsted Research Guide Online
Olmsted Archives on Flickr
Olmsted Online

data.title: Yosemite Transportation Office
data.listingDescription: Yosemite Valley was the center for most visitor services. The Yosemite Transportation Office was constructed in Yosemite Valley in 1910 by the Yosemite Valley Railroad Company as a transportation terminal and telecommunications hub. Visitors arriving by horse-drawn or auto stage used this office to make railroad and lodging reservations, place long-distance phone calls, or send telegrams.

images.altText: Wooden transportation office building with horse drawn stage and passengers in foreground
images.title: Yosemite Transportation Office
images.caption: Yosemite Transportation Office

data.bodyText:
The Yosemite Transportation Office was constructed in Yosemite Valley in 1910 by the Yosemite Valley Railroad Company as a transportation terminal and telecommunications hub.

Starting in 1907, Yosemite-bound tourists could ride the railroad from Merced to El Portal, just outside the park, eliminating the bumpy, dusty, two-day stage ride. However, the final fourteen-mile leg of the journey from El Portal to Yosemite Valley was still made by stage, and later by autos.

Upon arrival at this terminal in Yosemite Valley, passengers could book a stay in a hotel and make transportation arrangements with travel agents, who lived in the building’s back rooms. Despite its rustic design, the office provided modern conveniences. Visitors could make telephone calls or send telegrams to anywhere in the world. By 1914, automobiles were common in Yosemite, and in that year, horse-drawn stage service was discontinued. However, annual visitation to the park in 1915 doubled to 31,000. Consequently, stage operation was renewed but only for one additional year. In 1916, the era of stage travel ended and another began. The National Park Service, a federal agency created to preserve and manage our country's national parks, was established.

The reliance on transportation companies for park access diminished greatly when the All-Year Highway (now California Highway 140) opened in 1927, and personal cars soon became the dominant means of transportation in Yosemite.
data.audioDescription: The front of this wooden building has a windowed door in the center and two windows on either side of the door. The windows have a multitude of horizontal diamond-shaped window panes that are lined with white trim. There is a long green bench on each side of the door, and three wooden steps leading up to the door. A wooden sign above the doorway reads "Yosemite Transportation Company, Wells Fargo and Company Express " painted in yellow. This structure has a large A-frame roof.

data.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge
data.listingDescription: Yosemite Valley Lodge's close proximity to Yosemite Falls makes it the perfect base camp for exploring Yosemite National Park.

images.altText: A road leads to a lit building with many windows and a covered entryway
images.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Lodge registration building

data.bodyText:
Yosemite Valley Lodge features 245 rooms, including wheelchair-accessible, family, bunk, and traditional rooms. The lodge offers multiple dining options and a gift shop. An outdoor pool (seasonal), bicycle rental (seasonal), electric vehicle charging, and tour desk are also on-site. See website for more information and to make a reservation.

Located near the base of Yosemite Falls, Yosemite Valley Lodge began welcoming guests in an old Army barracks building in 1915. Most of the lodge buildings were rebuilt in the 1950s and 60s as part of Mission 66, a nationwide effort to revitalize the national parks.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Yosemite Valley Lodge is open year-round. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

Dining & Shopping

All shopping and dining is located around a central courtyard directly behind the lodge registration desk.

Base Camp Eatery. Fast casual, food court-style dining offering a variety of cuisines. Indoor and outdoor seating.

Starbucks Coffee. Located adjacent to Base Camp Eatery, offering a variety of espresso, coffee, tea, and other beverages as well as pastries, gifts, and grab-and-go items. No seating available, visitors may use Base Camp Eatery seating.

Mountain Room Restaurant. Upscale casual steakhouse serving dinner. Indoor seating. Reservations recommended via OpenTable.com.

Mountain Room Lounge. Cocktail lounge. beer on tap, and light dining. Indoor and outdoor seating.

Gift Shop. Selection of convenience items and gifts.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for dining and shopping hours.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select rooms are wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in front of the registration office and near pathways leading to lodge rooms.
data.audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge property is made up of three main buildings that contain the front desk, four dining options, a gift shop, and two meeting rooms. These three main buildings are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, with an outdoor amphitheater in the middle. There are also 15 other buildings on property that contain anywhere from 8 to 35 guest rooms per building.

Approaching the front of the main building, which contains the front desk, there is a porte coÂ·chÃ¨re that extends across almost the entire front facade of the building. Three steps on either the left or the right side of a raised porch lead to the entrance, two double-doors located in the center of the buildings' facade. A wooden sign to the right of the doors reads Yosemite Valley Lodge, while a wooden sign above the doors reads Welcome. A blue U.S. Postal Service mail box is also located on the porch to the right of the doors, as well as a bench, just down the steps. A accessible ramp is located to the right of the building.

data.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand
data.listingDescription: Biking is one of the best ways to see Yosemite Valley. Yosemite Valley is flat, which makes for easy riding along our 12 miles of designated paths. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. We also offer a select number of tandem bikes and hand-crank bikes for guests with physical limitations. Wheelchairs, electric scooters, and strollers may also be available for rent.

images.altText: Bikes lined up at the rental facility at Yosemite Valley Lodge
images.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand

data.bodyText:
With miles of designated bike paths, Yosemite Valley offers ample opportunity for easy riding. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, child trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. All rental bikes are first-come, first-served. Reservations are only available for bicycles intended for people with disabilities. A limited number of wheelchairs and motorized scooters are available at this location.

See website for rates.

Bicycles are not permitted on hiking trails. Ride on paved bicycle paths only. Cyclists that choose to ride on roads must ride with traffic and obey all traffic laws and signs.

Operating Hours & Seasons

See website for hours, or call 209/372-1208. Bicycle rentals are available daily spring through fall, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

A limited number of tandem and hand-crank bicycles as well as wheelchairs and motorized scooters are available for rent and may be reserved in advance by calling 209/372-1208.

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
data.audioDescription: The Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand operates out of a small, brown, wood-paneled kiosk. It is located near the pool, behind the main Yosemite Valley Lodge complex. Rows of bikes are parked side by side within a chain linked fence. The bikes are a variety of colors and range in size from larger adult-sized bikes, to smaller child-sized bikes, to tandem bikes, and bikes with trailers for children.

data.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located at the Yosemite Valley Lodge, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers in front of the Alder building as well as four additional level 2 chargers between the Laurel and Juniper buildings. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

images.altText: A parking lot with one truck and several EV charging stations as sun peeks through tall trees
images.title: Yosemite Lodge West EV Charging Station
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Lodge EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located at the Yosemite Valley Lodge, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers in front of the Alder building as well as four additional level 2 chargers between the Laurel and Juniper buildings. These chargers have a J1772 connector. You do not need to be a guest at the lodge to charge your vehicle.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the back row of a small parking lot, there are four standard-sized parking stalls in front of two electric vehicle charging stations. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. The stations are located about three feet from the curb in between the adjacent parking stalls. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." Behind the charging stations is a sidewalk that runs perpendicular to the parking stalls. A short distance (about 400 feet) to the west, along the sidewalk, there is an identical set of charging stations at the edge of a larger parking lot.

data.title: Yosemite Valley Welcome Center EV Charging Station
data.listingDescription: Located in the parking lot on the east side of the Yosemite Valley Welcome Center, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector.

images.altText: Several vehicles charging at a station in a parking lot with trees and cliffs towering behind
images.title: Welcome Center EV Charging Station
images.caption: Welcome Center EV Charging Station

data.bodyText:
Located in the parking lot on the east side of the Yosemite Valley Welcome Center, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.
data.audioDescription: At the northeastern edge of a large parking area, there are four standard-sized parking stalls in front of two electric vehicle charging stations. Each station is a narrow post about five feet tall with two boxes on the sides for two separate charging ports. The stations are located behind the curb next to the parking stalls on a small concrete footer within an unpaved, vegetated area. Each port has a long black cord with one end plugged into the station as a power source and the other end with a connector, which can be hung on the side of the port when not in use. The front of each port has a screen with charging information and above the screen is the word "Rivian". Next to each charging station are two cylindrical metal posts about three feet tall to protect the station from damage. Next to both stations there is a metal sign on a post that reads: "Vehicle Charging Station. This vehicle charging station is made possible through the generosity of Rivian, Adopt A Charger, and Yosemite Conservancy with the support of Yosemite Hospitality." At the northern boundary of the parking stalls is a small storage structure about the same length as the parking stalls.

data.title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center
data.listingDescription: Visit the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).

images.altText: A rustic brown building with large beams and posts, a shingled roof top and shingled siding
images.title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center

data.bodyText:
Visit the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center is closed seasonally from approximately late-October through mid-April. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located behind the post office which is adjacent to the Wilderness Center.
data.audioDescription: A rustic brown building with large beams and posts, a shingled roof top and shingled siding, serves as the Yosemite Wilderness Center. Large picture windows are framed with varnished logs, and the rest of the building also has split log trim. A large grey bear canister return bin sits under the porch as well as a bench. A large sign hangs from the porch rafters by chains and reads Yosemite Wilderness Center, with a circular logo that reads Yosemite Wilderness, National Wilderness Preservation System on the left, and the National Park Service logo to the right. The single door entrance is framed in wood and is painted orange.

data.title: Yosemite Village Parking
data.listingDescription: If you're visiting Yosemite Valley for the day, look for parking in the Yosemite Village Parking. This lot is centrally located to lodging, dining, and recreation in Yosemite Valley. Free shuttle service to destinations throughout Yosemite Valley is available from here. Once you find a place to park, please leave your car parked.

images.altText: Vehicles line a paved parking area with a large granite formation in the background
images.title: Yosemite Village Parking
images.caption: Yosemite Village Parking

data.bodyText:
This large parking area is centrally located near the Welcome Center, dining, and recreation in Yosemite Valley. A shuttle stop is located next to the parking area.

This lot cannot be reached by vehicle if taking the left turn over Sentinel Bridge on Southside Drive. Follow signs to Yosemite Village instead.

Tips & Seasonal Information

There is a restroom with flush toilets available next to this parking area.

Sleeping in vehicles or campers of any kind is not allowed in this parking area. Park in designated spaces only. Driving or parking on vegetation is prohibited.

During the busy summer season, especially on weekends, parking fills early and heavy traffic is common in Yosemite Valley. Arrive early to increase your chances of finding parking and avoiding traffic delays, then use the free shuttle system to get around Yosemite Valley.

During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed). Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark: use the food lockers available in this parking area.

Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces near the shuttle stop and near the path to Yosemite Village. The restroom next to the parking lot has two wheelchair accessible family restrooms.
data.audioDescription: The Yosemite Village Parking lot is laid out in a large semi-circle and has four long rows of parking, rows A, B, C, and D. Rows A and B are split into three sections, A1, A2, A3, B1, B2, and B3. Rows C and D are at the inner part of the semi-circle parking lot. A two lane bike and pedestrian path that leads to the visitor center or to Half Dome Village, is located at the north end of the parking lot. Trees line the road and the parking lot. Half Dome is viewable in the distance through the trees.

data.title: Yosemite Village Post Office
data.listingDescription:
Mail postcards and letters with the Yosemite National Park postmark to your family and friends.



Hours :
Year-round,
Monday - Friday
8:30am to 5pm,
Saturday
10am to Noon

Getting Here :
Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The post office is also located near shuttle stop 4 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle system.

Accessibility :
This facility is accessible. There are no designated accessible parking spaces available.

images.altText: A two-story building with steps leading up to the front door and trees surrounding
images.title: Yosemite Village Post Office
images.caption: Yosemite Village Post Office

data.bodyText:
Mail postcards and letters with the Yosemite National Park postmark from this historic post office built in 1925.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year round. 
Monday - Friday: 8:30 am to 5 pm
Saturday: 10 am to 12 pm

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible via the western entrance. The nearest designated accessible parking spaces are west of the Yosemite Museum and can be reached via paved, wheelchair accessible paths.
data.audioDescription: An elongated, two-story, building serves as the post office. The first story is made up of granite stonework, while the second story, which slightly overhangs the first story, is made up of wooden shingled siding. The second story has a row of windows with orange frames, while the first story windows and doors all have white frames. The are three sets of double doors with one set of four steps leading up to them, in the middle of the buildings facade. Potted plants hang from the rafters and some also sit on the ground, between each set of doors. Above the middle set of double doors is a wooden sign, that reads Post Office, Yosemite National Park, California, zip code 95389. A small wooden sign attached to the left door of the middle set of double doors reads Open, Monday through Friday, 8:30am to 5pm. A blue mailbox and a bike rack are located to the left of the path that leads to the entrances of the post office. Trees surround the building. A side entrance from the west does not have steps.
